FULL TEXT OF THE BOOK (1955 edition)
Introduction
1. Our Motherland,
the USSR, is a socialist country. Our Motherland is the largest country in the world. In the north, there is eternal ice, and in the south, the summer is so hot that oranges and lemons ripen, and tea and cotton grow. Our country ranks first in the world in natural resources. Everything necessary for life is available in our country. Up to 60 different nationalities, approximately 200 million people, live in the 16 Soviet republics. All of them united in one fraternal union—the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, or, for short, the USSR. All the peoples of the USSR live as one friendly family and work for the common good. In the USSR, there are no capitalists and landowners, as in other countries. In the USSR, there is no exploitation of man by man. We all work for ourselves, for the whole of society. From a backward country, our Motherland has become the most advanced and powerful. That is why we love our Motherland so much and are so proud of our USSR—the country of socialism. The great Communist-Bolshevik Party showed us the path to socialism. It led the struggle of our fathers and mothers, the struggle of the workers and peasants, when they overthrew the rule of the tsar, landowners, and capitalists. Under the leadership of the Communist Party, we created workers' and peasants' power; we built socialism. The peoples of our country successfully repelled all attempts to attack the USSR. The Soviet Union defeated German fascism and the Japanese invaders. Our country became even more powerful. What will this book teach you? It will tell you how people lived in the old days, how the peoples of the USSR fought against their oppressors and enemies, and how they achieved that our homeland became a country of socialism. From this book, you will also learn about the lives and struggles of peoples in other countries. All this is called history. We love our homeland and we must know its remarkable history well. Those who know history will better understand present-day life, will be better able to fight the enemies of our country and strengthen socialism.
I. Our Homeland in the Distant Past
2. How People Lived in the Distant Past
How do we learn about the lives of people in distant times? One day, children were digging a hole on the bank of a river. They found strange bones and a stone in the ground. They took the find to the teacher at school. “You guys,” said the teacher, “have found very interesting things. These are the bones of ancient large animals. Once upon a time, a long time ago, these animals inhabited our area. Now they are extinct. And the stone is a tool used by people who lived in ancient times to kill wild animals.” The teacher tied the stone to a stick, and the result was a heavy hammer.
“These are the kind of hammers primitive people had,” said the teacher.
The teacher told the children that scientists were excavating throughout the USSR and, from their finds, were learning how people lived in the most distant times.
The life of primitive people. About half a million years ago, almost our entire country was covered in a thick layer of ice. Centuries passed, and gradually the ice melted. It melted from the south. It was in the south that the first people appeared. Their life was very hard. Wild animals roamed all around—enormous mammoths and bears. People hid from them in caves and dugouts. People ate roots, berries, the meat of killed animals, and dressed in the skins of the animals they managed to kill. People hunted together, and they managed to kill even such a powerful beast as a mammoth. Together, people consumed their prey. More centuries passed. People learned to make their own fire, make tools from stone, wood, and bone. They invented the bow and arrow. Gradually, people learned to tame wild animals and began to breed livestock. After another millennia, people learned to sow useful plants and began farming. For shelter, people built huts, small huts, and wagons from cattle hides, and made clothing from flax. For a long time, people made do with stone and bone tools. Many thousands of years passed before people learned to mine ore and smelt copper and other metals. In those ancient times, people shared everything—tools and the food they obtained. Everyone was equal in their hard working life.
3. From Clan to State:
Clans and Tribes. It was impossible to hunt large animals, catch fish with nets, or cut down forests for arable land alone. Therefore, in the old days, relatives did not disperse, but lived together in clans, sometimes several hundred people. They had everything in common. They used tools communally. They went hunting and fishing together, and cultivated the land with joint efforts. The catch and harvest were divided among themselves. Livestock was shared. Elected elders supervised the work. Common affairs were decided at meetings of the entire clan. The clan protected its own. If a stranger killed a person, relatives would avenge the murdered one. Frequent wars broke out between different clans over fields, pastures, forests, and fishing grounds. Several neighboring clans formed a tribe. A tribe could consist of several thousand people. All members of a tribe spoke the same language and adhered to the same customs. The tribe had an elected leader. For many centuries, people lived in clans and tribes. Gradually, clans began to divide into families. The larger and more powerful families began to take over plots of land, some livestock, and run their own farms, stopping sharing what they obtained with others. They took captives and forced them to work for them. Thus, inequality arose within the tribe. Instead of communal ownership of the products and tools obtained, private property emerged. Some clan members acquired more property, others less. There emerged the rich and the poor. The rich and military leaders of warlike and powerful tribes raided their neighbors, took people captive and turned them into involuntary slaves. Tribal leaders and wealthy men received more slaves than other warriors. Those who accumulated large numbers of slaves became even richer. Wealthy leaders gathered bands of warriors around themselves, fed, housed, and supplied them with weapons. With these bands, the leaders launched new raids. They kept the plunder and captives from these raids for themselves and their warriors. The leaders and wealthy men forced not only slaves but also their own tribesmen to work for them and took a portion of their spoils. Thus, oppressors—the rich and the oppressed—the poor—emerged within the tribe. A state emerged. A small group of wealthy men began to live at the expense of the vast majority of workers, oppressing and robbing them. The leaders, with the help of their retinues, forced slaves and tribesmen to obey them. They became absolute masters of their tribes. Such tribal leaders were called princes, kings, and khans. To keep people in line, princes, khans, and kings expanded their retinues, established their own courts, and instituted various punishments. Not content with dominating their own tribes, they also subjugated neighboring, weaker tribes. This is how states were formed.
4. The oldest states in our country:
The first states in Transcaucasia and Central Asia. The most ancient states in our country arose in the south of Transcaucasia. This was about 3,000 years ago. The first state in Transcaucasia was called Urartu. It was located in the Ararat region near Lake Baiskoye. Georgia and Armenia later emerged on the territory of this state. The kings of Urartu had many slaves who built palaces for them and dug canals to irrigate the royal fields and gardens. The kings of Urartu waged constant wars with neighboring states. These wars were very brutal. This is evident from the inscription that one of the kings of Urartu had his slaves carve on a rock: "I put sixty-four thousand people to death, some I carried off alive." Similar states existed in Central Asia. These were the states of the ancestors of today's Uzbeks, Tajiks, and Turkmens. Their rulers also constantly warred with their neighbors. The ancient states of Transcaucasia and Central Asia had many cities. To protect against enemies, high stone walls were erected around the cities. Skilled craftsmen and slaves built houses for the wealthy, warehouses for goods, and for trade. Many artisans lived in the cities, and trade was brisk. City dwellers invented the alphabet and learned to read and write. For example, the alphabet was invented in Georgia more than 2,000 years ago. The first scientists appeared in the cities, and science and art began to develop. Peoples who inhabited Siberia and Eastern Europe in ancient times. Numerous tribes of nomadic pastoralists have long lived in southern Siberia and the Black Sea region. Led by their kings, they moved across the steppes with herds of cattle and horses in search of good pastures. About 2,500 years ago, the Scythian nomads were particularly powerful among these tribes. Under the rule of the Scythian kings, there were many nomadic and sedentary farming tribes and slaves. Over 2,500 years ago, settlers from Greece arrived on the northern shores of the Black Sea by ship. The Greeks built several cities here and conducted extensive trade with the Scythians. They bought cattle, grain, and fish from the Scythians and sent them to Greece for sea. Gradually, the Greek cities expanded and united into a single state. Wealthy Greek rulers and merchants did not work themselves. All the work was done by slaves, mostly Scythian captives. 2,000 years ago, Scythian slaves, led by the slave Savmak, rebelled against their oppressors and seized power. But the slave rebellion was suppressed by foreign troops arriving from overseas.
A slave in shackles.
In the 4th century AD, the powerful nomadic Huns attacked and routed Greek cities. In the 5th century, the formidable Hunnic ruler Attila launched a campaign from the Black Sea steppes against the peoples of Western Europe, conquering many of them. But after Attila's death, his kingdom disintegrated under the onslaught of other nomads coming from Asia. In the 6th century, the nomadic Khazar state emerged on the Volga in place of the Hunnic possessions, and further up the Volga, the state of the Bulgarians. The neighboring Slavic tribes warred with the Khazars and Bulgars for many years.
5. The Slavs.
The Slavs and their neighbors. Fifteen centuries ago, Slavic tribes occupied lands along the shores of the Baltic Sea, along the Dnieper and Danube, and in the upper reaches of the Oka and Volga rivers. Subsequently, the Slavs living in Eastern Europe formed three large peoples: Russians, Ukrainians, and Belarusians. To the east, their neighbors were the Volga tribes—the ancestors of the modern Mari, Mordvins, and other peoples—and further afield, the Bulgarian and Khazar states. To the south, the Slavs fought with the nomads of the Black Sea steppes. They also fought with the Greek state of Byzantium, a wealthy and cultured empire for its time. Greek artisans built remarkable buildings, palaces, and churches. The Greeks had writers, musicians, and painters. They produced beautiful silk fabrics, tableware, and gold and silver items. Byzantium had many well-armed soldiers. But the brave and courageous Slavs often defeated Greek troops. In the mid-ninth century, they waged a successful war against the Greeks and even attacked the Byzantine capital, Constantinople. In the west, the Slavs had to fight Germanic tribes and the Varangians. Slavic occupations. The ancient Slavs hunted and collected honey from wild bees. Later, agriculture became their main occupation. The Slavs would burn a patch of forest and sow grain into the ash-fertilized soil. This method yielded a good harvest, but after 3-4 years, the soil would become depleted, requiring a new patch of forest to be burned. In the steppe, the soil was loosened with hoes and then grain was sown, but even with this method, the soil would cease to yield after 4-5 years. Old plots had to be abandoned and new ones developed. This type of arable work, using very crude tools, was carried out communally—by the clan. When the iron-tipped plow appeared, horses began to be harnessed to the plow. Cattle manure was used as fertilizer. Fertilized and better cultivated arable land now yielded more food. A small plot of arable land could feed a family. The need for large communities to cultivate arable land began to disappear. Individual families were assigned plots of land, considering them their own. Clan and tribal leaders seized large tracts of land and forced their slaves to cultivate them. Free but impoverished people of various clans worked on these plots. Owners of plows and horses would rent out their plows or horses for a share of the harvest, thereby growing rich. The former equality disappeared; oppressors and oppressed, rich landowners and poor plowmen, emerged among the kin. By the 9th century, the Slavs already had boyars—landowners and wealthy men—as well as princes—tribal rulers. Princes and boyars traded grain, honey, and wax with the Greeks and other neighbors, but their greatest trade was in slaves captured by princely or boyar retinues. Trade took place in fortified points along trade routes, mostly along the banks of large rivers. By the 9th century, several Slavic principalities had emerged. The center of each was a city where the prince and his retinue resided. By this time, the Slavs had several cities. The most important of these were Kiev and Novgorod.
II. The Kievan State
6. Formation of the Kievan Principality
Varangian raids. In the 9th century, bands of Varangians, inhabitants of Scandinavia, raided the Slavic lands around Novgorod and along the Dnieper. Varangian princes and their retinues stole furs, honey, and wax from the Slavs and took people captive. They loaded the captured loot and captives onto boats and sailed along the rivers and lakes connecting the Baltic with the Black Sea, traveling to trade with the Greeks in Byzantium. This route was called "the route from the Varangians to the Greeks." It ran from the Gulf of Finland along the Neva River, Lake Ladoga, and the Volkhov River to Lake Ilmen. From there, the boats traveled up the Lovat River and were then dragged overland to the Dnieper. Rapids, or large rocks, blocking the Dnieper, impeded passage. Here, boats and luggage had to be unloaded and dragged along the shore. The warlike Pechenegs, who roamed the surrounding area, took advantage of this and often attacked passing merchants. From the Dnieper, Varangian boats entered the Black Sea and, keeping close to the shore, sailed to Byzantium. The Slavs, along with neighboring tribes, often rebelled against the Varangian robbers and drove them back across the sea. Individual Varangian retinues managed to return to Slavic lands and subjugate local Slavic princes, imposing tribute on the population. The beginning of the Kievan Principality. At the end of the 9th century, as recounted in ancient records, there was a Varangian prince in Novgorod named Rurik. The Slavs he conquered paid him tribute. After Rurik's death, the warlike Oleg became prince. He did not remain in Novgorod, but descended the Dnieper, reached Kiev, captured it, and made it his capital. From the beginning of the 10th century, the Kievan Slavic principality was called Kievan Rus'. Oleg united many Slavic tribes under his rule and imposed heavy tribute on them. Some Slavic princes were exterminated, while others submitted to Oleg and, together with him, collected tribute from the Slavic population. The Varangian princes and warriors did not possess a higher culture than the Slavs; they soon interbred with the Slavs and adopted their language, faith, names, and customs.
Prince Oleg.
Prince Oleg demonstrated vigorous activity. Under him, Kiev was heavily fortified. Guard fortresses were erected on the state's borders to protect against nomadic peoples. According to legend, Oleg, with a huge army, some in boats and some on horseback, set out on a campaign against Byzantium. He ravaged the environs of Constantinople and laid siege to it. The Greek Emperor (as the chief ruler of the Greeks was called) offered Oleg a large ransom: much gold, fine fabrics, wine, and slaves. In 911, the Greeks concluded a trade treaty with Oleg. Oleg greatly strengthened Kievan Rus'. He gathered the disparate Slavic tribes and principalities under his rule. Kievan Rus' began to be reckoned with by both the Byzantine Empire and neighboring western states. Prince Igor. After Oleg's death, Rurik's son, Igor, ascended to the throne. Under his rule, the expansion of Kievan Rus' continued. Igor fought extensively, like Oleg. He led campaigns against the Caucasus and Byzantium. The Greeks paid Igor a large and valuable ransom. By agreement with the Greeks, he pledged to defend Byzantium from nomadic raids.
Polyudye. The prince and his retinue collect tribute from the population. The population brought animal skins, wax, and honey. The prince's servant counted and noted the amount of tribute brought on a tablet.
Every autumn, Igor collected tribute from the population—he went "from one person to another," and therefore the collection of tribute was called "polyudye." By the time the prince and his retinue arrived, the villagers had prepared furs, honey, wax, and grain. Polyudye was a heavy duty for the population. Once, Prince Igor was collecting tribute from a Slavic tribe, the Drevlians, who lived on the right bank of the Dnieper. The Drevlians gave him everything he demanded. Igor left, but he felt the collection was insufficient. He returned and demanded tribute a second time. The Drevlians said, "If a wolf gets into the habit of wandering among the flock, he will slaughter the entire flock. Let's kill him." They routed the prince's retinue and tied him by the feet to the bent treetops. When the trees were released, the prince was torn to pieces.
7. Princess Olga and Prince Svyatoslav
. Princess Olga. After Igor's death, his wife Olga became prince. She took cruel revenge on the Drevlians for her husband's death. Olga's retinue laid siege to the Drevlians' main city. For a whole year, she stood with her army at the city walls and was unable to take it. Then, according to legend, she resorted to cunning. She demanded a very light tribute from the Drevlians—three pigeons and three sparrows from each household. The Drevlians agreed to this tribute. By Olga's command, tarred bundles of tow were tied to the pigeons' and sparrows' feet, lit, and the birds were released. The pigeons and sparrows each flew to their nests, and immediately a fire broke out throughout the city. Olga's troops rushed to the burning city and killed many of its defenders. Olga imposed a heavy tribute on the Drevlians. But then she established precise tribute amounts for all tribes, thereby streamlining its collection. Olga traveled to Byzantium to learn from the Greeks how to govern a state, and there she became acquainted with the Greek faith. The Slavs at that time still practiced paganism. They did not understand natural phenomena and feared them. Storms destroyed their homes. Lightning set houses and trees ablaze. The sun scorched crops. People considered the sun, wind, and thunderstorms to be gods. They made images of them from wood and stone and sacrificed animals, and sometimes children and captives, to them. This was their way of appeasing the fearsome gods they had invented. Olga was delighted with how the Greek priests preached everywhere that the king's power was sacred. Olga saw that the Greek faith was an excellent means of strengthening the prince's power and uniting the disparate Slavic tribes into a single state. Therefore, she herself converted to the Greek faith—Christianity—and persuaded her son Svyatoslav to do the same. But Svyatoslav refused. He believed that only arms could unite the Slavs and create a strong state. Prince Svyatoslav. Svyatoslav became Prince of Kiev after Olga. He spent his entire life on campaigns. During campaigns, he slept on the ground, by the fire, in the open air, with a mat under him and a saddle under his head. Svyatoslav ate whatever he could find—horse meat, animal meat baked over coals. Fearless, he warned the enemy of his attack and sent a message: "I am coming against you."
The prince with his retinue. An ancient drawing.
Svyatoslav conquered many tribes on the Oka River, plundered the Bulgarian cities on the Volga, the Circassians on the Kuban, and destroyed the Khazar kingdom. From that time on, the Khazar kingdom ceased to exist. The Kievan principality grew stronger and more powerful. The entire Black Sea region came under the rule of the Kievan prince. Then Svyatoslav began a war with the Bulgarians living on the Danube. He captured many cities from them and planned to move his capital from Kiev to the Danube. The cunning Byzantine emperor, fearing such a powerful and warlike neighbor as Svyatoslav, enlisted the Pecheneg nomads, then living in the steppes near the Black Sea, to attack Kiev. While Svyatoslav was driving the Pechenegs away from Kiev, the Bulgarians on the Danube conspired with the Greeks to fight Svyatoslav together. In a new war with the Bulgarians and Greeks, Svyatoslav was defeated. On his return to Kiev, he was ambushed by the Pechenegs at the Dnieper Rapids and routed. Svyatoslav himself fell in battle. The Pecheneg prince made a cup from his skull and drank from it at feasts.
8. The Kievan princes introduce a new faith and laws.
The campaigns of Prince Vladimir. Svyatoslav's son, Vladimir, having taken control of the Kievan principality after a protracted struggle with his brothers, followed his father's example and launched a campaign against his rebellious subjects. He pacified the rebellious tribes in the north and plundered the Bulgarian cities on the Volga. Then Vladimir marched with his retinue into Poland and captured several cities. Vladimir subjugated the Slavic Principality of Polotsk and the lands of several Lithuanian tribes—the Slavs' neighbors to the west, near the Baltic Sea. Thus, the Kievan principality grew stronger and more powerful under Vladimir. Byzantium began to reckon with him even more. Vladimir helped Byzantium suppress a rebellion by the Greek army. For this assistance, the Byzantine emperor gave him his sister in marriage. Vladimir decided to convert to Christianity. He believed that accepting the Greek faith and being related to the Byzantine emperor would strengthen his power. The introduction of Christianity. In 988, Vladimir destroyed all the images of ancient Slavic pagan gods in Kiev. The Kievans were driven into the waters of the Dnieper. Greek priests brought from Constantinople read their prayers over the people standing in the water. This was called baptism. The people rebelled against the new faith more than once, but all rebellions were suppressed by the prince's retinue. Christianity, in its time, represented a significant step forward in Russia's development compared to paganism. Along with Christianity, Greek culture and education spread among the Slavs. Byzantine artisans taught the Slavs how to build and decorate houses and churches. Learned Greek monks created a Slavic alphabet, which came to be used in the Kievan state. The prince gave Greek priests and monks money and allocated them land. The monks wrote church books in Slavic, translating them from Greek. They also recorded all important events. These records were kept "from summer to summer" (year after year) and were called chronicles. Chronicles provide much information about the history of the Eastern Slavs and neighboring countries. Folk songs and tales—bylinas—also tell us about this time. The bylinas contain many tales of the prowess of Slavic heroes and their struggle against nomads attacking the Kievan state. Prince Yaroslav the Wise. After Vladimir's death, Yaroslav, nicknamed the Wise, became the Kievan prince. Under Yaroslav, the first set of laws of the Kievan state, the "Russkaya Prazda," was compiled. The "Russkaya Pravda" set out rules for protecting the rights of slave owners, landowners, and merchants.
9. Spontaneous popular uprisings in the Kievan principality
. How princes and boyars ruled the Kievan principality. The Kievan prince had a large retinue—an army of boyars and service people. The prince's relatives and boyars governed cities and lands on behalf of the prince. Some boyars owned large amounts of land and rivaled the princes in wealth. The prince, his army, boyars, priests, and monks—all lived off the labor of slaves and farmers, the smerds. The smerds owned small plots of land, ran their own small farms, and were free, meaning they were not enslaved. Under the first Kyivan princes, they paid them only tribute, which the princes went to the polyudye to collect. Kyiv and other cities were home to artisans, traders, and the urban poor. Merchants traded with the smerds and artisans, delivering goods to the princes, boyars, and their army. The merchants kept the artisans in bondage. Large merchants traded with other countries. Free artisans built houses, churches, and bridges, sewed clothing, made dishes, and weapons. They smelted ore in bloomeries and mined iron. Blacksmiths worked in towns and villages. City residents were governed by a general assembly of citizens—the veche. The veche elected city leaders from among the wealthy and noble. Without the veche's consent, the prince could not raise an army or wage war. Therefore, he had to obey the veche in many ways. The princes tried to seize control of the cities and abused the peasants in the villages. Princes and boyars enslaved the smerds. In the 11th century, princes and boyars greatly intensified the oppression of the people. They established their own laws, administered justice, and meted out punishment. For example, under Yaroslav the Wise, the murder of a boyar was punishable by 80 hryvnia (or 16 kilograms of silver), while the murder of a smerd was punishable by only 5 hryvnia. Princes and boyars seized land and declared it their own. The smerds living on the seized lands were forced to work the princes' and boyars' fields, build bridges, and fortifications. Little by little, free farmers were reduced to dependent peasants, that is, serfs. The smerds responded to these practices with new uprisings against the princes and boyars. Spontaneous uprisings against princes and boyars also occurred in the cities. Many uprisings occurred in Kiev, Novgorod, and other cities in the 11th and 12th centuries. Princes and boyars with their retinues suppressed these uprisings without much effort, as they were spontaneous and unintentional. In 1113, the oppressed urban populace of Kiev rebelled against the princely authority, the merchant moneylenders, and the wealthy Kiev-Pechersk Monastery. They were supported by the smerds (commoners). Then, the frightened boyars and merchants hastened to summon Vladimir Monomakh, Prince of Pereyaslav, as their prince. Vladimir suppressed this rebellion. Fearing further uprisings, he somewhat eased the payment of debts to moneylenders and made minor improvements to the situation of some farmers. Vladimir Monomakh was well known in Byzantium and Europe. For his time, he was an educated man. His mother was the daughter of a Byzantine emperor, and his sister was married to a German emperor. He himself was married to the daughter of an English king. Vladimir Monomakh was the last powerful prince of Kiev.
10. Novgorod Land.
Fragmentation of the Kievan Principality. In the 12th century, the Kievan Principality was divided among the sons, grandsons, and relatives of Vladimir Monomakh. Constant wars broke out between them for control of principalities and cities. In these wars, the princes mercilessly plundered the commoners and townspeople, forcing them to participate in their campaigns. The princes dealt cruelly with each other. They gouged out the eyes of the defeated and starved them in prison. Individual princes grew wealthy and became independent of the Grand Prince in Kiev. Thus, in the 12th century, the Galicia-Volyn Principality to the west of Kiev, and the Rostov-Suzdal and Novgorod Principalities to the north, grew wealthy and powerful. The Kievan land was devastated by raids from the south by a nomadic people, the Polovtsians. An ancient work of art, The Tale of Igor's Campaign, has come down to us about the struggle against them at the end of the 12th century. The Kievan land was further devastated by the rapacious plunder of princes and boyars. The peasants, unable to tolerate their violence, left the Dnieper for farther afield—to the Oka and Volga. Kiev's trade also began to decline. Merchants began traveling from Europe to Asia by other routes, bypassing Kiev. Kiev began to lose its importance as a major city. By the early 13th century, Kiev had become desolate. Novgorod emerged as the leading center of foreign trade. Novgorod, the ruler of the Novgorod land, stood on the route to the Baltic Sea, along whose shores lay German and Swedish cities. Novgorod merchants and boyars conducted extensive trade with their German and Swedish neighbors. They received materiel, weapons, and other goods from them, and in return sold them furs and agricultural produce. To obtain furs for foreign trade, Novgorod boyars and merchants conquered lands in the north and east and forced local trappers to hand over their spoils. Novgorod thus became the capital of a very large country, with several thousand houses. While Kiev was declining, Novgorod boyars and merchants grew rich from plundering conquered peoples and trading with foreigners.
Foreign merchants unloaded their goods at the Novgorod wharf.
All affairs of the Novgorod land were governed by boyars, wealthy merchants, and the high clergy. They summoned Novgorod residents to a general assembly—a veche—but matters were decided according to the wishes of the rich and powerful boyars. The governor of Novgorod, the posadnik, elected at the veche, was always a prominent boyar. The prince in Novgorod had limited powers. Novgorod residents, the smerds of neighboring villages, and conquered tribes repeatedly rebelled against the rule of the boyars and merchants. But these uprisings never progressed beyond spontaneous rebellion. The people were unable to break the boyar and merchant power due to their lack of awareness and organization.
A veche (assembly) in Novgorod. At the assembly, urban artisans confront the boyars and wealthy merchants with their demands.
The struggle between Novgorodians and the Swedes and Germans. In the early 13th century, the Swedes attacked Novgorod. They advanced from the Baltic Sea and the Neva River, where Leningrad now stands. The Novgorodians defeated the Swedes at the Neva. Prince Alexander, who defeated the Swedes and commanded the Novgorodians, was nicknamed Nevsky for this victory. In 1242, German knights also attempted to seize Novgorod. They appeared on the shores of the Baltic Sea in the 12th century and mercilessly plundered and exterminated the Slavic, Lithuanian, and other tribes living there. The Germans built their fortresses and cities here and further intensified their atrocities. They imposed their faith on the inhabitants, destroyed their freedom, and turned them into serfs. German "knight-dogs" with a strong army attacked the Novgorod land, ravaging cities and threatening Novgorod. The great Russian commander, Prince Alexander Nevsky, gathered his troops and engaged the Germans in a decisive battle on the ice of Lake Peipus. The battle was fierce—the ice turned red with blood. In this Battle on the Ice, the Germans could not withstand the onslaught of the brave Novgorod warriors and fled. Alexander Nevsky pursued the enemy to the very border of his lands. Thus, the Novgorodians decisively repelled the enemy and defended their land from the German tyrants.
11. Suzdal Rus'
Rostov-Suzdal land. Since ancient times, the Mordvins, Mörya, Ves, and other tribes lived between the Volga and Oka rivers. Slavs also lived here. By the 10th century, the Slavic cities of Rostov and Suzdal were already in this region. Slavic farmers fled the oppression of princes and boyars from the southern regions of the Kievan Principality, ravaged by nomads. But even here, the princes and boyars seized land and forced the population to work for them.
The Princely Court.
At first, the Rostov-Suzdal land attracted little attention from the princes of the Kievan state. But this changed in the 12th century, when this remote outskirts became populated. Prince Yuri Dolgoruky, son of Vladimir Monomakh, came here from Kiev with a strong retinue and consolidated his power, subjugating the holdings of individual boyars and minor princes. Among the holdings he captured was the village of Moscow. But Andrei Bogolyubsky, son of Yuri Dolgoruky, established an even stronger foothold in Rostov-Suzdal Rus'. He waged war against Novgorod, the Bulgars on the Volga, and the Mordvin tribes. He then captured Kiev and became Grand Prince of the vast holdings of almost the entire Kievan state. Andrei Bogolyubsky made the city of Vladimir on the Klyazma River his capital. From that time on, his principality became known as Vladimir-Suzdal. Andrei Bogolyubsky sought to subjugate all the local princes and boyars. Dissatisfied with Andrei Bogolyubsky's autocracy, the boyars conspired and assassinated the prince. Vsevolod became prince in Andrei Bogolyubsky's place. He took villages and lands from the rebellious boyars and severely punished those who attempted to declare themselves independent princes. Vsevolod launched several campaigns against Novgorod and extended his authority to Kiev. He fought against the Bulgarians and Mordvins on the Volga. Vsevolod was unable to establish a strong hold on the other minor princes and boyars. After his death, the Vladimir-Suzdal Principality fragmented into small holdings. Each prince and boyar tried to live independently and did not submit to the Grand Duke. The fragmented small principalities feuded with one another. There was no unified, strong state. Each wealthy owner sought to acquire more land and power. Princes constantly warred among themselves. Constant campaigns devastated the peasant population. When the Mongol conquerors attacked the Russian principalities in the 13th century, they encountered no truly united resistance. The Vladimir-Suzdal land was fragmented into small parts and could not defend its independence.
III. Eastern Europe under the Rule of the Mongol Conquerors
12. Mongol Conquerors and the Tatar-Mongol Yoke
. The Mongols in the 12th Century. The Mongols were nomadic pastoralists. They lived in what is now the Mongolian People's Republic. In the 12th century, the Mongols were divided into large warlike tribes led by khans. The khans had abundant livestock and pastures. The subject tribes paid tribute to the khans. The khans fought among themselves and their neighbors over tribute and pastures. In the early 13th century, the talented military leader Genghis Khan rose to prominence among the Mongol khans. He assembled a vast army from various tribes and subjugated the eastern Turkic-Mongol peoples. Like a hurricane, Genghis Khan's cavalry swept through his enemies. Genghis Khan burned the wooden walls of fortresses with clay grenades laced with petroleum. He smashed stone walls with massive engines. Nothing could stop his onslaught. Genghis Khan's conquest of Central Asia and the Caucasus. Having conquered Northern China, Genghis Khan moved his troops into Central Asia and conquered it. From Central Asia, rounding the southern shores of the Caspian Sea, Genghis Khan's troops advanced to the Caucasus and conquered Armenia and Georgia. In Georgia, the Mongols encountered strong resistance. At this time, Georgia was a more powerful state than Armenia. The Georgians fought bravely, but the Mongols defeated them and imposed heavy tribute on Georgia and Armenia. For hundreds of years, Central Asia and the peoples of Transcaucasia remained under Mongol rule.
Mongol cavalry on campaign.
Batu Khan and his conquest of the Russian principalities. Having subjugated all the peoples of the Caucasus, the Mongol army defeated the combined forces of the Slavic princes and the Polovtsians at the Kalka River in 1223. Carrying rich booty, the Mongols retreated to Asia. Thirteen years later, the Mongols reappeared on the Volga. At their head stood Batu Khan, the grandson of the deceased Genghis Khan. This time, the Mongols attacked the Russians from the east. Batu Khan defeated the Volga Bulgars and the Mordvins, then slaughtered the armies of the Russian princes one by one. In 1240, he captured Kyiv and marched on Western Europe. Repulsed by the Czechs, Batu Khan turned back and founded his own state on the lower Volga River—the Golden Horde—with its capital at Sarai. It was a wealthy city with stone palaces, gardens, and a mint. The Khan of the Golden Horde became the ruler of the lands he had conquered. The princes remained in their positions, but were subordinate to the Khan. The Tatar-Mongols collected tribute from the population in favor of the khan. To collect the tribute, the khan's deputies were posted in the cities with military detachments. No one was spared in collecting the tribute.
"...whoever has no money, he will take his child; whoever has no child, he will take his wife; whoever has no wife, he will take his head"
(that is, he will take her prisoner and sell her into slavery). So went the folk song. Since rebellions constantly arose against the Tatar tax collectors, the khans of the Golden Horde later handed over the collection of tribute to the Russian princes themselves. Thus began the Tatar, or, more accurately, Tatar-Mongol yoke.
Khan Batu.
13. Moscow and the first Moscow princes
Moscow. On the hill where the Kremlin now stands, there was a settlement called Moscow at the beginning of the 12th century. Moscow is first mentioned in chronicles in 1147. In 1156, it was surrounded by a wooden wall. The Tatar-Mongols of Khan Batu burned Moscow and the wooden walls of its fortifications. Some residents perished, others fled into the surrounding forests. But gradually, the population regrouped near Moscow and took up farming. By the 14th century, Moscow had become the capital of a small principality. Moscow's central location in the Russian lands helped the Moscow princes unite other principalities around it. Moscow was surrounded by forests, making it easier to fight enemies, especially the Tatars. Moscow's location on convenient river routes allowed the princes to collect large duties on all goods transported along the Moscow River. Ivan Kalita. Moscow gained particular strength under Prince Ivan (1328–1341), who was nicknamed "Kalita," meaning moneybag. With gifts and flattery, Kalita won over his overlord, the Khan of the Golden Horde, and received the right to collect tribute for the Khan from all Russian lands. Kalita kept part of this tribute for himself and his principality. With the money he accumulated, he purchased villages, volosts, and even entire principalities. Ivan Kalita slandered the Tatars against neighboring princes and set the Tatar Khan against them. Acting on his denunciations, the Tatars killed the princes and ravaged their principalities. Kalita annexed these devastated principalities to his Moscow Principality. The Khan made Kalita senior over the other Russian princes, declaring him "Grand Prince." At the beginning of his reign, Kalita owned only four towns; upon his death, he left his children 97 villages and towns.
Moscow in the 12th century.
Thus, Kalita united the disparate Russian principalities into a single state centered around Moscow. Kalita's descendants were similarly "gatherers." By the end of the 14th century, the Moscow Principality had become so powerful that Kalita's grandson, the outstanding military leader Prince Dmitry, decided to openly oppose the Tatar yoke. In 1380, at Kulikovo Field on the Don River, he defeated the Tatar forces led by Khan Mamai. The victory at Kulikovo Field was of tremendous historical significance: it united the Russian people in the struggle for their national independence, inspired them with self-confidence, and undermined the foundations of the Tatar yoke. However, two years later, the Tatars gathered their forces, attacked Moscow, and captured it, forcing it to pay tribute, albeit less than before. The young Moscow Principality nevertheless grew stronger. Its old enemy, the Golden Horde, was weakening. But a new, powerful adversary emerged on the western borders of the Moscow Principality: the Lithuanian state, united with Poland. The Lithuanian state and its relationship to Moscow. The Lithuanian tribes were neighbors of the Slavs and lived to the west, near the Baltic Sea. By the 13th century, the Lithuanian tribes united under a single prince and, in the 13th and 14th centuries, took over Belarusian lands and parts of Ukrainian and Russian lands. Lithuania became a large state. At the end of the 14th century, it came very close to the Grand Duchy of Moscow and captured the city of Smolensk. The Lithuanian prince Jogaila, having married the Polish queen, became king of Poland and Lithuania. The union of Lithuania with Poland greatly strengthened both states. They now began to exert even greater pressure on the Grand Duchy of Moscow. Life was hard for Ukrainians, Belarusians, and Russians under the rule of their princes and boyars. But their lives became even harder under the rule of Polish and Lithuanian invaders, who reduced all peasants to serfdom. The Polish lords forced peasants to convert from Greek Orthodoxy to Catholicism, their own faith. The Polish lords were particularly insistent on this conversion in Ukraine. In the cities, the lords did not allow Ukrainians and Belarusians to engage in trade or crafts. The lords controlled all city governance. The lords dreamed of subjugating the entire Muscovite Principality. But they were attacked by German knights entrenched on the shores of the Baltic Sea. The Germans plundered Lithuanian and Polish cities and ravaged the lands. They lacked the strength to fight the Germans and Moscow at the same time. Lithuania then made peace with the Muscovite Principality. The combined forces of Polish, Lithuanian, and Russian troops routed the Germans at the village of Grunwald (1410). Russian troops, especially the Smolensk regiments, distinguished themselves in this battle. However, soon after, Lithuania and Poland again intensified their attacks on the Muscovite state. To defeat Moscow, the lords formed an alliance with the Tatars.
14. Tamerlane and the Decline of the Golden Horde
Tamerlane. While the young Moscow Principality, uniting under a single prince, grew and strengthened, the Mongol state itself increasingly fragmented. Only occasionally did individual conquering khans emerge among the Mongols. One such conqueror was Tamerlane. Tamerlane was born in Central Asia in 1336. As he grew older, he became the leader of a band of daring men and moved from one ruler to another. Tamerlane first came to prominence during the suppression of a popular uprising in the city of Samarkand (Central Asia). Having dealt brutally with the rebels, Tamerlane soon declared himself Khan-ruler and made Samarkand his capital. Tamerlane conquered a number of neighboring states. In 1395, he defeated Tokhtamysh, Khan of the Golden Horde, thereby helping Moscow to quickly free itself from the Tatar yoke. Tamerlane was ferocious and cruel. After capturing one city, he buried 4,000 people alive. When capturing another, he ordered his soldiers to bring him 70,000 heads of inhabitants and use them to build a tower. No matter what countries Tamerlane conquered, he brought the best craftsmen from everywhere to Central Asia. He brought up to 150,000 such artisans to his capital, Samarkand, whose embellishment he took great care to embellish. Uzbeks in Central Asia. After Tamerlane's death in 1405, the states he had conquered gradually regained their independence. In the 15th century, Central Asia was conquered by the nomadic Uzbeks, who had previously lived in the lands of modern-day Kazakhstan. The Uzbeks firmly established themselves in Central Asia. Uzbek khans became the heads of the states of Khorezm and Bukhara.
IV. The Creation of the Russian National State
15. Expansion of the Muscovite State under Ivan III and the End of the Tatar-Mongol Yoke
. The annexation of Novgorod and the liberation of the Muscovite State from the rule of the Tatar Khan. To combat the Tatars and Lithuanian-Polish lords, the Muscovite princes sought to expand their holdings and strengthen their power over all Russian lands. Ivan III achieved this. He became Grand Prince in 1462. At this time, the Muscovite Principality was still under the rule, albeit weakened, of the Khan of the Golden Horde. Ivan deceived the Khan, assuring him of his loyalty, but quietly sought to accumulate strength and escape Tatar subordination. Ivan III united the principalities neighboring Moscow—Tver, Ryazan, and others—under his rule. All these principalities opposed unification under a single prince and formed alliances with the Tatars and Lithuania against Moscow. But Ivan III ensured that the Muscovite state became a strong and unified Russian national state under his rule. Only Novgorod remained independent. At the end of the 15th century, Ivan III waged war against Novgorod. The Novgorod boyars had formed an alliance with Lithuania. But this did not save them. Ivan III defeated the Novgorod forces, and Novgorod also became part of the unified Russian state. By this time, the Golden Horde had disintegrated into three khanates: Kazan, Astrakhan, and Crimea. The Siberian Kingdom on the Irtysh River seceded from it. The Moscow princes benefited from this disintegration of the Golden Horde. Now the Golden Horde was no threat to the strengthened Russian state. Choosing an opportune moment, Ivan III declared to the Khan of the Golden Horde that he would not recognize his authority over Moscow. The Khan then waged war against Ivan III. The opposing armies met on the Ugra River, but neither dared engage in decisive battle. Thus, they stood facing each other for several months. Frosts set in. The khan had no fodder for his cavalry, and he also received news of unrest in the Horde, so he turned back. Ivan III thus emerged as the "victor." Thus, in 1480, the Tatar-Mongol yoke, which had lasted over two hundred years, ended. Soon, the Horde finally withered and disintegrated. Ivan III's war with Lithuania and Poland. In 1500, war began between Ivan III and the Polish-Lithuanian king. The Polish-Lithuanian forces were utterly defeated, and their main leader was captured by Russian troops. The king then formed an alliance with the Baltic Germans—the knights. The Germans were initially successful, but then Russian troops went on the offensive, routed the Germans, and ravaged their lands. The war ended with a six-year truce. Ivan III retained the Russian and Belarusian lands he had conquered from the lords. Under Ivan III, the Russian state's holdings tripled. Ivan III became "Sovereign of All Russia." After the capture of Byzantium by the Turks in 1453, Ivan III married the Greek princess Sophia Palaiologina. Ivan III now claimed to be the heir of the Byzantine emperors. Ivan III adopted the ancient coat of arms of Byzantium (the double-headed eagle) as the coat of arms of the Muscovite state. Ivan began to call himself "Sovereign of All Russia."
Coat of arms of the Muscovite state under Ivan III.
Ivan began to intensively embellish Moscow. He imported Italian artisans, technicians, and artists from abroad. Ivan III rebuilt the small Moscow Kremlin into a large stone castle with buildings previously unseen in Moscow. The Kremlin walls and towers, built by the Italians, still vividly recall the time of Ivan III. Ivan introduced the opulent court customs of the Greek emperors to the Kremlin Palace. But the strengthening of the power of the Moscow prince led to the strengthening of the oppression of the boyars over the broad masses of the peasantry.
16. How were peasants oppressed in the Muscovite state in the 15th century
Corvée and quitrent. Throughout the Moscow Principality, princes, boyars, and monasteries owned estates. The landowners lived with their families, servants, and guards in estates separate from the peasants, surrounded by a high wall. Villages spread out in all directions from the master's manor. The peasants lived in low, smoky huts without floors, windows, or chimneys. The peasants plowed the land with wooden plows. The plots of land that the peasants cultivated and fed themselves from were now no longer peasant property, but princely, boyar, or monastery property. In exchange for this land, the peasants were obliged to do whatever the owner demanded of them. They plowed the master's land, threshed and milled the master's grain, mowed and hauled hay to the master's manor, built the master's manor, mansions, and bridges, and dug ponds and ditches. But all this was not enough for the princes, boyars, and monasteries. They believed that the peasants were still working too much for themselves and too little for their masters. The landowners began to take some of the land the peasants were cultivating for themselves. They demanded that the peasants work even more on the master's fields. All this work was called corvée. In addition to corvée, the peasants also gave their masters the products of their farms: grain, cattle, chickens, eggs, milk, butter, and so on. This was called quitrent. Those peasants who did not fulfill their corvée or quitrent were severely punished by their masters: they were beaten with sticks until they were half dead, or imprisoned. The peasants were bound to the land. A peasant could leave his master, but he had to leave behind his farmstead and buildings and pay all his debts, of which there were many. The peasant had to find another master who would let him onto his land. The new master had the same terms of use as the old one. The peasant had no way to escape his bondage, except to flee to lands where there were no masters. But such free lands became fewer and fewer. Landowners found it unprofitable for peasants to leave them whenever they wanted. Boyars and monasteries began allowing peasants to transfer to new owners only after all summer work had been completed. In 1497, Ivan III issued a law stipulating that a peasant could transfer from one lord to another only in late autumn, on St. George's Day. This strengthened the peasants' bondage to the lord's land. The lord had the right to judge his peasants and beat them for disobedience. In addition to boyar and monastic holdings, under Ivan III, the holdings of noble landowners—military servicemen, princely and boyar servants—began to appear. For participating in campaigns and guarding the borders, they received payment from the prince in lands and the peasants living on them. From these lands, cultivated by the peasants and subject to the landowner's authority, the landowner was required to feed himself and his family, acquire military equipment and horses, and lead a certain number of warriors on campaign. The prince placed service people on the lands he had seized. Such lands were called estates, and their owners were called pomeshchiks. Boyars, on the other hand, owned lands by inheritance—from father to son—and their holdings were called votchinas, or "otchinas."
V. Expansion of the Russian State
17. Ivan IV and the Defeat of the Volga Tatars
. The Tsar-Autocrat. Ivan III's grandson, the future Tsar Ivan IV the Terrible, lost his father early in life; the boyars poisoned his mother and seized power for ten years. In 1547, seventeen-year-old Ivan became the first of the Moscow sovereigns to declare himself autocratic tsar and began to govern the state independently, distrusting the boyars and relying on the noble landowners. To consolidate his power, Ivan IV considered it essential that the people of his state be educated by reading books glorifying the Tsar's authority. Ivan IV used book printing, a Western invention, for this purpose and established a printing house in Moscow. Books were printed there under his special supervision. The first Russian printer at this printing house was Ivan Fedorov.
Ivan Fedorov at the printing house.
The conquest of Kazan and Astrakhan. Consolidating his power and authority, Ivan IV continued the policy of conquest of his grandfather, Ivan III, and his father, Vasily III, who had captured Smolensk from Lithuania. Ivan IV decided to first capture the Tatar khanates on the Volga. In the autumn of 1552, Ivan IV, with a large army and numerous cannons, laid siege to Kazan, the capital of the Kazan Khanate. The siege lasted all autumn. The Tatars fought with desperate courage and tenacity. On the tsar's orders, a secret underground passage from Kazan to the water was blown up, forcing the city's inhabitants to drink tainted water from puddles and wells. The people of Kazan continued to defend their city. Without rest, day and night, they fought off the besiegers. The Tsar ordered tunnels dug under the walls and blew them up with barrels of gunpowder. Fierce fighting raged at the city gates and in the breaches. Ivan IV's troops—up to 150,000 strong—defeated the Tatars. Kazan was annexed to the Muscovite state. Many Muscovite service people and merchants were resettled in Kazan, while the Tatars were permitted to live only in the suburbs. Captured lands were distributed among landowners. Fortresses were built throughout the Kazan Khanate, housing Muscovite troops. All residents of the Kazan Khanate—Tatars, Mordvins, Mari, Chuvash, and Bashkirs—were forced to build fortresses. With the conquest of Kazan, they all came under the rule of Ivan IV.
St. Basil's Church, built in Moscow by Ivan IV after the capture of Kazan.
In 1556, Ivan IV's troops captured the city of Astrakhan on the Volga, the capital of the Nogai Tatars. The entire Volga route fell into the hands of the Russian Tsar. After this, Ivan IV captured the northeastern Caucasus and built several fortresses on the Terek River. Circassian and Kabardian princes began to enter his service. The Russian state began to transform from a national one into a multinational one, consisting of different peoples.
18. Reprisals against the boyars and Ivan IV's warriors
. Oprichnina. Having seized Tatar lands on the Volga and fortified himself in the North Caucasus, Ivan IV began a war with the Baltic Germans, Poland, Lithuania, and the Swedes. Ivan IV wanted to reach the shores of the Baltic Sea and establish relations with Western European peoples. The Swedes and Germans prevented foreign craftsmen from entering Moscow and did everything they could to hinder Russian trade. After the initial defeats in the war, Ivan uncovered the treason of the leading boyars who owned estates. These traitors went over to the service of the Poles and Lithuanians. Tsar Ivan waged a brutal war against the boyars, who opposed the unification of the country and the strengthening of the Tsar's autocratic power. He executed many boyars and their supporters, exiling others to remote parts of the state. He confiscated their lands, distributing them to small landowners (nobles). Ivan IV needed to combat the boyars to finally break these petty tsars, which the boyars were, and to strengthen his unified power. To combat them, Ivan IV formed a special detachment of several thousand landowners, calling them "oprichniks." The oprichniks had their own distinctive uniform. A dog's head and a broom were tied to an oprichnik's saddle. These were the insignia of his office: to sniff out and track down the Tsar's enemies and sweep away traitorous boyars. Ivan IV and his oprichniks exterminated many boyars. Ivan distributed the lands of the executed to the oprichniks and other landowners. In this way, Ivan the Terrible strengthened autocratic power in the Russian Tsardom by destroying the boyars' property. In this way, he effectively completed Kalita's unification of the disparate appanage principalities into a single strong state.
Tsar Ivan the Terrible (1530–1584). From a painting by V. Vasnetsov.
Peasants and Cossacks. Under Ivan IV, the peasants' situation worsened considerably. Toward the end of his reign, peasants were forbidden to leave their masters, even on St. George's Day. It was then that the saying arose: "So much for St. George's Day, grandma!" Fleeing the plunder and violence of landowners and oprichniki, peasants fled from the center of the Russian Tsardom to the steppes, on its southern outskirts, and settled there. Many fugitive peasants settled along the Don and Dnieper rivers. Soon, settlements grew there, the inhabitants of which were called Cossacks. War for the Baltic lands. Ivan the Terrible fought for 24 years to gain access to the Baltic Sea. At the beginning of the war, Russian troops routed the German knights and captured several cities. But the war ended in failure for the Russian state. Poland, Sweden, and Denmark intervened. The Poles and Lithuanians recaptured the Baltics and took from Ivan the Terrible the Belarusian lands he had conquered at the beginning of the war. The Swedes took the shores of the Gulf of Finland from him. A convenient sea route for trade with foreign countries was once again lost. Ivan the Terrible was forced to conduct trade with foreign countries only via the inconvenient White Sea, which froze for several months each year. This route was accidentally discovered by an English captain. He wanted to cross the Arctic Ocean to India, but a storm drove him to the mouth of the Northern Dvina River, where the port city of Arkhangelsk was later founded.
Yermak.
Annexation of the Siberian Kingdom. At the end of the 16th century, the lands of Western Siberia were annexed by the Tsardom of Muscovy. The Siberian Kingdom was inhabited by Tatars and other Siberian peoples, and was ruled by Khan Kuchum. In 1581, the Stroganov merchants, wealthy owners of lands in the Urals, sent a small detachment of mercenary Cossacks, well-armed with firearms, against Kuchum. This detachment of Cossacks, under the command of Yermak, routed Khan Kuchum's numerous troops, armed with bows and arrows. Ivan the Terrible rewarded Yermak with military armor and a fur coat from his own shoulders, and his Cossacks with rich gifts. Kuchum, however, later managed to defeat Yermak's detachment. Yermak himself died in the Irtysh River during a night attack by Kuchum's warriors. Kuchum regained his power in the Siberian Kingdom, but not for long. Voivodes and troops sent from Moscow finally conquered the Siberian Kingdom a few years later. Under Ivan IV, Russia's dominions expanded many times over. His kingdom became one of the largest states in the world.
VI. Peasant Wars and Uprisings of Oppressed Peoples in the 17th Century
19. The First Peasant War in the Russian State
Tsar Boris Godunov and the Beginning of Peasant Uprisings. In 1584, Ivan IV died. Shortly before his death, in a fit of rage, he killed his eldest son, Ivan, with a blow to the temple with his staff. He was left with two other sons—the feeble-minded Feodor and little Dmitry. The feeble-minded Feodor Ivanovich became tsar. Under Feodor, the tsar's wife's brother, Boris Godunov, a former oprichnik of Ivan the Terrible, ruled the kingdom. Little Dmitry, who lived with his mother in the city of Uglich, died or was killed by Godunov's supporters. In 1598, after Feodor's death, Boris Godunov became tsar. The peasants' situation worsened considerably under Godunov. They fled from the boyars and landlords to Ukraine and the Don. The country suffered three consecutive years of crop failure. A terrible famine ensued. The peasants ate chaff, cats, and dogs, even resorting to cannibalism. Various diseases broke out; corpses littered the roads; there was no one to bury them. In various places, peasants rose up and smashed their oppressors—the boyars and landlords. Popular unrest also began in the cities. This marked the first attempt by the Polish lords to enslave the Russian state. The Polish lords, longtime enemies of the Russian state, decided to take advantage of the opportune moment—the unrest in Russia—to enslave it. To this end, they spread a rumor that Ivan the Terrible's son, Dmitry, had not died in Uglich at all, but had fled from Boris Godunov to Poland. The Poles found a suitable person and, disguised as Tsarevich Dmitry, sent him with their troops to Moscow. This False Dmitry was to depose Boris Godunov and become Tsar in his stead. In Ukraine, Cossacks from the Don and Dnieper, dissatisfied with the boyars, joined False Dmitry. Tsar Boris Godunov died at this time, and the Tsar's troops offered no resistance to False Dmitry. False Dmitry reached Moscow unhindered and triumphantly entered it as the true Tsar. The mother of the deceased Tsarevich Dmitry was bribed by the boyars and publicly recognized the impostor as her son. False Dmitry became Tsar. The Poles rejoiced—their plan had succeeded: their protégé sat as Tsar in Moscow. False Dmitry married a Polish woman, Marina Mniszech, and gave her father much land. The Poles who came to Moscow with Marina occupied the best positions and began to rape and plunder the people. False Dmitry openly disregarded ancient Russian customs. Unrest broke out among the people against the Poles and the new tsar. The boyars, taking advantage of the unrest, plotted against False Dmitry and assassinated him. The impostor's body was burned at the stake, and the ashes were stuffed into a cannon and fired in the direction from which the impostor had come. A prominent landowner, the noble boyar Vasily Shuisky, became tsar. His election in Red Square in Moscow was orchestrated by the boyars and wealthy merchants during the popular uprising against the Poles. The peasant leader was Ivan Bolotnikov. Under Shuisky, peasant uprisings continued. At this time, they acquired an energetic leader, Ivan Bolotnikov. Bolotnikov had previously been a serf of a boyar and had fled from him. He had visited Turkey and Italy and seen much. Peasants, petty servicemen, and Cossacks flocked to Bolotnikov, a talented military leader. With his army, assembled in the south, Bolotnikov marched on Moscow in 1606 to overthrow the boyar tsar Vasily Shuisky and install another, "good" tsar.
Peasants flocked to Bolotnikov's army.
Along the way, in towns and villages, the rebels seized the tsar's officials, killed boyars and landowners, plundered their estates, and destroyed the homes of wealthy merchants. Bolotnikov's army was also joined by detachments of small landowners dissatisfied with the boyars' autocracy and the boyar Tsar Shuisky. Bolotnikov laid siege to Moscow. The landowners who had joined Bolotnikov soon realized that his victory would weaken the landowners' power. During the battle near Moscow, the landowner detachments deserted Bolotnikov and went over to the boyars and Tsar Shuisky. Bolotnikov's army was defeated. Preparing for a new offensive on Moscow, Bolotnikov retreated first to Kaluga and then to Tula. Shuisky, with a large army, besieged Bolotnikov in Tula. The rebel army bravely defended itself but was defeated. This is understandable. The peasants at that time had no ally or leader like the working class. And the peasants themselves were unconscientious. They fought not against tsarism and the landlord system, but against a bad tsar and bad landlords, for a "good" tsar and "good" landlords. In 1607, Ivan Bolotnikov was captured. The boyars gouged out his eyes and then drowned him in an ice hole. Things got even worse for the defeated peasantry: Shuisky issued new decrees increasing the bondage of the serfs. Now, for 15 whole years, a landowner could search for and recapture peasants who had fled from him. The uprisings continued.
20. The Struggle with the Polish Invaders.
The Polish invaders and their expulsion from Moscow. The Polish lords, after the failure of their first attempt to enslave Russia, made a second attempt. They put forward a new impostor. A rumor was spread that another man had been killed in Moscow by mistake, while False Dmitry had escaped. Ten thousand Polish troops accompanied the new False Dmitry. He and his army approached Moscow and set up camp in the village of Tushino near Moscow, demanding that Shuisky cede the throne to him. Shuisky called on the Swedes for aid. The Swedes, taking advantage of the weakness of the Moscow government, captured Novgorod. At the same time, the Polish King Sigismund approached Smolensk with his army, routed the Moscow troops, and laid siege to Smolensk. The enemy was tearing Russia apart. The Moscow nobles dethroned Shuisky and forced him to become a monk. At the same time, False Dmitry II was assassinated. Meanwhile, popular unrest continued. The Moscow boyars were unable to cope with the rebels. Then, instead of Shuisky, the Moscow boyars, trying to save their position, elected the Polish prince Vladislav, son of King Sigismund, as tsar. "Better to serve the prince than to be beaten by one's own serfs," said the boyars. In the autumn of 1610, the Polish army, with the help of the boyars, entered Moscow and occupied the Kremlin. The Polish lords seized much treasure from the treasury of the Moscow tsars. The invaders took estates for themselves, distributed lands to their supporters, and oppressed and plundered the Russian people. Six months later, in the spring of 1611, Muscovites rose up against their Polish oppressors. Barriers of tables, chests, and logs were erected on the streets of Moscow. From behind them, Muscovites fired upon the Poles. From the rooftops, they rained bullets and stones upon them. The Poles began to burn Moscow. Much of the city burned to the ground. The Poles fortified themselves behind the Kremlin walls. In the autumn of 1611, the Russian people rose up against the Polish invaders. The Nizhny Novgorod zemstvo elder, Kozma Minin, led the campaign against the Poles entrenched in Moscow. A large militia was equipped with funds he collected from the cities. Prince Pozharsky was chosen as the military commander. Some of the peasant units fighting the landowners joined the militia. And that was the deciding factor. The militia approached Moscow and besieged the Poles entrenched in the Kremlin. In 1612, the Kremlin was captured, and the Poles fled Moscow.
Minin urged the people to fight the Poles.
The Russian people produced many heroes in the fight against the Polish invaders. One such hero was the peasant Ivan Susanin. A Polish detachment forced him to serve as a guide. Susanin, sacrificing his life, led the detachment into the forest wilderness. Susanin was cut down by the Poles, but the Polish detachment could not escape the forest and perished. In 1613, representatives of landowners, merchants, and Cossacks convened in Moscow. They elected Mikhail, a Romanov boyar, as tsar. The Poles were forced to evacuate all the lands they had captured, but Smolensk remained in their hands. Only five years after the war did the Swedes return Novgorod to Russia, but the entire coast of the Gulf of Finland, with its Russian cities, remained Swedish. The peasant movement was crushed. The new tsar waged a brutal struggle against the still-raging popular movement. Many armed bands of fugitive peasants and Cossacks roamed around Moscow and throughout the country. The Tsar sent troops and military commanders to deal with the bands and participants in the uprisings. Prikazy (Tsarist chanceries) with their clerks and sub-clerks resumed their work in Moscow, and once again, as before, the people groaned at the military commanders and the military commanders. Tsar Mikhail generously distributed estates and large salaries to the landowners. Tsar Mikhail defended the interests of the landowners who elected him.
21. Uprisings of city dwellers and oppressed peoples in the 17th century
. Uprisings in the cities. After the death of Tsar Mikhail, his son Alexei became Tsar of Moscow. By his order, a heavy tax on salt was introduced in 1646. This tax increased popular unrest. Fearing an uprising, Tsar Alexei ordered the tax abolished. But this tax was not the only issue. Even after it was abolished, the people of Moscow nevertheless rose up against their oppressors. In 1648, the people of Moscow rose up in a "revolt," as popular uprisings were called at the time. The people remembered well the grievances of the tsar's servants and officials. The people demanded that the tsar hand over the chief of them for reprisal.
Zemsky Sobor of 1640.
The Tsar promised to fulfill the rebels' request. But the people began to be beaten with whips and trampled by horses. The crowd then sacked the houses of the particularly hated boyars and Tsarist servants, some of whom were killed. The Tsar's troops suppressed the uprising. In the same year, 1648, uprisings in other cities were also suppressed. Following these uprisings, the Tsar convened representatives of the boyars, landowners, and merchants in Moscow—the Zemsky Sobor. In 1649, they established the right for landowners to search for and return peasants who had fled from them throughout their lives. The peasants were completely enslaved. All villages and peasant households were registered. It became very difficult for peasants to hide. Craftsmen and small traders were also forbidden to move from one city to another without permission. In the cities, artisans lived in settlements named according to the occupations of their residents—tanners, potters, and gunsmiths. There were many such settlements in Moscow, the largest city in the state. In Moscow's settlements, small houses with two or three tiny windows stood in crooked, narrow alleys. Craftsmen earned little. Life was hard for them—they were robbed by governors and merchants.
Craftsmen sold their wares in the marketplace.
Uprisings by artisans and the urban poor continued. Such uprisings reached particularly large proportions in Pskov and Novgorod in 1650. Peasants also joined the uprising of the urban poor. Tsar Alexei was forced to send a large army to suppress this uprising. The urban poor continued to rise up in the following years. For example, a major uprising in Moscow occurred in 1662. During this uprising, the tsar's troops killed and drowned several thousand rebels in the Moskva River. The Bashkir Uprising. That same year, the people of Bashkiria, conquered by Tsar Ivan IV shortly after the capture of Kazan, rose up in the Urals. The Tatars joined the Bashkirs. The rebels seized a supply train with weapons and obtained gunpowder. They fought Muscovite troops for three years, besieging the tsar's fortresses, but were defeated.
22. Ukraine's struggle for liberation from the oppression of the Polish lords, for reunification with Russia
. War of the Ukrainian peasants with the Polish lords. Bohdan Khmelnytsky. From the 13th-14th centuries, Ukraine was under the yoke of the Polish-Lithuanian lords. They ultimately turned all peasants into serfs. For the slightest offense, the lords executed their serfs. Gallows were permanently erected near some Polish houses. The Poles forced the Ukrainian people to accept their faith. Peasants languished in lordly captivity both in Poland and in Belarus. The serfs fled from the lords to the Dnieper, where they built a small fortification beyond the rapids and called it the Zaporizhian Sich, and they called themselves Zaporizhian Cossacks. Another group of Cossacks lived in cities and towns. Cossacks were divided by wealth into rich and poor. The Cossacks united into regiments. Their chief commander was elected by the Cossacks and was called the hetman. Peasants and Cossacks often rebelled against the rule of the Polish lords. In 1648, the Ukrainian people rose up in a war of liberation against the lords' oppression. The outstanding statesman and Cossack commander Bohdan Khmelnytsky led the rebellious people. The peasants were the main force in this war. Men from Bohdan Khmelnytsky's army, disguised as beggars and monks, traveled through the villages of Ukraine, calling on the peasants to fight against the lords. The Ukrainian people were supported by Belarusian peasants, and sympathized with Polish peasants, who also suffered under the oppression of their landlords. The people of Russia provided constant aid and support to the Ukrainian people. The peasants plundered the lords' estates. Many victories were achieved over the lords' troops, but the war continued, bringing great devastation to the Ukrainian people. The Crimean Khan helped the lords devastate Ukraine. Ukrainians saw their salvation from foreign oppressors in unification with the great Russian people. The reunification of Ukraine with Russia. Expressing the Ukrainian people's desire for an alliance with the fraternal Russian people, Khmelnytsky appealed to the Russian government with a proposal to unify Ukraine with Russia. In January 1654, at a council (assembly) in the city of Pereyaslav, a decision was made to reunite the Ukrainian and Russian peoples in a single state. Russia could protect Ukraine not only from the Polish lords, but also from the Crimean Khan and Turkey. The Ukrainian peasantry was freed from the lords' bondage. No one imposed a foreign faith on the Ukrainians. Soon, Russia began a war with the Polish lords. After a long war, the lords were forced to renounce all Ukrainian lands on the left bank of the Dnieper and the city of Kiev on the right.
23. Razin's War with the Boyars and Landowners.
Cossacks on the Don. Runaway peasants in the south—on the Don and its tributaries—gathered large Don Cossack settlements, or stanitsas. In the mid-17th century, the Don Cossacks were unequal. Some Cossacks seized the best lands, established farms, traded, and became prosperous or home-loving. Others remained destitute, the rabble. The rabble were forced into indentured servitude to wealthy Cossacks or to survive by plunder. The tsar's military commanders captured the runaways and returned them to their landowners. The rabble harbored considerable hatred for the Muscovite landowners. The Cossack Stepan Timofeevich Razin led the rabble into rebellion. Razin and his struggle against the boyars and landowners. A foreigner who was in the Muscovite state at the time wrote of Razin: "His appearance was majestic, his bearing noble, his expression proud, his height tall, his face pockmarked. He possessed the ability to inspire fear and love." Stepan gathered a large rabble around him. He was elected ataman, that is, chief commander. Many Cossacks and others embittered against the tsar's military commanders and landowners joined Razin. In the spring of 1670, with 7,000 men, Razin attacked Tsaritsyn on the Volga (now Stalingrad) and captured it. Here, the tsar's army—the Streltsy—also defected to his side. Razin then marched on Astrakhan and took it after a two-day siege. The Cossacks slaughtered wealthy merchants, boyars, and the tsar's officials. Razin threw the Astrakhan military commander from a bell tower. In Astrakhan, the dvorianstvo appointed their own Cossack rulers. With military equipment captured in Astrakhan, Razin moved up the Volga. He captured cities and dealt with the tsar's military commanders and officials. Razin's messengers went to the peasants and recruited them to join the rebels. At Razin's call, peasants rebelled, killed their landlords, burned their estates, and marched in entire detachments to join Razin's army. The peoples of the Volga region—the Chuvash, Tatars, Mordvins, and Mari—joined the Russian peasants. Their different languages ​​didn't hinder them either. Hatred for the tsar and the landlords united them as one family. The peasant movement was crushed and Razin was executed. The tsar and the landlords assembled troops and regiments of hired foreign soldiers and marched them against Razin. Razin had a hard time defeating these well-armed forces. He gave them battle near Simbirsk. Razin was wounded, his army routed. Razin, with a small detachment, managed to escape to the Don. Wealthy Cossacks on the Don captured Razin and handed him over to the tsar. The tsar sentenced Razin to "a cruel death." In 1671, Stepan Razin was executed in Moscow.
The execution of Stepan Timofeevich Razin.
Tsar Alexei dealt cruelly with the rebellious peasants. Thousands of them were hacked to death, flogged, and hanged. The peasant insurrection was crushed. During Razin's rebellion, as during Bolotnikov's, the peasants lacked such a reliable ally as the organized working class. They also lacked an understanding of the objectives of the uprising: they knew how to burn and ruin landowners, but they did not understand what new order needed to be built or where to proceed. This was their weakness.
24. Subjugation of the Peoples of Eastern Siberia
. Conquest of Eastern Siberia. Cossack detachments penetrated Siberia by river, dragging boats from one river to another. Cossack Semyon Dezhnev, leading a small detachment, was the first to reach the strait between Asia and America by sea. The easternmost cape of Asia (Cape Dezhnev) is named after him. Following the Cossacks, Moscow's military commanders moved deeper into Siberia, settling in newly established towns and commanding Cossack detachments from there. Firearms, unknown to many of the Siberian peoples, helped the Cossacks defeat the locals. For a hundred years, the peoples of Eastern Siberia were subjugated to the rule of the Russian Tsar. By the end of the 17th century, almost all of Siberia was under this rule. The Khakass, Altai, Buryat-Mongols, Evenks, and Yakuts who lived there began to pay tribute—yasak—to the Russian Tsar. The peoples of Siberia were oppressed. Small wooden fortresses were built throughout Siberia. They housed military commanders and their troops. From these fortresses, the military commanders would travel to collect yasak from the local population. The military commanders forced the local population to plow the lands near the fortresses and fed their troops with the harvested grain. Russian peasants were also forcibly resettled in Siberia or lured with various benefits. Voivodes bribed local princes to facilitate their extortion of the indigenous population. Voivodes often sold local people into slavery in Central Asia. Voivodes sent Cossacks to conquer new peoples. The Cossack Khabarov and his retinue reached the Amur River in 1651. Along the way, he burned all villages that resisted him; the inhabitants fled into the forests. Russian merchants, priests, and monks accompanied the tsar's voivodes and troops. The merchants plied the Siberian peoples with vodka and confiscated the best furs from the drunks for next to nothing. Priests and monks seized land from the population, built churches and monasteries, and robbed the locals, forcing them to convert to Christianity and give them gifts.
A Yakut fortress built by Russians in Siberia in the 17th century.
The power of the tsarist government lay like a heavy yoke on the conquered peoples of Siberia. They repeatedly rebelled, killed their oppressors, and burned fortresses and cities. But the governors and merchants raised new military forces and dealt cruelly with the rebels.
25. Economy and State Administration in Russia at the Late 17th Century
. Landlord Economy. Having crushed the peasant uprisings, the landlords further increased their pressure on the serfs. They demanded that the peasants pay quitrent in cash.
