In addition, they increasingly took from the peasants grain, flour, butter, eggs, chickens, sheep, cloth, and linen. The landlords ate much of this wealth themselves, but they also sold much on the side. Hundreds of carts carried grain, flax, lard, and hides from the landlords' households to the city markets. Some goods were sold domestically, some were exported abroad. Landowners were keen to maximize their income from agriculture. Thus, they grew rich by robbing the peasants. Industry and Commerce. There were very few factories and plants in Russia at the end of the 17th century. They had only just appeared in Russia. Under Tsar Alexei, the cannon yard (zavod), where craftsmen cast cannons and church bells, was expanded. Ironworks and weapons factories operated in the cities of Kashira and Tula. The country had small mines and workshops, staffed by skilled craftsmen and serfs. Specialized craftsmen were brought in from abroad. At metallurgical plants, the hammer and bellows of small blast furnaces, where the ore was smelted, were powered by water. Water flowed through a trough and, like in a watermill, turned a wheel. Mechanisms were attached to the wheel that inflated the bellows and raised and lowered the hammer.
A plant with water-powered bellows.
All the factory buildings were wooden. Besides the cannon foundry, Moscow had only one stone factory—a manufactory where serf weavers handcrafted fabrics for the tsar's court. There were also potash factories in the Volga region and saltworks in the north and the Urals. Trade in Russia increased significantly with the reunification of Ukraine and the seizure of Siberia. Trade flowed throughout the country. Goods were transported long distances, by barges along rivers in summer and by sleigh in winter. Dozens of English and Dutch ships brought foreign goods from abroad and exported timber, furs, leather, potash, resin, grain, wax, honey, and caviar from Russia through Arkhangelsk. Every year, Russia exported goods worth more than 15 million gold rubles. The Dutch and English strove to control all Russian trade. To maintain its independence in trade, Russia needed its own fleet and more convenient seaports than Arkhangelsk, which froze for months. Such ports existed on the Black and Baltic Seas, but the Black Sea was then in the hands of the Crimean Tatars and Turks, while the shores of the Baltic Sea were under the control of the Swedes.
Foreign soldiers in Russia with rifles and muskets in hand.
State governance. In Russia, the Tsar, the autocratic ruler, ruled over all affairs. He lived in Moscow, in the Kremlin. The Tsar had advisors—boyars—whom he convened from time to time. The council of boyars under the Tsar was called the Boyar Duma. The Tsar decided all matters at his own discretion, but on important matters, he consulted with the boyars. The Tsar governed the state through his chanceries, which were called prikazes. The heads of the prikazes were boyars appointed by the Tsar. There were more than 50 prikazes. Clerks and sub-clerks sat in the prikazes. They wrote papers and accepted petitions. The state was divided into several large districts, governed by voivodes. In addition to the standing army—streltsy and military men—Tsar Alexei brought in mercenary troops of well-armed foreigners. But such troops were few in number. The Boyar Duma and the prikazy functioned very poorly. The entire state administration needed a radical overhaul.
26. Culture in Russia in the 17th Century
. Culture. The entire way of life in Russia at that time was backward, but the worst situation was with literacy. The population of this vast country was almost entirely illiterate. Even in the capital of the state, Moscow, there were very few schools and literate people. A few educated people emerged in Moscow from landowners who had traveled abroad. They lived like wealthy people in Western Europe, were fluent in foreign languages, and enjoyed reading scholarly books. Such people were few and far between. The boyars and tsarist officials looked askance at their connections with foreigners. Only the tsar and the boyars close to him were treated by foreign physicians. Russian physicians did not exist at that time. The people were treated by healers. They treated with prayers, whispers, water, fumigated the sick, and gave them various tinctures to drink, which often led to the death of the sick. There were no theaters back then. The first theater was built only for Tsar Alexei, where performances sometimes lasted the entire day. In the evening, the Tsar went to the bathhouse to wash away his "sin," since watching a performance was considered a sin. Priests taught people to obey the Tsar, the boyars, and the landowners. "All power comes from God," the priests said, "God endured and commanded us to do the same." Anyone who did not accept the church's teachings or read forbidden books was punished, sometimes even burned. Boyars and merchants wore large beards and long caftans. The women of the boyars, nobles, and wealthy merchants covered their faces with thick muslin. They were forbidden to meet or speak with other men. The common people disregarded these customs of their oppressors. Among the townspeople, artisans, and serfs, women enjoyed greater freedom. The Tsar and the landowners, with the help of the church, kept the people of Russia in darkness and ignorance. Russia was in need of serious reforms. Otherwise, it could have remained an uncultured and backward country and lost its independence. Peter I emerged as the reforming tsar who strengthened the Russian state of landowners and merchants.
7. Russia in the 18th Century: An Empire of Landowners and Merchants.
27. Peter I's Warriors and Popular Uprisings.
The War with the Turks and Peter I's Journey Abroad. At the very end of the 17th century, Alexei's son, Peter I, became Tsar of Russia. Upon his accession, the intelligent and active young Tsar soon began to establish new orders. He completely disregarded the Boyar Duma and became very friendly with the foreigners living in Moscow. He recruited them into his service and raised new troops in a foreign style, dismissing the Streltsy, as an old-fashioned force. In 1695, Peter began a war with Turkey to open a route to the Black Sea. He built a fleet of 29 ships on the Don River and, with an army trained by foreigners, attacked and captured the Turkish fortress of Azov. During this war, Peter became even more convinced of the need to restructure the country's entire life and adopt European military and naval techniques. Peter went abroad. In Western Europe at that time, the leading countries were Holland and England. In Holland, he worked with an axe in his hands in the shipyards. In England, he mastered shipbuilding. Peter I spent about two years abroad and learned much. A rebellion of the Streltsy (musketeers) began in Russia; they were dissatisfied with the new order established by Peter and demanded a return to the old. It was a reactionary uprising. Peter returned from abroad and personally oversaw the crackdown on the rebellious Streltsy, who were dragging Russia backward. The Streltsy regiments were disbanded.
Peter I (1672–1725). The War with the Swedes Begins. In 1700, Peter I began a war with the Swedes for control of the Baltic coast. The Swedes had the best army in the world and a good navy. Charles XII was King of Sweden at the time. Charles attacked Peter's troops besieging the Swedish fortress of Narva, routed them completely, and captured all their artillery and many prisoners. Peter, however, did not lose his nerve. He ordered the church bells removed and recast into cannons. 250 young men were sent to study literacy and the rudiments of mathematics to become artillerymen and craftsmen. A new army was recruited from among the serfs and trained in military affairs. Large sums of money were needed to maintain the army. Peter imposed taxes on bathhouses, mills, inns, even oak coffins, and doubled the price of salt. Peter introduced severe penalties for peasants fleeing their landowners. He ordered the destruction of all settlements of fugitive peasants in the upper Don region. Bashkirs were deprived of their cavalry horses. In 1703, Peter occupied the marshy mouth of the Neva River and built a fortress and the city of St. Petersburg (now Leningrad), which became the capital of the state under Peter. To build the fortress and city, Peter drove masses of serfs from all over Russia. Thousands died here from hunger and disease. The people responded to these torments with uprisings. Popular uprisings. Under Peter I, the Bashkirs, Tatars, and Udmurts rebelled. In 1707, a Cossack and peasant uprising broke out in the Don region. The rebels were led by the Cossack Kondraty Afanasyevich Bulavin. The rebels captured several cities. Peter sent an entire army against Bulavin. At this time, wealthy Cossacks plotted and attacked the farm where Bulavin lived. The ataman fought back until his last bullet. Unwilling to surrender to the enemy, Bulavin fired his last bullet into himself.
These were Bulavin's final moments.
The rebels fought Peter's troops for two years. Rebellious peasant villages on the Don were burned. Captured rebels were almost universally executed. Many thousands of fugitives were returned to their landowners. The reasons for Bulavin's defeat were the same as in previous peasant and Cossack uprisings. Having suppressed the popular uprisings, Peter concentrated all his forces on the fight against the Swedes.
28. Peter I's Wars with Sweden and the Eastern Countries
Defeat of the Swedes. The Swedish king, Charles XII, exploiting the treason of the Ukrainian hetman Mazepa, invaded Ukraine through Poland with his army. In 1709, the Swedes and Russians clashed near Poltava.
Soldiers of Peter I's regular army
. The Swedish troops were routed by the Russian regular army. Peter I himself distinguished himself in this battle. Charles XII and Mazepa fled to Turkey. Charles convinced the Turks to wage war on Russia. War with Turkey began again. Peter fielded a 40,000-strong army against the Turks. The Turks, however, assembled an army five times larger. Peter's troops were surrounded on the Prut River. He was forced to conclude an unfavorable peace with the Turks and return the fortress of Azov to them. After the defeat of the Turks, Peter decided to finish off the Swedes and finally secure the shores of the Baltic Sea for Russia. He took Riga and Reval from the Swedes and built a strong navy. The Swedish fleet was defeated in a naval battle. The war with the Swedes lasted for 21 years. Eventually, the Swedes signed a peace treaty, which ceded to Russia the lands along the shores of the Gulf of Riga and the Gulf of Finland. Peter I's struggle for the Caspian Sea coast. Peter I also decided to strengthen his position on the shores of the Caspian Sea, which served as a gateway to the East—to Central Asia, India, and Iran. He assembled an army of 80,000 men and led it from Astrakhan on a campaign against the Iranian lands. Peter had made advance arrangements with the Georgian princes, who were under Iranian rule, and with Armenian merchants, who were to assist him in the war against the Shah, the ruler of Iran. In addition to the land army, Peter also sent troops by ship. These troops landed in cities on the shores of the Caspian Sea and captured them. Peter captured the cities of Derbent and Baku. The Azerbaijani cities captured by Peter were then inhabited by peoples who had been conquered by the Iranian kings 200-300 years before Peter the Great's campaigns. The Azerbaijanis had continually fought the Iranian conquerors for their independence and against their oppression. Therefore, the native inhabitants of Azerbaijan did not offer serious resistance to Peter's troops.
29. Reforms of Peter the Great
Reforms in government. Peter the Great achieved his goal. The shores of the Baltic Sea were in Russian hands. Russia had come closer to Europe. Peter waged a relentless struggle against Russia's backwardness and reshaped its order along European lines. In place of the Boyar Duma, Peter established a senate composed of individuals appointed by himself. Instead of 50 departments, Peter created 12 collegia, which oversaw the army and navy, foreign affairs, the economy, and the courts. Nobility managed all affairs in the senate and collegia. Peter divided Russia into eight provinces. He appointed a governor at the head of each province, who governed the region and was responsible for recruiting soldiers and collecting money. To strengthen the power and authority of the nobility, Peter granted them full ownership of their estates. In 1721, after defeating the Swedes, Peter assumed the title of emperor. From that time on, Russia became known as the Russian Empire. Economic reforms. To increase state revenue, Peter introduced a poll tax, forcing all male peasants, young and old, to pay it. Under Peter, cloth and other manufactories were established. Serf workers worked on handlooms. Merchants were given money to establish new factories.
The interior of a silk factory under Peter the Great.
At this time, many free hired laborers were already working in England's factories. To provide merchants with workers, Peter assigned entire villages of peasants to factories. Under Peter, there were already more than 200 factories. Arms factories in Tula expanded significantly. New ironworks sprang up in the Urals. Merchants and factory owners quickly grew rich. Peter gave merchants their own management in the cities. Education. Peter placed great emphasis on education, even trying to instill it by force. Peter sent young noblemen abroad to study shipbuilding and foreign languages. Schools were opened where they taught maritime affairs, engineering, medicine, and other sciences. The teachers in the schools were English, Dutch, Swedes, Germans, and other foreigners whom Peter invited to serve in Russia. Peter ordered the opening of numerology schools in all provinces, where the children of the nobility were required to learn literacy—reading and writing, arithmetic, and geometry. Peter even forbade illiterate noblemen from marrying. Peter established the first Russian newspaper, Vedomosti, based on the European model and simplified the Russian alphabet for it. Before Peter, the New Year was counted from September 1st. Peter ordered the year to be counted, as was done abroad, from January 1st. The new calendar was introduced on January 1st, 1700, according to the new chronology, which is still used today. Peter ordered the nobility to cut their beards, wear wigs, and wear short waistcoats and caftans, similar to those worn in Western Europe. Only priests and peasants were allowed to wear long dresses and beards. Peter ordered that evenings with European dances and games, so-called assemblies, be held in the homes of his close associates. Under Peter I, Russia made significant progress, but remained a country where everything rested on serfdom and tsarist tyranny. The strengthening of the Russian Empire under Peter I was achieved at the expense of the deaths of hundreds of thousands of workers and the impoverishment of the people. Peter I did much to create and strengthen the state of landowners and merchants.
30. The Noble Empire in the 18th Century
. The Dominance of the Nobility. Peter I died in 1725. After Peter I's death, court noble circles, supported by noble guard regiments, plotted and dethroned emperors they disliked. Empresses Anna Ivanovna and Elizabeth Petrovna reigned the longest. Their reigns included several wars with Turkey, Sweden, and other states. From the newly captured lands, the nobles received new estates with peasants. Russian troops achieved particular fame during the Seven Years' War, when the German forces were routed and the city of Berlin was captured in 1760. In St. Petersburg, the nobles built magnificent palaces for themselves, hosting lavish celebrations and balls. The imperial court and Russian nobility now imitated the French kings and their courtiers in everything. The nobles learned to speak French, and the men dressed in French velvet waistcoats. Silk stockings hugged their legs. High-heeled shoes were adorned with precious buckles, and curled, powdered wigs were worn. The women wore expensive dresses of the finest silk and lace. Their hair was adorned with elaborate French hairstyles. The adorned nobles, with their powdered wigs, were neither able nor willing to work. But to work in factories and build palaces, the nobility needed scientists and specialists. They were invited from abroad, which was very expensive.
Empress Elizabeth Petrovna, surrounded by her retinue, goes for a walk.
Peter also conceived the idea of ​​founding the Academy of Sciences, which opened the year of his death. All the academicians were foreigners. Students were trained at the academy. But the nobility did not want to study, and peasants were not allowed into the academy. M.V. Lomonosov. A great Russian scientist was a peasant from the village of Denisovka (near Arkhangelsk) – Mikhail Vasilyevich Lomonosov. From the far north, he reached Moscow and enrolled in school, posing as the son of a nobleman; otherwise, he would not have been accepted. Living hand to mouth, Lomonosov, through persistent work, completed an eight-year course of study at the age of five. The talented young man was sent abroad at government expense to continue his education. Upon his return to Russia, Lomonosov was appointed a member of the Academy of Sciences.
The great Russian scientist, Academician M. V. Lomonosov (1711–1765).
Lomonosov was an outstanding scientist in physics, chemistry, and other sciences. He made many major scientific discoveries. Lomonosov laid the foundations of Russian science and was the first to write literary works in pure Russian, purging it of many obsolete Slavic words. At Lomonosov's suggestion, the first university was founded in Moscow in 1755. A monument to M. V. Lomonosov now stands in the university courtyard. Lomonosov died in 1765, during the reign of Catherine II. Empress Catherine II. In 1762, the nobility placed Catherine II on the Russian throne, having assassinated her husband, Peter III, with her assistance. Under Catherine II, the rights of the nobility were further expanded. Catherine II distributed over a million peasants among the nobility. In order to finance their luxurious lifestyle, the nobility began to oppress the peasants even more. Corvee labor reached the point where peasants were forced to work for the landowner almost constantly. The landowner's serfs did everything—they were farmers, blacksmiths, cooks, footmen, hunters, even artists. The peasants were left only with holidays and nights to work for themselves. Under Catherine II, the quitrent increased almost fivefold. The nobles traded peasants. A woman cost 20–30 rubles, a literate man or artisan 100–200 rubles. A small child could be bought for 10–20 kopecks. Dogs were more valuable to the landowners. The landowners abused the peasants in every possible way. The landowner Saltychikha beat her serfs to death, scalded them with boiling water, and scorched their hair. She killed more than a hundred people. This terrible situation led the peasants to revolt.
31. The Peasant War under the Leadership of Pugachev.
The beginning and course of the peasant war. The Cossacks on the Yaik River (now the Ural River) were the first to rebel. The tsarist government deprived the Ural Cossacks of their liberties and imposed onerous taxes on them, seeking to turn them into serfs like the peasants of central Russia. Cossack elders exacted excessive taxes from rank-and-file Cossacks and pocketed their wages. In 1773, the Cossack poor rose up against their oppressors. The uprising was led by the Don Cossack Yemelyan Ivanovich Pugachev, a strong, intelligent, and courageous man.
Yemelyan Ivanovich Pugachev.
The Cossacks captured several fortresses and besieged Orenburg. Pugachev was joined by serf workers from the Ural factories. The peasants attached to the factories cursed the backbreaking labor they endured. Even at the beginning of Catherine II's reign, only about 50,000 of the 200,000 factory peasants participated in the uprising. Workers eagerly joined Pugachev's army. They supplied his troops with weapons, cannons, and cannonballs. The leaders of Pugachev's detachments, Khlopusha and Beloborodov, emerged from factory workers. At the same time, the Bashkirs joined the uprising. The nobles took land from the Bashkirs and established ironworks there. The plundered Bashkirs repeatedly rebelled, but the uprisings were suppressed. Now the Bashkirs rose up again and joined Pugachev's army with their cavalry. One of their leaders was Salavat Yulaev, a brave young rebel who greatly assisted Pugachev with his army. At the same time, serfs rebelled in the Volga region: Russians, Tatars, Chuvash, Mordvins, and Mari. Pugachev pretended to be Emperor Peter III. He claimed that the nobles and his wife, the villainous Catherine II, had failed to assassinate him and that he had escaped. In the name of Peter III, Pugachev signed orders and sent manifestos across the country calling for the extermination of the nobles, declaring that he was liberating the peasants from the rule of the landowners, military conscription, and taxes.
Pugachev judges the landowners. From a painting by V.G. Perov.
The entire Volga region and the Urals, as well as part of Siberia, were engulfed in rebellion. The landowners' estates were plundered. Peasants seized the landowners' lands, and the masters' grain reserves were taken to Pugachev's army. Pugachev and his troops approached Kazan and laid siege to the fortress. Catherine II's troops soon began to push back Pugachev's army. Pugachev was forced to retreat south down the Volga. The Volga cities in his path surrendered to Pugachev without a fight. But he couldn't gain a foothold there. The peasant rebellion was suppressed. In August 1774, Pugachev reached Tsaritsyn. A few days later, he was defeated in a battle with a detachment of tsarist troops and fled with the remnants of his army into the steppe. There, traitors from among the wealthy Cossacks handed him over to the tsarist authorities. Pugachev was chained and taken to Moscow in a large wooden cage. On January 10, 1775, executioners executed the brave leader of the peasant rebellion, Yemelyan Ivanovich Pugachev, on Bolotnaya Square. Salavat Yulaev's nostrils were torn out, and the words "thief and murderer" were burned into his forehead with a hot iron. After this, he was brought to Bashkiria and flogged in every village where he led the rebellion. After brutal torture, Salavat Yulaev was exiled to hard labor. The peasants fought bravely and steadfastly, but, overwhelmed by the darkness, they had no clear idea of ​​what they were trying to achieve. Disunited, they were unable to create a strong organization or a sturdy army to fight. This is why the peasants and oppressed peoples were defeated.
32. The annexation of new lands to Russia in the late 18th century.
The annexation of Crimea. Suvorov. During the reign of Catherine II, Azov was recaptured from the Turks. Crimea, previously ruled by Tatar khans subservient to Turkey, was annexed to Russia. The naval fortress of Sevastopol, a stronghold of the Russian fleet on the Black Sea, was built in southern Crimea. The great Russian commander Alexander Vasilyevich Suvorov gained fame in the war with the Turks. He began his military service as a simple soldier. Suvorov led a harsh lifestyle: he ate soldier's food and hardened himself. With 25,000 troops, Suvorov defeated a 100,000-strong Turkish army. Simultaneously with the annexation of Crimea, all of Left-Bank Ukraine was finally ceded to Russia. The Hetmanate in Ukraine was abolished. Russian troops entered the Zaporizhian Sich, and the Sich was destroyed forever. Its lands were seized by the tsar's generals. Some of the Zaporozhian Cossacks were transferred to Kuban (North Caucasus), some went to Turkey, and poor Cossacks and peasants were forced to work as serfs. Catherine II gave Ukrainian elders equal rights with Russian nobles.
Alexander Vasilyevich Suvorov (1730–1800).
Partition of Poland. Poland was greatly weakened in the 18th century. Poland was ruled by the largest landowners, the lords, who were constantly at odds with each other. Royal power was weak. Taking advantage of the weakness of the Polish lords, Austria, Prussia, and Empress Catherine II agreed to divide the lands of the Polish state. During the partition of Poland, Belarusian and Ukrainian lands on the right bank of the Dnieper River ceded to Russia. Austria seized most of the land. In 1794, a Polish uprising for the restoration of Poland took place in Poland under the leadership of Kosciuszko. Austria, Prussia, and Russia sent their troops against him. Kosciuszko was defeated. In battle, he was seriously wounded and captured. Lithuania ceded Poland to Russia. From that time on, Poland ceased to exist as an independent state for many years. Conquests in Kazakhstan and the Far North. In the 18th century, the Kazakh pastoralists had three states—zhuzes. Khans and sultans ruled the zhuzes. Kazakh nobility and merchants traded with Russia and neighboring Central Asian states—Kokand and Bukhara—as well as with China. All these states sought to subjugate the Kazakhs, exploiting their internecine strife. The Kazakhs were first conquered by the Mongols. Mongol tribes enslaved and attacked the Kazakhs for approximately 200 years, until Kazakhstan's annexation by Russia. The Kazakhs repeatedly petitioned the Russian tsars to accept them as Russian subjects. In 1731, the Little Zhuz joined Russia at the request of Khan Abulkhayir. The Russian tsars, taking advantage of this, began to conquer all of Central Asia. Catherine II built fortresses in the conquered regions and stationed garrisons of Russian soldiers there. Tsarist agents pursued a policy of plundering Kazakh lands. The Kazakh people repeatedly rose up against the policies of tsarism. In 1783, the brave Sarym Datov rose to the head of the Kazakh rebellion. For fourteen years, the Kazakh people fought against their enemies under the leadership of their fearless leader, Sarym, who became a national hero. Sarym was killed, and the uprising was suppressed. Catherine's troops penetrated deep into the Kazakh steppes and built fortresses there. In the first half of the 19th century, all of Kazakhstan was annexed. By the end of the 18th century, the last lands of the northern peoples of Siberia were subjugated by Russian authorities. Tsarist troops penetrated the Bering Strait to North America and established Russian rule over Alaska. In the 19th century, the Russian tsars sold Alaska to the American government for a pittance, unaware of its abundance of gold. At the end of Catherine II's reign, the final conquest of Azerbaijan began.
VIII. Tsarist Russia in the late 18th and first half of the 19th centuries
33. The bourgeois revolution in France and the struggle against it of Catherine II and Paul I.
The overthrow of royal power in France. At the end of the 18th century, major events occurred in Western Europe that affected the lives of all countries, including Russia. Revolution broke out in France. On July 14, 1789, a rebellious crowd in Paris stormed the royal prison, the Bastille. The prisoners were released. A revolutionary flag was raised on the Bastille. The revolution quickly spread throughout the country. Craftsmen, small tradesmen, and the then-sparse workforce rose up in every city. Peasants everywhere attacked noble estates, seized land, and demanded the complete abolition of serfdom. Many nobles fled abroad. Relying on the revolutionary people, the bourgeoisie seized power. The bourgeois revolution was victorious in France. King Louis XVI attempted to flee France. Catherine II ordered her ambassador in Paris to issue the king a Russian passport to enter Russia. However, the king was captured en route and returned to Paris.
The rebellious people of Paris storm the royal prison, the Bastille.
The feudal states of Austria and Prussia, supported by French nobles fleeing the revolution, began a war against bourgeois-revolutionary France. The king knew of the counterrevolutionary plans of the interventionists and secretly aided them. The revolutionary government of France organized the country's defense. A republic was declared in France, and Louis XVI was executed as a traitor. After the king's execution, the Jacobin revolutionaries, representing the interests of peasants and artisans, came to power in France. Their leaders were Robespierre and Marat, nicknamed the "friend of the people." Under the Jacobins, the peasants were finally freed from serfdom.
Marat (1744–1803).
The land was confiscated from the landowners by the revolutionary government and sold to anyone who wanted it. Much of the land was purchased by the peasants, but some of it fell into the hands of the bourgeoisie. The Jacobins were not consistent revolutionaries. They stood for private ownership of land, factories, and plants. They prohibited workers from striking and fighting the capitalists. The revolutionary people rose up to defend their country. The Republican army routed the interventionist forces and drove them out of France. Now, France's troops fought beyond its borders, liberating other nations from the rule of feudal kings and nobles. Fearing the growing power of bourgeois-democratic France, the powerful industrial country of England went to war with it. Domestic and foreign counterrevolutionaries fought the revolution with all means necessary. They sent assassins to the leaders of the revolution and killed Marat. The Jacobins then declared a merciless reign of terror against the enemies of the people. But soon, the French upper class managed to seize power again. The Jacobin leaders were executed. General Napoleon Bonaparte became the leader of bourgeois France. The bourgeois revolution liberated the French people from the rule of the king and the landowners, but established the rule of the bourgeoisie. The bourgeoisie won because the working class in France was weak and disorganized, and the peasants, freed from the rule of the landowners with the help of the bourgeoisie, supported the bourgeoisie. The French Revolution destroyed the oppression of the landowners and strengthened that of the bourgeoisie—the capitalists. The struggle of Catherine II and Paul I against the bourgeois revolution. Catherine II feared that revolution would break out in her empire as well. There were already people in Russia who sympathized with the revolution. One of the most enlightened and progressive figures of the time, the nobleman Radishchev, wrote a book entitled "Journey from St. Petersburg to Moscow," in which he openly opposed serfdom and autocracy and sympathized with the peasant uprisings against the landowners. Catherine II exiled Radishchev to Siberia and ordered his book burned. Catherine II considered the fight against the bourgeois revolution in France her primary task. She eagerly welcomed nobles fleeing France to Russia and ordered all Russians in Paris to leave. Catherine II aided all states at war with France. She gave Austria money and, having ceded part of Poland to Prussia, promised to send Russian troops to their aid and prepared her army for the campaign. Only her sudden death in 1796 prevented her from starting a war with bourgeois France.
A. N. Radishchev (1719–1802).
After the death of Catherine II, her son, Paul I, became tsar and continued the fight against the bourgeois revolution. He closed all private printing houses in Russia, forbade the reading of French books and the discussion of the revolution in France. Paul I began to wage war against France and sent Suvorov against it. Suvorov won several victories in northern Italy and made a heroic march across the Alps. However, his allies—Austria and Prussia—failed to aid Suvorov. The Russian army was left without provisions. Paul I recalled Suvorov's troops and concluded peace with France. By this time, Napoleon Bonaparte had staged a coup d'état in France against the revolution and became the sole ruler. Paul I, seeing that Napoleon was fighting the revolution, entered into an alliance with him. Negotiations with Napoleon led to Russia's break with England. From an ally of England, Paul became its enemy. Nobles, dissatisfied with Paul I's alliance with France, with the help of the English ambassador in St. Petersburg, plotted and assassinated Paul.
34. Tsar Alexander I. The Patriotic War of 1812.
Annexation of Georgia. His son, Alexander I, who ascended the throne after Paul's assassination, took part in the conspiracy against his father. Alexander I continued the conquest of the Black Sea shores and the rich lands of the Caucasus, begun by Peter I and Catherine II. He first consolidated his position in Georgia. In Georgia, as in Russia at the time, landowners reigned supreme. Peasants worked for them from dawn to dusk, never bending their backs. They lived in stone huts and dugouts. Most of the harvest from their fields and gardens was taken from them by their lords, the landowners. The rulers of Georgia's neighboring states (Turkey and Iran) carried out devastating raids on the rich Georgian lands, further impoverishing the peasants. After one attack, in which the Iranians took more than 10,000 Georgians captive, the king of Georgia appealed to Paul I for help. Tsarist troops were brought into the Georgian capital, Tbilisi; in 1801, Georgia finally joined Russia. The devastating raids of the Iranian kings on Georgia ceased. Georgia became a possession of Tsarist Russia. Russian officials were placed in courts and other institutions. They demanded that petitioners in all Georgian institutions speak only Russian, a language unknown to the Georgian people. Serfdom continued to exist in Georgia. Cruelly oppressed Georgian peasants repeatedly rebelled against their landlords and tsarist officials, but with the help of Georgian princes and nobles, the tsarist troops mercilessly suppressed them. Relying on the serf-owning Georgian nobles, Alexander I firmly established himself in Transcaucasia. He conquered Finland and Bessarabia. In 1805, Alexander I, having restored a military alliance with England, began a war with Napoleon I, who had declared himself Emperor of France. Napoleon defeated Alexander I's troops and demanded that Russia cease trade with England, France's main adversary. The defeated Alexander I was forced to agree. Napoleon promised in exchange not to interfere with the Russian Emperor's wars with Sweden and Turkey. Napoleon himself brought almost all the nations of Western Europe under French rule. Alexander I soon declared war on Sweden and quickly occupied Swedish-held Finland with his troops. The Russian army crossed the frozen Gulf of Bothnia in winter and threatened the Swedish capital. The Swedish king was obliged to make peace in 1809 and agreed to the cession of Finland to Russia. Three years later, Alexander I succeeded in recapturing Bessarabia—the region between the Dniester and Prut rivers—from Turkey. The Patriotic War of 1812. But Russia's alliance with France did not last long. The landowners and merchants were keen to secure free trade with England and demanded that the Tsar break with Napoleon. The nobles also feared that, under the influence of bourgeois France, where serfdom had been abolished, their hold on Russia would be weakened. Alexander I relented. Trade with England resumed. Then Napoleon, with a massive army of over 500,000 men, attacked Russia in the summer of 1812. The Russian forces numbered only about 200,000. They retreated, destroying all food and equipment along the way. Napoleon soon captured Lithuania and Belarus and advanced on Moscow. Napoleon's invasion of Russia roused the Russian people to wage a Patriotic War against the invaders; peasants began a guerrilla war. Ukrainians, Belarusians, Tatars, Bashkirs, and other peoples of our country participated in the fight against Napoleon. Suvorov's favorite student, the great military leader Field Marshal Mikhail Kutuzov, was placed at the head of the Russian army. At the end of August, the largest battle took place near Moscow, near the village of Borodino. Russian troops fought tenaciously against the enemy, who were devastating their country. More than 50 thousand Russians died in this bloody battle, but the strength of the Russian army was not broken. The French suffered enormous losses, but the odds were still in their favor. Kutuzov decided to surrender Moscow to Napoleon without a fight and retreat to preserve his army. The French occupied Moscow. Large fires broke out in the city. Many houses burned down. The French in Moscow were left without food.
Mikhail Illarionovich Kutuzov (1745–1813).
Winter was approaching. It was impossible for the French to hold on to Moscow. Napoleon and his army began to retreat along the road destroyed during the march on Moscow. His attempt to retreat by another route failed—other roads were occupied by Russian troops. Kutuzov relentlessly pursued Napoleon's retreating troops. Partisans attacked and destroyed individual French detachments. While crossing the Berezina River, Napoleon narrowly escaped the complete defeat of the remnants of his army and personal capture. Of Napoleon's vast army, only 30,000 men survived and returned from Russia abroad.
1812. Retreat of the French army. From a painting by Pryanishnikov.
Napoleon raised a new army and continued the war. But now, in alliance with Russia, Prussia, Austria, England, and Sweden opposed him. They defeated Napoleon near Leipzig. The allies crossed the French border and occupied Paris. Napoleon's victors restored the power of the old French kings and princes in France. The French were ruled by the brother of the king executed during the Revolution. Napoleon was exiled to a remote island in the Atlantic Ocean. In all the other European states previously conquered by Napoleon, the kings and princes he had driven out again came to rule. For his fight against Napoleon, the allies gave Alexander I part of Poland, including the city of Warsaw. To combat the revolution in Europe, the Russian Tsar, the King of Prussia, and the Emperor of Austria formed a reactionary Holy Alliance. They vowed to support each other in the fight against popular uprisings. The head of this alliance was the Russian Tsar Alexander I. Tsarist Russia became the gendarme of Europe.
35. The Decembrists:
Secret societies of noble revolutionaries. Alexander I kept a huge army under arms. Troops stationed closer to the European border were transferred to special military settlements, where they served in the army and, by cultivating the land, supported themselves. The commander of these settlements was the cruel and rude General Arakcheyev. The already difficult life of the soldiers, who had served in the army for 25 years, became worse than penal servitude. They spent their entire days either working in the fields or participating in military exercises. They were even married at the officers' discretion. For the slightest offense, soldiers and peasants were mercilessly beaten with sticks, often to death. The Tsar's arbitrary rule and the feudal system greatly outraged progressive members of the nobility. Many of them served as officers. During their foreign campaigns in France, they saw that the peasants lived better without serfdom, that hired labor on estates and in factories was more profitable than serfdom. They saw that in the cities of Western Europe, people lived wealthier and more cultured lives than in Russia. These nobles dreamed of a similar life in their homeland. They organized secret revolutionary societies: the "Northern Society" and the "Southern Society." Members of the "Northern Society" wanted to abolish serfdom—that is, the power of the nobility over the peasants—but decided to leave almost all the land to the landowners. They believed it was necessary to preserve the Tsar and only recognized the need to limit his power. The main leaders of this society were the poet and friend of Pushkin, Ryleyev, and the officers Trubetskoy and Kakhovsky. In Ukraine, among the tsarist troops, a "Southern Society" arose, led by the educated and courageous Colonel Pestel. He believed that the peasants should be given not only freedom but also land. Pestel wanted Russia to be a republic. He proposed assassinating the tsar and his family. But the members of these secret societies were nobles and were afraid to call the people to revolt. They remembered the peasant revolt against the nobility under Catherine II. They wanted to carry out a revolution only with the help of the troops they commanded. The Decembrist Rebellion. In 1825, Alexander I died. He had no children. His brother, Nicholas, was to reign. On the morning of December 14, 1825, officers—members of the "Northern Society" in St. Petersburg—led their regiments onto the square in front of the Senate and refused to swear allegiance to Tsar Nicholas I. Guards sailors joined them. The rebels awaited orders from their leader, Prince Trubetskoy. But he chickened out and didn't show up at the square, leaving the uprising leaderless. Nicholas summoned troops loyal to him and surrounded the rebel regiments with them. Serfs, artisans, and construction workers gathered around the rebels. They threw logs and stones at the soldiers who remained on Nicholas's side. But even here, the noble revolutionaries were afraid to accept their help.
December 14, 1825, in St. Petersburg. Nicholas I ordered the cannons to fire at the rebels.
Nicholas sent the governor to negotiate with the rebels. Officer Kakhovsky killed the governor. Nicholas I lacked confidence in his troops and hesitated for a long time to act by force. Only in the evening, when artillery arrived, did he order the cannons to fire at the rebels. Shots rang out. The rebels and the people fled. Hundreds of dead and wounded remained in the square. Two weeks later, near Kiev, officers from the Southern Society instigated a rebellion in the Chernigov Regiment in Ukraine. They led their regiment to join forces with other troops in the organization. Troops sent by Nicholas I to suppress the uprising routed the regiment. Having suppressed the rebellion, Nicholas I arrested its participants and dealt with them brutally. Five key leaders (Pestel, Ryleyev, Kakhovsky, Muravyov-Apostol, and Bestuzhev-Ryumin) were hanged. More than 100 conspiratorial officers were exiled to Siberia. Hundreds of soldiers were forced to run the gauntlet (each receiving several hundred blows with sticks), and many were exiled to hard labor and to active duty in the Caucasus. The noble revolutionaries who rebelled in December 1825 became known as Decembrists. They were few in number, and they had no connection with the people. But the Decembrists were the first to take up arms in an organized and open manner against the autocracy in the tsarist capital itself. Their cause did not perish. It was continued by subsequent generations of revolutionaries.
P. I. Pestel, K. F. Ryleyev, M. P. Bestuzhev-Ryumin, S. I. Muravyov-Apostol, P. G. Kakhovsky—the five Decembrists executed by Nicholas I.
Nicholas I, having become tsar, considered the fight against the revolution his primary task and in every possible way protected the old, feudal order.
36. In the kingdom of gendarmes and officials,
Nicholas I. About Tsar Nicholas I, when he was a boy, his teacher said: "I never saw a book in his hands: his only occupation was the front and the soldiers." Such a man became the Emperor of Russia. Nicholas I was greatly frightened by the uprising of December 14, 1825. To combat the revolution, he created a special police force—the gendarmes. The chief of the gendarmes reported only to the Tsar himself. The entire population was kept under strict surveillance. Gendarmes and secret police agents prowled the entire kingdom. They eavesdropped on all public gossip and private conversations. People were arrested at the slightest suspicion or on unverified denunciations. Nicholas I ruled Russia through noble officials, many of whom were bribe-takers and embezzlers. Officials in institutions and courts extorted bribes from the population, mocked, and abused people. Nicholas I established a brutal discipline in Russia. Under his rule, soldiers, peasants, and those arrested were beaten, as were anyone who opposed the landowners and princes. They were beaten with rods, lashes, whips, and sticks. Peasants were forced to work even harder for the landowners. All their land was confiscated, and corvee and quitrent were increased. The peasants couldn't stand such a life of hard labor and rebelled against the tyranny of the serf owners. They killed the most cruel landowners, set fire to and destroyed their estates, and refused to work corvée labor or pay quitrent. The peasant unrest continued. Tsarist troops and police mercilessly suppressed discontented peasants and dealt harshly with them. Life in Tsarist Russia was unbearably hard. Great Russian writers. The great Ukrainian poet Shevchenko. The brilliant Russian poet Alexander Sergeyevich Pushkin lived under Nicholas I. He wrote wonderful works ("Eugene Onegin," "Boris Godunov," "The Captain's Daughter," and many others), which we are proud of to this day. Pushkin created Russian literature. Pushkin was born in 1799 in Moscow, into a noble family. As a boy, he began writing poetry. After graduating from the noble school – the lyceum in Tsarskoye Selo (now the town of Pushkin near Leningrad), he became a famous writer and became close to the Decembrists. In his poems, he sharply condemned serfdom and autocracy. Such poems were forbidden to be published; they were copied by hand, read secretly, and distributed everywhere.
Alexander Sergeevich Pushkin (1799–1837).
Tsar Alexander I learned of these poems, and Pushkin was exiled first to the south, then to his village for two years. For the rest of his life, Pushkin was under constant surveillance by gendarmes. Life was especially difficult for him under Nicholas I, who knew of Pushkin's close relationship with the Decembrists. Pushkin's works were published only when Nicholas I himself permitted it. The Tsar hated Pushkin. The court nobility hounded and insulted the great poet. Nicholas I was well aware of this persecution, but took no action, even when it came to a duel. Pushkin fought a duel with one of his assailants and was killed by him in early 1837. Free thought had no place in the reign of the gendarmes. Nicholas I exiled another famous poet, Mikhail Yuryevich Lermontov, to the Caucasus, serving with the army. The Tsar sent him to face the bullets of the highlanders for denouncing Pushkin's murderers—court parasites—in a poem. In the Caucasus, Lermontov was killed in a duel by a negligent officer. Upon learning of this, Nicholas I said, "A dog's death for a dog." The third greatest writer of the period, Nikolai Vasilyevich Gogol, described the dominance and tyranny of Nicholas I's officials. His remarkable works, Dead Souls and The Government Inspector, vividly and truthfully depict the hard life of feudal Russia. Under Nicholas I, the famous Russian literary critic and revolutionary Vissarion Grigorievich Belinsky
(1811–1848), hounded by gendarmes and suffering from tuberculosis, died.
Life in Nicholas I's Russia was also difficult for the greatest Russian composer, M. I. Glinka. Mikhail Ivanovich Glinka composed the first national Russian opera, Ruslan and Lyudmila. In it, he conveyed the music of folk songs not only of the Russian people, but also of other peoples of Russia. The nobility did not understand the beauty of this remarkable work, and Glinka's opera soon ceased to be performed in theaters. Outraged, Glinka left Russia. He died abroad. Nicholas I also dealt cruelly with the Ukrainian revolutionary poet and artist Taras Grigorievich Shevchenko. Shevchenko was initially a serf and bought his freedom.
Taras Grigorievich Shevchenko (1814–1861).
In his poems, he wrote about the oppression of the Ukrainian and other peoples in Tsarist Russia, the hard lives of serfs, the arbitrary rule of tsars and lords, and the lack of rights of the people. Nicholas I conscripted Shevchenko into military service and exiled him to Kazakhstan, forbidding him even to write or draw. Shevchenko was tortured in the soldiers' barracks for ten years, but his spirit was not broken. He continued to secretly write poetry. It was only under Soviet rule that his poetry collection, "Kobzar," was published in full in Ukraine.
37. Annexation of the Caucasus
. Annexation of Azerbaijan and Armenia. In the early 19th century, Georgia joined Russia. Soon after, the annexation of Azerbaijan and Armenia, which had suffered for hundreds of years under the yoke of Iranian rulers, was completed. The Shah of Iran repeatedly attempted to recapture these lands. However, Russian troops defeated the Iranian forces each time. In addition to Iran, Turkey also frequently attacked Georgia and Armenia. Turkish troops destroyed cities and villages, stole livestock, devastated fields, slaughtered the population of entire cities, and took thousands of inhabitants into slavery. After Georgia, Azerbaijan, and Armenia joined Russia, Turkey's plundering attacks began to be decisively rebuffed. Turkey could no longer plunder Georgians, Armenians, and Azerbaijanis with impunity. The Turkish sultan then conceived of raising the small, backward mountain tribes to war against Russia. The mountain tribes lived in the high, inaccessible Caucasus Mountains. These mountains hampered Russia's relations with Georgia, Armenia, and Azerbaijan. Very few roads passed through the mountains. If the mountain tribes waged war against Russia, it would be easier for Turkey to attack Transcaucasia again. The highlander movement led by Shamil. The fragmented highlander tribes were ruled by various princes and landowners. One of the wealthy highlanders, Shamil, declared himself the ruler of all the tribes. He began to incite Muslims against the Russians and recruit backward highlanders into his forces. Shamil relied on landowners and princes who hated Russia. The Turkish Sultan bribed Shamil, giving him money, weapons, and promising troop support. England also aided Shamil. It sought to weaken Russia and seize the Caucasus. England was already a cruel oppressor of many millions of people in Asia, Africa, and other countries. The capture of the Caucasus by England or Turkey would have been a great disaster for the peoples of the Caucasus. Shamil's troops constantly attacked Kuban stanitsas and Georgian villages. Shamil captured many peasants during his raids, executing them or enslaving them. Shamil's raids intensified especially when Russia's war with Turkey, England, and France began in 1853. Russian troops had a difficult time fighting Shamil's troops, who hid in impregnable gorges and dense mountain forests after raids. However, Russian troops still prevailed against Shamil's troops. Shamil's defeat and the final annexation of the Caucasus. At first, Shamil succeeded in deceiving the highland masses by pretending he was waging a war of liberation for independence. But then the people saw through this deception. They saw that this war was bringing them only suffering and ruin. The highlanders also did not want to be under the rule of Turkey and England. The progressive people of the Caucasus strove for unification with Russia. The masses were dissatisfied with the brutal rule Shamil and the officials he installed over the highlanders and their impoverishment. Shamil wanted to force the highlanders to continue the war against Russia through mass executions. He exterminated entire villages of discontented highlanders. But the people did not submit to Shamil. Shamil's troops began to thin. On a high mountain in the village of Gunib (Dagestan), Shamil was surrounded by Russian troops and captured. Soon after, the Caucasus was finally annexed to Russia. The peoples of the Caucasus gained security from external enemies. The tsarist government, having defeated Shamil, did not free the highlanders of the Caucasus from the oppression of local landowners. Moreover, the tsar established the rule of his officials there. However, the annexation of the peoples of the Caucasus to Russia helped them come into closer contact with the Russian people. They became acquainted with advanced Russian culture. Subsequently, the peoples of the Caucasus fought together with the Russian people against the tsar, landowners, and capitalists.
38. The Revolution of 1848 in Europe. Karl Marx and Friedrich Engels
The Revolution of 1848 and Nicholas I. By the mid-19th century, industry in Europe had already developed significantly. Large industrial centers emerged in a number of countries, with numerous factories and plants equipped with new machinery, and railroads were rapidly being built. Manufacturers and plant owners reaped enormous profits. Rich millionaires emerged, wielding power and authority within the state. Growing industry required ever more labor. A large working class, previously absent, emerged—the proletariat. It began an open struggle against the capitalists for its rights. The Parisian proletariat gained particular prominence in the Revolution of 1848. On February 22, 1848, a revolution broke out in Paris and quickly engulfed the cities of France. The king fled abroad. A bourgeois republic was declared in France. But the revolution in France brought no relief to the workers. At the end of June 1848, the Parisian proletariat rose up against their capitalist masters and the bourgeois republican government. For three days, the workers fought heroically. Their wives and children made lead bullets, helped build barricades, and carried food to the fighters under fire from soldiers. The bourgeoisie moved well-armed troops against the workers. The workers were poorly organized, lacked weapons, and lacked peasant support, and the uprising was suppressed. The bourgeoisie dealt harshly with the vanquished: thousands were shot, imprisoned, and exiled to hard labor. The bourgeoisie celebrated its victory.
The June uprising of Parisian workers in 1848.
At the first news of the revolution in Paris and unrest in Prussia and Austria, Nicholas I moved his army to the border of Prussia and Austria. He bided his time to crush the hated revolutionary movement with his troops. Following France, revolution erupted in many European countries. In the Austrian capital, Vienna, rebellious workers, students, and other citizens overthrew the rule of the nobility. The Emperor fled Vienna. In Berlin, revolutionary workers fought on the barricades for 18 hours and forced the king to yield. A new government was formed in Prussia, and serfdom was abolished. Workers and citizens rebelled against kings, nobles, and, to some extent, capitalists in other European countries as well. The revolution engulfed part of the Austrian Empire—Hungary—and Nicholas I, at the request of the Emperor of Austria, sent his troops there and suppressed the revolution. Thus, Tsar Nicholas I, the gendarme of Europe, fought the revolution. But no force could suppress the young class that rose up in the 1848 revolution—the proletariat. Karl Marx and Friedrich Engels. Marx and Engels were brilliant teachers and leaders of the proletariat. In 1848, they emerged as leaders of the revolutionary workers in Germany. Marx was then 30 years old, and his friend Engels was 28. They were the first communist revolutionaries and, even before the revolution, founded the "Communist League" and wrote the famous "Communist Manifesto." In this manifesto, they called on workers all over the world to fight their enemies—the capitalists. Since then, their call "Workers of the world, unite!" has become the banner of workers all over the world.
Karl Marx (1818–1883).
Friedrich Engels (1820–1895).
After the defeat of the revolution in Germany, Marx and Engels were forced to leave Germany and settled in England. They had to live and work in difficult conditions. Marx's family was in great need. Engels helped his friend as much as he could and shared his failures and joys. But the hard life did not break the great revolutionaries. They tirelessly continued the great work they had begun to liberate the working people from the oppression of the capitalists. They wrote many books from which workers learned how to fight the capitalists and how to defeat them. Marx and Engels taught workers that a fierce struggle has always raged between the oppressed and the oppressors. Under capitalism, such a struggle is inevitable between the bourgeoisie and the workers, and it must end in the victory of the working class. The working class will overthrow the power of the bourgeoisie and establish its revolutionary power—the dictatorship of the proletariat. The victorious proletariat will build a new society—a communist society in which there will be neither classes nor oppression of people. Marx and Engels called on workers of all countries to unite in a single powerful communist party.
39. Tsarist Russia before the reform of 1861.
Industrial development. Until the mid-19th century, industry in feudal Russia developed slowly. Only one tenth of the country's total population lived in cities. Only 500,000 workers worked in factories and mills. Among them were many serfs, freed by landowners on quitrent and hired to work in factories. Machines and steam engines were just beginning to be installed in factories. Only the first steamships appeared on the Volga and Dnieper. Only one major railroad had been built—between Moscow and St. Petersburg. Manufacturers and plant owners were unable to build many factories and mills, as there were few free people available to become hired laborers. Moreover, selling goods in Russia was difficult; serfs bought little. The growing urban population and the growing number of factories and mills strengthened Russia's domestic grain trade. Landowners exported much Russian grain abroad, especially to industrial England. Wanting more grain to sell, they began to oppress the serfs even more. Many landowners realized that serfdom was hindering the development of the landowners' economy, that hired laborers worked the land better and were cheaper to maintain. They began to talk about the need to abolish serfdom. The Crimean War. To gain complete control of the Black Sea coast, to finally drive the Turks out of the Caucasian lands, and to freely transport the landowners' grain through the straits to Europe, Nicholas I launched a new war in 1853 with Turkey, which had weakened by that time. But England and France did not want Russia to grow stronger and defeat Turkey. They formed an alliance and declared war on Nicholas I. The allied fleet entered the Black Sea. Their warships had steam engines and powerful artillery, while Nicholas I had only a sailing fleet. The enemy landed a large army in Crimea and laid siege to Sevastopol. The enemy was armed with cannons and rifles that could fire twice as far as the Russians'. Such was the military technology of a backward, feudal Russia. The tsarist generals didn't even have a good map of Crimea. The army's supplies were in the hands of bribe-takers and embezzlers. The naval fortress of Sevastopol had no land-based fortifications. In a short time, the population and troops built earthen ramparts and installed batteries on the hills. Nicholas I's sailing fleet was unable to engage the enemy fleet. The Russians sank their ships at the entrance to Sevastopol harbor—the enemy fleet could no longer enter. The siege of Sevastopol lasted 11 months. Admiral Nakhimov led the defense of Sevastopol. Russian soldiers fought heroically, stubbornly defending the city. Finally, the main fortification—Malakhov Kurgan, known as the door to Sevastopol—was captured by the French after a brutal bombardment. Sevastopol was completely destroyed. It was no longer possible to hold out. The garrison abandoned the ruins of the fortress. The defeat of Nicholas I's Russia was complete. Nicholas I died unexpectedly during the siege of Sevastopol. Alexander II became tsar. In 1856, peace was concluded in Paris. Russia was forbidden to have a navy or fortresses on the Black Sea. However, Sevastopol remained Russian. Russia's defeat in the Crimean War exposed the extreme backwardness of feudal Russia. After the war, peasant unrest broke out throughout the country, and Tsar Alexander II declared at a meeting of the nobility: it was better to liberate the peasants "from above" than to wait for them to rebel and liberate themselves "from below." A. I. Herzen. The writer and democrat Alexander Ivanovich Herzen resolutely spoke out against serfdom and the tsar's arbitrary rule.
Alexander Ivanovich Herzen (1812–1870).
Nicholas I exiled Herzen from the capital. Returning from exile, Herzen went abroad. Here, together with his friend Ogarev, during the reign of Alexander II, Herzen began publishing the magazine "Kolokol" (The Bell) at the first free Russian printing house in London. In the magazine, he passionately defended the cause of the liberation of the peasantry and oppressed peoples. People were arrested and exiled to Siberia for reading "Kolokol," which was secretly brought to Russia.
IX. The Rise of Capitalism in Tsarist Russia
40. The Abolition of Serfdom in Russia.
The Manifesto of Alexander II, February 19, 1861. Tsar Alexander II, fearing that the peasants would revolt and smash the serfdom system from below, signed the Manifesto on February 19, 1861, emancipating the peasants. The peasants were declared free; they could not be bought or sold; they ceased to be the property of the nobility. However, the peasants were left with little land—less than they had before the reform. The land they were given was poor, and the landlords took the best land for themselves. The landlords carved out for themselves the land the peasants needed, such as forests, meadows, and pastures. The landlords divided the land in such a way that the landlords' fields separated the peasants' lands from the roads to watering holes, forests, and pastures. The peasants were forced to beg the landlords to allow them to use the landlords' plots under any conditions they desired. The peasants were forced to pay the landlords a ransom for their land and their liberation, with the land being valued at double or triple its original value. Over the course of more than forty years, the peasants paid the landlords around two billion rubles in ransom for their liberation. The tsar and the landlords robbed the peasants even more in Crimea, Ukraine, and the Caucasus. In Crimea, they took all the best land along the Black Sea coast. Here were the palaces and estates of the tsar, the royal family, and the court nobility, who kept all the land for themselves. Peasants in Ukraine also received very little land. Landowners were unwilling to give up their fertile black soil. In Georgia, peasants, in addition to a huge ransom, were forced to continue to work for landowners for many years, giving them one-third of the harvest from their vineyards and fields. This abolition of serfdom sparked widespread peasant unrest throughout the country. The peasants demanded complete freedom and the transfer of the necessary land free of charge. Troops were sent in to suppress the peasants, and bloody clashes ensued, resulting in hundreds of dead and wounded. N. G. Chernyshevsky. The interests of the peasants were defended by the best, most educated people of the time. One of them was the great Russian scholar and populist revolutionary Nikolai Gavrilovich Chernyshevsky. Even as a child, he observed the difficult life of serfs and Volga barge haulers. During the preparation of the reform, Chernyshevsky wrote many articles demanding that the peasants be given complete freedom and all the landowners' land free of charge.
Nikolai Gavrilovich Chernyshevsky (1828–1889).
Following the February 19 Manifesto, Chernyshevsky, along with other populist revolutionaries, called on peasants to revolt against the tsar and the landowners. To this end, Chernyshevsky wrote an appeal, "To the Master's Peasants," which was intercepted by the tsar's gendarmes. Alexander II imprisoned Chernyshevsky in the Peter and Paul Fortress and then exiled him to hard labor. The staunch revolutionary did not renounce his beliefs, and the tsar kept him in a Siberian prison and in exile for 19 years. Marx, Engels, and Lenin highly valued Chernyshevsky as an outstanding scholar and a steadfast and courageous populist revolutionary.
Nikolai Alekseevich Nekrasov (1821–1877).
Poet N. A. Nekrasov. During these same years, the talented Russian poet Nikolai Alekseevich Nekrasov wrote his poetry. His simple verse vividly depicts the bitter life of peasants in Tsarist Russia. He wrote about the cruelty suffered under serfdom and the merciless exploitation of peasants by landowners and capitalists after the reform. "Instead of the chains of serfdom, people invented many others," Nekrasov wrote. Nekrasov's poems were favorite songs of revolutionaries of the time. They are still sung by the Russian people today. Changes in governance. Under serfdom, the landowner himself governed and judged his peasants. After the Peasant Reform, a village elder was appointed to govern each village. Several villages and hamlets were united into a volost, governed by a volost elder. The volost elder and village elders were chosen from among wealthy peasants. They were subordinate to tsarist officials, extorted taxes from the peasants, and assisted the police in pacifying the peasants. In the volosts, volost judges were elected, who judged peasants in minor cases. Volost judges could sentence peasants to flogging, fines, and arrest. Corporal punishment was retained for peasants and criminals. Zemstvo councils were elected in the provinces and districts, overseeing schools, hospitals, and bridge and road repairs. The peasants paid for all of this. Few peasants were elected to the zemstvo councils—one person per 3,000 households. Peasant representatives on the zemstvo councils were mostly kulaks. Landowners ran all affairs in the zemstvo councils. In the cities, city dumas were created to manage municipal affairs, with the right to vote granted only to factory owners, merchants, and wealthy homeowners. The military service system was changed. Everyone over 21 years of age was now eligible for conscription. The term of permanent military service was reduced to six years. But as before, peasants served in the army as simple soldiers, and nobles as officers. Even after the reform, the tsar and landowners retained power, owning vast tracts of the best land and keeping the peasants under the strict supervision of the police and officials. But with the abolition of serfdom in Russia, more new factories and plants appeared, railways were built more quickly, and trade began to develop more widely. Serfdom-ridden Russia was becoming a capitalist country.
41. The Poles' Struggle for Independence. The Wars of Alexander II
. The Polish Uprising of 1863. For many years, the Poles, led by the Polish nobility, had been preparing to liberate Poland from the rule of the Russian tsar. In Warsaw, revolutionaries formed the "People's Committee," which prepared the uprising. The "People's Committee," created by the Polish nobility, launched an uprising in 1863 and declared itself the Polish government. The uprising engulfed Poland, part of Lithuania, and part of Belarus. Rebel detachments gathered everywhere. The rebels were armed with pistols, hunting rifles, pikes, and sabers. Avoiding pitched battles with large detachments of Russian troops, they resorted to guerrilla warfare. Rebel units hid in forests and from there attacked the tsarist troops. Over a thousand such small battles took place over the course of a year and a half. The uprising was particularly powerful in Belarus. Here, under the leadership of Kastus Kalinovsky, peasants armed with scythes and axes burned landowners' estates, exterminated small detachments of Russian troops, and killed landowners, tsarist officials, and officers. Alexander II sent an entire army to suppress the uprising. Only after 18 months were the tsarist generals able to crush the bravely fighting rebels. In Belarus and Lithuania, the brutal General Muravyov led the suppression. He mercilessly hanged prisoners. The brave Kastus Kalinovsky was also captured and hanged. After suppressing the uprising, the tsarist government exiled tens of thousands of Poles to Siberia. During the uprising, Tsar Alexander II hastened to issue a law abolishing serfdom in Poland and Lithuania under less oppressive conditions for the peasants than in other Russian provinces: peasant dues were abolished, and in Lithuania, peasants received their former land plots for a lower yen than in other provinces, while in Poland, they received them for free. The tsar needed this to win over the peasants against the Polish landlords. Conquest of Central Asia. At the same time, Tsar Alexander II began decisive conquests in Central Asia. Having consolidated his position in captured Kazakhstan, Tsarist Russia conquered Kyrgyzstan within 10 years. The Kyrgyz stubbornly resisted Russian troops, but their resistance was broken. Moving along the Syr Darya River, Russian troops began advancing on the Uzbek city of Tashkent. The Uzbeks fiercely defended their lands, and the Russians were forced to take Tashkent twice. They only fortified their position in 1865. Three years after occupying Tashkent, Russian troops captured the ancient city of Bukhara—Samarkand (once the capital of Tamerlane). The ruler of Bukhara, the emir, acknowledged the authority of the Russian tsar and was forced to surrender his fertile lands. The Khan of Khiva's lands were then subjugated. The khan also acknowledged his allegiance to the Russian tsar. Following this, the Kokand Khanate was conquered. The warlike tribes of Turkmenistan fought the tsar's troops for 12 years for their independence. They repelled strong Russian forces from their main fortress, Geok-Tepe, and yielded it only after a crushing Russian offensive with powerful artillery. Ashgabat was then occupied by tsarist troops. At the end of the 19th century, Russia conquered the Pamir Mountains—the "roof of the world." Thus, over the course of 30 years of persistent warfare, Tsarist Russia conquered the lands of the peoples of Central Asia. Following the Russian troops, tsarist officials and merchants moved into Central Asia. They exacted heavy taxes from the population, confiscated their lands and property, cheated them, and defrauded them in trade. Khans, elders, and mullahs bribed by the tsar aided them in plundering the conquered peoples. Cotton from American seeds began to be grown on favorable lands. Cotton was needed for Russia's growing textile factories. All the profits from cotton cultivation fell into the hands of local wealthy individuals and Russian factory owners, who profited from the labor of the enslaved poor—Uzbeks, Turkmens, and Tajiks. The peoples of Central Asia were completely at the mercy of tsarist generals, nobles, and capitalists. The oppressed masses repeatedly rebelled, but the Russian nobles prevailed, aided by the wealthy indigenous population. Central Asia became a colony of tsarist Russia. War with Turkey. At the end of the reign of Alexander II (in 1877), Russia fought a war with Turkey. The Russian tsar failed to seize the straits from the Black Sea to the Mediterranean this time as well. Under the peace treaty with Turkey, Russia received the major trading port of Batumi on the Black Sea. As a result of this war, the Slavic peoples of the Balkans (Bulgarians, Serbs, and others), as well as Romania, were liberated from Turkish rule. Despite Russia's enormous superiority over Turkey, Russia's backwardness led to enormous losses in the war: hundreds of thousands of poorly armed soldiers died in vain.
42. The First International and the Paris Commune
The First International. Marx and Engels considered the revolutionary movement of European workers in 1848 to be only the beginning of the proletariat's struggle for liberation. They knew this struggle would be difficult and that the bourgeoisie would defend its dominance. The great leaders of the proletariat believed that to successfully combat the bourgeoisie, the proletariat needed to organize its own international party. Therefore, they created the first international association of the proletariat. In 1864, at a congress of workers' representatives in London, at the suggestion of Marx and Engels, the International Workingmen's Association—the First International—was founded. Karl Marx was the leader of the First International. The First International united the workers' movement of various countries. Marx developed a unified program for this movement. For nearly ten years, Marx led the First International and organized the working masses. Engels was his faithful assistant. Marx and Engels stubbornly and persistently defended the interests of the working class and waged a constant struggle against all who pointed the proletariat to false and harmful paths. Marx and Engels tirelessly exposed those who, calling themselves socialists but in fact being supporters of the capitalists and traitors to the workers, convinced workers that socialism could be built peacefully, without overthrowing the power of the bourgeoisie. Marx and Engels also tirelessly explained the enormous harm caused by those who considered themselves revolutionaries but opposed the establishment of workers' power, the dictatorship of the proletariat. They argued that such views benefited only the enemies of the working class, the capitalists. These views were harmful because they reconciled workers to capitalist exploitation, weakened the proletariat, and made it easier for the capitalists to deal with them. The Paris Commune. In 1870, war broke out between Prussia and France. Prussia emerged victorious in this war. The French troops were routed. The French Emperor Napoleon III and his army were captured. A revolution of workers and petty-bourgeois urban masses began in Paris. But the bourgeoisie came to power. Prussian troops advanced on Paris. An armed citizen's army, the "National Guard," was then formed in Paris, consisting largely of workers. The Germans approached Paris and laid siege. Workers' battalions rose up to defend their city and vowed to die rather than surrender it to the enemy. Surrounded by enemy troops, the population of Paris steadfastly held out for four and a half months. Workers and their families starved. The bourgeois government, fearing a workers' uprising against the bourgeoisie, committed outright treason—secretly, it negotiated with the Germans to surrender Paris. But the workers remained armed. German troops, seeing the formidable strength of the Parisian workers, did not dare enter the city. Then the bourgeois government minister, a despicable traitor and enemy of the people, Thiers, sent a detachment of soldiers to suddenly seize the cannons from the workers. But the working women noticed the detachment's approach and raised the alarm. The National Guard recaptured the cannons. Many soldiers defected to the people and promptly executed two of their generals. Then Thiers, the ministers, generals, the bourgeoisie, speculators, officials, and priests fled Paris for Versailles. On March 18, 1871, power in Paris passed into the hands of the working class. The working class formed its own government—the Paris Commune. Some of the members of the Paris Commune were socialists, members of the First International. Marx and Engels called on the Commune to attack Versailles, where Thiers' bourgeois government had taken refuge. But the Commune hesitated to take such a step. The indecisiveness of the Paris Commune can be explained by the fact that it included many hesitant petty-bourgeois revolutionaries who believed in the "good intentions" of the bourgeoisie. Marx harshly criticized this indecision. Meanwhile, Thiers' troops formed a tight encirclement around Paris. The Commune handed over the factories to the fleeing bourgeoisie. Churches and monasteries were converted into public clubs. Everything was done to improve the workers' situation. An order was issued for workers to move from dark and damp basements to the homes of the rich. The entire world tensely followed the great struggle of the Parisian proletariat. But the Communards were under siege, cut off from the rest of France. They failed to forge an alliance of workers and peasants against the bourgeoisie, and they failed to win over the peasantry. The Communards fought heroically against the numerous and well-armed troops of the Versailles bourgeois government. Women and children fought alongside men. On May 21, Thiers' troops stormed Paris. German troops assisted Thiers. The bourgeoisie dealt brutally with the Communards. Within a week, tens of thousands of men, women, and children were shot. Even more workers were imprisoned and exiled to distant islands for hard labor.
A battle between the Communards and Thiers' troops in a Paris square.
The Paris Commune was crushed. It lasted 71 days and forever remained in the memory of the proletariat. Every year, workers lay wreaths at the Communards' graves in one of the Parisian cemeteries, where the heroes of the Commune were shot against the wall. The Paris Commune perished because the workers did not yet have their own workers', Marxist, revolutionary party, capable of unhesitatingly leading the workers against the bourgeoisie. And also because the workers did not have the support of the peasants and did not understand the importance of an alliance between the workers and the peasants. Five years after the fall of the Paris Commune, in 1876, the First International ceased to exist. The significance of the First International was enormous. It was the first international workers' union, serving as a model for the Communist International founded by Lenin. Karl Marx died in 1883, and Engels in 1895. Their teachings set the workers' struggle for communism on the right path and formed the basis of the work of V. I. Lenin and our Communist Party.
43. Capitalism in Russia
. The life of workers and peasants under capitalism. After the reform of 1861, tens of millions of peasants continued to live in terrible poverty and without rights. They had little land. To feed themselves and pay taxes, the peasants were forced to lease land from landowners or borrow money from them. The landowners forced the peasants to cultivate the land with the peasants' horses and tools under oppressive conditions. The landowners, like spiders, sucked everything they could from the peasants. By the end of the 19th century, half of all peasants had become poor, either having no horses at all, or having one emaciated horse. The middle peasants still managed their farms somehow. If there was a crop failure or crop failure, the middle peasants became impoverished, fell into even greater dependence on the landowners and the kulak peasants, and were forced to work for them as farmhands.
Barge haulers on the Volga. From a painting by I. E. Repin.
In addition to the landowners, the peasants were robbed and oppressed by the kulaks. The ruined peasants fled to the cities. The cities grew rapidly, and industry developed in them. By the end of the 19th century, there were already more than 2 million workers in Russia.
