Large industrial centers were formed: in St. Petersburg and Nizhny Novgorod (now the city of Gorky) - machine-building plants; in Tula, in the Urals and in the Donetsk Basin - metallurgical plants; Textile factories flourished in the Moscow, Vladimir, Kostroma, and Yaroslavl provinces. Impoverished peasants flocked to these areas. Many workers were also needed for railroad construction. By the end of the 19th century, Russia already had over 30,000 kilometers of railroads, and construction had begun on a road across Siberia. Hundreds of thousands of peasant families flocked to the vast Siberian lands. In Siberia's harsh natural conditions, they toiled tirelessly to develop this rich region. Peasants penetrated the remote taiga. Russia's ancient holdings were populated en masse by impoverished peasants. Life for the workers was no better. Factory owners and manufacturers forced workers—not only men, but also women and children—to work 13–14 hours a day. Often, the workday lasted 17–18 hours. They were forced to work even on holidays. There were no vacations. Such backbreaking labor was paid a pittance, because crowds of hungry people stood at the gates of factories and plants, begging for work.
The workers demanded that their employers raise their wages.
Workers were fined for every possible reason—a portion of their wages was withheld. The factories were dirty, damp, and dark; there weren't even any vents in the windows. Workers lived in cramped, filthy barracks-like buildings, where workers from different shifts slept on the same beds: as soon as one woke up, another would lie down. In Tsarist Russia, both workers and peasants were equally disenfranchised. But the workers in the factories and plants were the first to unite and rise up against their oppressors. And then the peasants—the Narodniks—followed them. Many Russian revolutionaries of the time failed to understand the vanguard role of the working class. They incorrectly believed that all power lay in the peasantry and that liberation from the rule of the tsar and the landowners could be achieved through a peasant uprising alone. They failed to understand that peasants alone, without an alliance with the working class, could not defeat tsarism and the landowners. Soon after the 1861 peasant reform, these revolutionaries began secretly organizing revolutionary circles of young people, mostly students, in many Russian cities. These circles heatedly discussed how to help the peasantry. It was decided to go to the villages ("to the people," as they said at the time) and call on the peasants to revolt against the tsar and the landowners. That's why these revolutionaries were called Narodniks. But the peasants didn't follow them. The Narodniks then decided to continue the struggle without the people, using their own forces. They planned to begin by assassinating the tsar and organized a secret society called "Narodnaya Volya." They spent much time and effort preparing the assassination. Only on March 1, 1881, did the Narodniks succeed in killing Alexander II with a bomb. But nothing came of it. In place of one murdered tsar or minister, another, even more vicious, arose. Alexander II's son, Alexander III, became tsar, under whom life became even worse for the workers and peasants. Almost all of the Narodnaya Volya revolutionaries were tracked down and arrested by the tsarist gendarmes. By order of Alexander III, five of them were hanged, while the others were imprisoned for life in a fortress or exiled to hard labor. The Narodniks' failure was no accident. The path they chose to fight tsarism, the path of terror, was mistaken and very harmful to the revolution. The Narodniks' activities were harmful because they prevented the working class from understanding its leading role in the revolution and hindered the creation of a Marxist workers' party. They distracted workers from the struggle against the entire oppressor class with the useless assassinations of individual members of that class, and they hindered the creation of a workers' and peasants' alliance. In 1887, a small group of revolutionaries again attempted to assassinate the tsar (Alexander III), but failed. The organizers of the assassination—Lenin's older brother, Alexander Ulyanov, and his comrades—were captured by the gendarmes and hanged. A second mistake brought the same harm. Vladimir Ilyich Ulyanov (Lenin) was already 17 years old at the time. Upon learning of his brother's execution, he said, "No, we won't go that way. This is not the way to go." Lenin was right. Only an organized working class, in alliance with the peasantry, leading the peasantry, could achieve complete victory over the power of the tsar and the landowners. Russian scientists, writers, and artists. The second half of the 19th century saw many talented scientists, writers, artists, and composers. Great Russian scientists lived during this time. Dmitri Ivanovich Mendeleev made outstanding discoveries in chemistry. He worked extensively to study the natural resources of our country. Ivan Mikhailovich Sechenov was the first to scientifically explain the workings of the human brain. Nikolai Yegorovich Zhukovsky discovered the laws essential to aircraft construction. He is called the "father of Russian aviation." Alexander Stepanovich Popov invented the radio.
Dmitri Ivanovich Mendeleev (1834–1907).
Alexander Stepanovich Popov (1859–1906).
Ilya Efimovich Repin (1844–1930).
Leo Nikolayevich Tolstoy (1828–1910).
The greatest Russian writer, Leo Nikolayevich Tolstoy, began writing his works at a young age, when he participated in wars with the highlanders of the Caucasus and in the defense of Sevastopol during the Crimean War. Tolstoy wrote his most significant works after leaving military service and settling on his estate, Yasnaya Polyana (near the city of Tula). His main work, War and Peace, vividly depicts Russia's war with Napoleon I in 1812. In his works, Tolstoy described the lives of landowners under serfdom and under the capitalist system. Towards the end of his life, he began writing about the desperate situation of the peasants after the 1861 reforms. Tolstoy was not a supporter of the revolution. But he witnessed the hard life of the peasants and castigated the tyranny of tsarist officials, landowners, and capitalists. The great Russian artists Ilya Efimovich Repin and Vasily Ivanovich Surikov also lived during this period. Repin was born in Ukraine to a soldier's family and loved to draw from childhood. Surikov was born in Siberia to a Cossack family. Repin and Surikov understood the peasants' lives well, as they themselves came from the common people. Their paintings are known throughout the world. The second half of the 19th century saw the birth and creation of major musical works by the great Russian composers Mussorgsky, Rimsky-Korsakov, Borodin, and Tchaikovsky. Mussorgsky wrote the opera Boris Godunov, and Rimsky-Korsakov wrote The Snow Maiden and Sadko. In their operas, they made extensive use of songs from the peoples of Russia. We often listen to all these wonderful works even today.
44. The Labor Movement of the 1970s–1990s. V. I. Lenin
. The First Workers' Unions. Even under Tsar Alexander II, workers began to fight against the capitalists. Workers would collectively present demands to the factory or plant owner for improvements in their situation and refuse to begin work until the owner met these demands. This was called a strike. To more effectively fight the capitalists, workers began to unite in unions. The first, the "South Russian Union," was founded in Odessa in 1875. The union prepared for the fight against the autocracy and called on workers to unite for revolution. But its members were soon arrested. Its leader, Zaslavsky, was exiled to hard labor, where he died. Three years later, the "Northern Union of Russian Workers" was organized in St. Petersburg, led by carpenter Khalturin and mechanic Obnorsky. This union had already begun to participate in workers' strikes and led them. The tsarist government also crushed this workers' union. But the labor movement spread to more and more regions. Life became increasingly difficult for workers, and capitalists robbed them more and more. The manufacturer Morozov mercilessly fined his workers. Under the guise of fines, he confiscated one-third of their earnings. In 1885, eight thousand workers at Morozov's textile factory in Orekhovo-Zuyevo could not stand this plundering and went on strike. The factory shut down. This strike had been pre-organized. It was led by a leading worker, Moiseenko, who had previously been a member of the Northern Union of Russian Workers. Together with a group of his fellow weavers, he wrote demands to the factory owner, and the workers approved these demands at a secret meeting.
A workers' meeting before Morozov's strike.
Morozov refused to fulfill the workers' demands and secured the arrest of one of their leaders. A crowd of weavers forcibly freed their arrested comrade. Morozov called in troops to the factory, who routed the workers. 600 striking workers were arrested, several dozen of whom were put on trial. Similar strikes occurred in many factories across Russia. The following year, the tsarist government, frightened by the growing labor movement and strikes, was forced to issue a law preventing factory owners from so brazenly cheating workers. Workers realized they could achieve much through organized struggle. Advanced Russian workers first began to become acquainted with the teachings of Marx and Engels through workers' circles and unions. The "Emancipation of Labor" group. Proletarian revolutionaries—supporters of Marx's teachings who believed that the leading role in the revolutionary movement should belong to the proletariat—emerged in Russia at that time. One such revolutionary was Georgy Valentinovich Plekhanov
(1856–1918) , the first propagandist of Marxism in Russia.
After leaving the country, Plekhanov formed the revolutionary Marxist group "Emancipation of Labor" in 1883. The group translated the works of Marx and Engels into Russian and disseminated them in Russia. It also pointed out the enormous harm the Narodnik teachings and their methods of struggle wrought on the workers' movement. Study circles in which Marx's works were studied began to develop rapidly in Russia. However, both the "Emancipation of Labor" group and these circles were not yet connected to the workers' movement. This was done by Lenin, who organized the Bolshevik Party and led the working class and peasantry in struggle against the tsarist government, landowners, and the bourgeoisie.
Lenin at school.
V. I. Lenin—leader of the working class and founder of Bolshevism. Vladimir Ilyich Lenin (Ulyanov) was born in 1870 in the city of Simbirsk (now Ulyanovsk). He was an excellent student at school. At 17, Lenin enrolled at Kazan University, but was soon expelled for participating in the revolutionary student movement. He then began preparing for the university's full curriculum exams, which he passed. In Kazan, Lenin joined a Marxist circle, studied the works of Marx and Engels, and amazed everyone with his knowledge. In 1893, Lenin moved to St. Petersburg and began working with workers in circles. Lenin united all the workers' circles in St. Petersburg into the "Union of Struggle for the Emancipation of the Working Class," thereby paving the way for the creation of a truly revolutionary workers' party. At his suggestion, similar unions were organized in other cities.
V. I. Lenin in a workers' circle in St. Petersburg (in the 1890s).
Vladimir Ilyich Lenin in the 1890s.
Lenin mercilessly fought the Narodniks and all those who misinterpreted Marx's teachings. Lenin delved into every detail of workers' lives, writing leaflets and books for them, calling for a persistent struggle against the capitalists. Tsarist detectives managed to arrest Lenin. He was held in prison for a long time, and then exiled to Siberia for three years. The "Leagues of Struggle" organized by Lenin made the first attempt to unite into a party. For this purpose, the First Congress of the Russian Social Democratic Labour Party (RSDLP) was convened in Minsk in 1898. However, the party failed to form at this congress. After returning from exile, Lenin went abroad and began publishing the first Marxist newspaper, called Iskra. Iskra was printed on thin tissue paper to facilitate its clandestine smuggling back to Russia. Lenin wrote articles for Iskra, calling on workers to unite in a revolutionary political party to fight the autocracy and the capitalists. Lenin's Iskra prepared the way for the creation of the Bolshevik Party. The workers' struggle flared up and soon spread to the outskirts of Russia, including Transcaucasia, where Lenin's disciple, Comrade Stalin, had been working since the late 1990s.
X. The First Bourgeois Revolution in Russia
45. On the Eve of the Revolution:
the Obukhov Defense and the Rostov Strike. From the beginning of the 20th century, the revolutionary workers' struggle intensified. Workers staged strikes, demonstrated, and rose up to fight against the capitalists and the tsarist government. Nicholas II was the tsar at the time. (He began his reign in 1894.) In 1901, in St. Petersburg, on May Day (a holiday celebrated by workers around the world), workers at the Obukhov military plant went on strike. They presented their demands to their management. The confused administration didn't know what to do and asked the workers: "So, what's wrong? You'll soon demand that not only us, but also the ministers be fired?" "Not only the ministers, but the tsar himself," the strikers responded. Factory management called in the police and troops to suppress the workers. But the strikers erected barricades in and around the factory and met the arriving pacifiers with a hail of stones and broken iron. Police and soldiers opened fire. For several hours, the workers fought the troops.
The strikers were dispersed.
Several workers were killed and seriously wounded. This workers' struggle became known as the Obukhov Defense. About 800 participants in the defense were arrested, many of them imprisoned for long periods and exiled to hard labor. News of the Obukhov heroes spread throughout the country. Workers rose up in all corners of vast Russia. In 1902, a large railway workers' strike occurred in the city of Rostov-on-Don. They were joined by workers from other factories. The strike and workers' meetings were led by the RSDLP committee. Committee members spoke openly at meetings, calling on workers to wage a decisive and steadfast struggle until complete victory over the tsarist regime. Workers' rallies outside the city lasted for several days. Up to 30,000 workers from Rostov-on-Don attended these meetings. The police and local Rostov troops were powerless to stop the strikers. Rostov authorities, in an attempt to suppress the strike, called in Cossacks from neighboring towns. Only then was the strike called off. The Rostov strike demonstrated that the Russian working class had risen to open political struggle against the tsarist regime. The peasant movement. Following the workers, the peasants also rose up. In the spring and summer of 1902, the peasant struggle spread to more than 300 villages and hamlets in Ukraine and the Volga region. Peasants destroyed landowners' estates, divided the landowners' grain among the hungry, and seized the landowners' lands. Troops were sent against the peasants. They were shot and flogged to death with rods. Thousands of peasants were arrested and imprisoned. The peasant movement was crushed. The peasants did not yet understand that to defeat the landowners, they first had to destroy the tsarist regime. Lenin, in the newspaper Iskra, called on the peasants to fight against the tsarist regime together with the workers. But the work of the Social Democrats, supporters of Iskra, in the villages was hampered by the Socialist Revolutionary Party (SRs), which arose at the beginning of the 20th century. This party, under the guise of protecting the peasants, defended the interests of the kulaks and tried to implement the incorrect program of the Narodniks. Lenin waged a persistent struggle against the SRs. The Russian Social Democratic Labor Party was founded. Lenin's Iskra rallied the disparate Social Democratic organizations in Russia. What had previously failed—to create a revolutionary proletarian party—was now achieved. In 1903, the Second Congress of the RSDLP convened secretly abroad. Forty-three delegates from various Russian cities attended the congress. The congress adopted the party program, developed by V. I. Lenin. It outlined the primary task of the working-class party—organizing a socialist revolution, establishing the dictatorship of the proletariat, and achieving the victory of socialism. But to achieve this primary goal, the program stated that the party must first achieve its immediate objective—overthrowing the tsarist autocracy in Russia, creating a democratic republic, establishing an eight-hour workday for workers, abolishing all remnants of serfdom in the countryside, and reclaiming the peasants' land. To achieve these great goals, Lenin demanded that only staunch fighters for the workers' cause, proven friends of the working class, be admitted to the party. The party, Lenin argued, must be the vanguard of the working class, and its members must be selflessly devoted to the revolution. Lenin demanded that party membership be restricted to those who accepted the party's program and participated personally in one of its organizations. Martov, Trotsky, and several other delegates opposed this demand. They proposed admitting anyone who wished to join the party, including anyone who promised to contribute to the party in any way, but did not require mandatory work in its organizations or submission to party discipline. Such a proposal weakened the party as the leader of the working class, as it could be infiltrated by unstable, hostile bourgeois elements. Following this, Lenin's opponents, led by Martov and Trotsky, proposed that the workers form an alliance with the bourgeoisie, not the toiling peasantry, to fight tsarism. Lenin denounced the harm of Martov and Trotsky's proposals and argued that the working class should never enter into an agreement with the bourgeoisie, lest it betray the workers. The workers needed to unite not with the bourgeoisie, but with the revolutionary peasantry, and join forces to fight against the tsar and the landowners. Lenin and his supporters advocated immediately beginning the struggle against the capitalists, the struggle for socialism, after the overthrow of tsarism and the landowners. The congress elected the Central Committee of the party and the editorial board of the newspaper Iskra, which it tasked with directing the party's work. Lenin's supporters were elected to the Central Committee and the editorial board of Iskra; they received a majority of votes at the congress, earning them the nickname "Bolsheviks," while his opponents, who received a minority at the congress, were called "Mensheviks." After the congress, the majority of Russian Social Democratic organizations supported the Bolsheviks. Comrade Stalin was not present at the Second Congress; he was in prison. In 1904, he escaped from Siberian exile and led the workers of Transcaucasia to the Bolsheviks. Advanced workers firmly believed in Lenin and Stalin. There were thousands of such workers at the time. Under the leadership of the RSDLP, the first general workers' strikes occurred in the summer of 1903 in the major cities of Ukraine and the Caucasus. All factories and plants came to a standstill. Workers gathered in the thousands on the streets and squares. Speakers delivered speeches about the revolution. Workers staged marches and demonstrations with red flags—the banners of the proletarian struggle for socialism. Having amassed troops in the cities, the tsarist government suppressed these strikes. But the strikes had their effect—they accelerated and brought the revolution closer.
46. The Revolution Began
. War with Japan. Tsar Nicholas II tried by all means to stifle the revolution. Those close to the Tsar advised him to quickly begin the long-planned war with Japan. They believed that war would delay the revolution. "Better war than revolution," his courtiers advised Nicholas II. But the Japanese started the war first. In January 1904, without any declaration of war, they treacherously attacked the Russian-built fortress on the Yellow Sea, Port Arthur, where Russian warships were moored, and blew up the best of them with mines. Japan transported troops from its islands by sea to Manchuria. The well-armed and trained Japanese army began to defeat the backward Tsarist army, poorly armed and led by incompetent generals—bribe-takers and thieves. The Japanese captured the fortress of Port Arthur and defeated the Tsarist army at Mukden. In the narrow Tsushima Strait, the Japanese destroyed the last warships of Tsarist Russia sent from the Baltic Sea. The tsarist autocracy, defeated in the war, concluded a shameful peace with Japan. Japan took half of Sakhalin Island and Port Arthur from Russia, and entrenched itself in Korea. Bloody Sunday and the first Soviet of Workers' Deputies. The unsuccessful Russo-Japanese War further intensified the people's hatred of the tsarist government. The war did not delay the revolution, but rather accelerated it. In early January 1905, the large Putilov factory (now the Kirov factory) in St. Petersburg went on strike. A general strike soon broke out in St. Petersburg. Stormy meetings and assemblies took place at the factories. The workers sought a way out of their dire and disenfranchised situation. They put forward demands for an eight-hour workday, freedom of association, freedom of the press, and freedom of speech. The workers also demanded the transfer of landed estates to the peasants and the convening of a Constituent Assembly to change the political system in Russia. To combat the labor movement, several months before the strike, the tsarist government created the "Workers' Society," headed by the provocateur priest Gapon. When the strike began, Gapon urged workers at his society's meetings to march to the tsar and write him a petition. The workers included all their demands in this petition. The Bolsheviks urged the workers not to listen to Gapon. "Freedom and land are not won by petitioning the tsar," they said, "they must be won with arms in hand." But Gapon convinced the workers to go to the tsar with this petition. Gapon had a hidden agenda: to provoke bloodshed among the workers and thereby weaken the labor movement. On January 9, 1905, early on a frosty morning, crowds of workers with their wives and children marched to the Winter Palace. In total, over 140,000 people gathered. The unarmed populace greeted the tsar's troops with volleys of gunfire. More than a thousand people were killed, hacked to death with sabers, or crushed to death by Cossack horses. The streets of St. Petersburg were awash with workers' blood.
On January 9, 1905, hundreds of workers were shot in the square near the Winter Palace.
That day, the workers learned a bloody lesson. It became clear to everyone that the tsar and his servants could not be trusted. That evening, workers began building barricades on the outskirts of the city. Red flags flew from the barricades. Workers attacked officers and police officers, disarming them. The Bolsheviks led the workers' struggle. An explosion of indignation at the tsar's bloody atrocity swept across the country. Workers abandoned their jobs and took to the streets singing revolutionary songs, chanting the slogan "Down with the Tsarist Autocracy." Revolution soon engulfed the entire country. Mass strikes and worker protests continued throughout the spring. In May 1905, a particularly stubborn strike began in the textile mill town of Ivanovo-Voznesensk. The workers were led by Bolsheviks. Outside the city, thousands of workers gathered on the Talka River. They elected deputies to lead their struggle against the tsarist regime and the factory owners, forming a Council. This was one of the first Soviets of Workers' Deputies in Russia. This Council met daily, surrounded by thousands of workers. Bolsheviks, who led the Council, spoke at these meetings. The crowd listened eagerly to the revolutionary speeches of the orators. The heroic struggle of the workers lasted for more than two months. The workers and their families were starving, but they did not surrender. But on orders from the tsarist governor, troops began firing on the workers. Finally, the workers' strength was exhausted. On the proposal of the Council, a 40,000-strong meeting of workers decided to end the strike. The strike steeled the workers and prepared them for a further, even more stubborn struggle. Peasant Movement. In the spring of 1905, peasant unrest began. In central Russia and the Volga region, peasants seized land and forests, stole grain from landowners' barns, and divided it among the hungry. They burned landowners' estates, demanded division, and in some places seized the landowners' lands. Frightened landowners fled their estates under the protection of troops and police. The tsarist government sent soldiers and Cossacks against the peasants. Troops shot, imprisoned, and flogged peasants. But the peasants, supported by workers in the cities, did not cease their struggle. The peasant movement grew stronger every day.
Peasants seized landowners' estates.
In Georgia, peasants stopped paying their dues to the landowners. In several places, they seized land, pastures, and forests, refusing to recognize any tsarist authority. The peasants themselves managed affairs. In Latvia and Estonia, farm laborers rebelled in the spring and summer of 1905. They armed themselves and formed revolutionary peasant committees. Relying on these organizations, they expelled the German barons, landowners, from the villages of Latvia and Estonia. Peasants in Ukraine and Belarus also rose up in struggle against the tsarist government and the landowners. The Third Congress of the RSDLP. At Lenin's insistence, the Third Congress of the RSDLP was convened in London in April 1905. The party then had up to 8,500 members. Delegates from 20 Bolshevik party committees attended the congress. The Mensheviks refused to participate in the congress and did not attend. Lenin stated at the congress that for the revolution to succeed, it was necessary to create and strengthen an alliance of workers and peasants, join forces to launch an armed uprising, overthrow the tsar, and establish a revolutionary government of workers and peasants. The peasants must create their own revolutionary committees and seize all the land from the landowners without compensation. The workers must lead and support this peasant struggle. Lenin further stated that after the overthrow of the tsar and the landowners, the Bolsheviks must lead the workers and poorest peasants in a struggle against the capitalists and kulaks, in a struggle for socialist revolution. The Third Congress accepted all of Lenin's proposals. The delegates returned to Russia and began implementing the congress's decisions with great energy. At the same time, Stalin, who was working in Transcaucasia, was leading the struggle for the victory of the revolution alongside Lenin. Stalin strengthened Bolshevik committees there, prepared for the Bolshevik Congress, created an underground printing press, wrote leaflets for the workers, taught and rallied revolutionary workers and peasants, and directed preparations for an armed uprising. Comrade Stalin devoted much effort to uniting the workers and toiling peoples of Transcaucasia and all of Russia into a single family.
47. Preparation for an Armed Uprising.
Mutiny on the battleship Potemkin. The revolution spread to the army. In June 1905, a sailor's revolt broke out on the battleship Potemkin in the Black Sea.
The revolt took place in June 1905.
The battleship was anchored near Odessa, where workers were on strike. The sailors knew about the events in Odessa and were extremely excited, eager to join the fight to support the workers, who were urging them to fight. One day during lunch, one of the sailors shouted, "Guys, there are worms in the borscht!" The ship's officers were feeding the sailors rotten meat and pocketing the money. This incident with the worms in the borscht precipitated the uprising. A murmur arose among the sailors. The ship's commander appeared and ordered the sailors to disperse. The sailors disobeyed. The commander ordered 30 sailors arrested and executed. The sailors' hearts boiled with anger and resentment. At the call of sailor Matyushenko, they armed themselves and, shouting "Beat the monsters!", rushed at the hated officers, killed them, and threw them overboard. A red flag was raised over the Potemkin. The Tsar sent warships to suppress the Potemkin. But the sailors on these ships refused to fire on the rebellious battleship. The Potemkin, however, could not hold out for long without coal and provisions. Nor did it have sufficiently experienced Bolshevik leaders. The Potemkin crew was forced to flee to Romania and surrender to the authorities there. Despite the failure of the uprising on the Potemkin, it inspired the workers. They saw the navy and army beginning to defect to the revolution. The October General Strike. By the autumn of 1905, the revolutionary movement had engulfed the entire country. With each passing day, the ranks of the strikers swelled with workers from new factories and plants. Workers held meetings in the streets and often clashed with the police and troops who dispersed them. In early October, a strike broke out on the Moscow railways, soon spreading to railways across the country. Postal and telegraph services ceased operation. Teachers, doctors, professors, and students joined the workers in the struggle. In Kharkov and Yekaterinoslav (now Dnepropetrovsk), workers began building barricades and, after sacking weapons stores, engaged in gunfights with troops and police. Under the leadership of the Bolsheviks, workers' unions (trade unions) were organized in many cities. In major industrial centers, Soviets of Workers' Deputies were established. These were the seeds of a new, revolutionary power of workers and peasants. Many Soviets of Workers' Deputies prepared for an uprising, procuring weapons by various means and training workers in military affairs. Combat squads were formed in almost all large factories and plants where Bolshevik party organizations were present. The tsarist government ordered the troops to "spare no ammunition" and to mercilessly execute strikers. In a number of cities, troops fired on workers and dispersed assemblies. The workers were still unable to launch an armed uprising. There were very few combat squads and a shortage of weapons. But even the tsar lacked the strength to suppress the revolutionary movement. His troops were in a state of severe unrest: soldiers began to openly sympathize with the revolution. This was facilitated by the work of the Bolsheviks in the army, where they secretly distributed leaflets calling on soldiers to join the revolution. The tsar's defeat in the war with Japan also contributed to this. Frightened by the spread of the revolution, Tsar Nicholas II issued a manifesto on October 17. In it, he promised to grant freedom to the people and convene a State Duma of representatives of the population to decide, together with the tsar, all state affairs of Russia. The October 17 manifesto was a blatant deception. The tsarist government needed to buy time to gather its forces and drown the revolution in blood. Despite the manifesto of freedoms, the police continued to disperse assemblies, arresting and killing workers and their Bolshevik leaders. In Moscow, tsarist pogromists assassinated Nikolai Ernestovich Bauman, a remarkable Bolshevik leader of the Moscow workers. At Bauman's funeral, a hundred thousand Moscow workers, led by the Moscow Committee of the Bolshevik Party, followed his coffin. In November 1905, Lenin arrived from abroad. He directed the work of the party and the workers' struggle. Meanwhile, in Transcaucasia, Stalin, just as firmly, in Lenin's style, prepared the workers for battle against the tsar and his servants. He denounced the Mensheviks, who opposed preparations for an armed uprising. Comrade Stalin told the workers of Tbilisi: "What is needed to truly win? Three things are needed, understand and remember: the first thing we need is arms; the second is arms; the third is more and more arms." In December 1905, the question of an armed uprising was discussed at a Bolshevik conference. Here, Lenin and Stalin met in person for the first time. Before that, they had kept in touch by letter and through comrades.
48. The December Armed Uprising.
An armed uprising of Moscow workers. On December 7, 1905, a general strike began in Moscow, quickly escalating into an armed uprising. At a predetermined hour set by the Bolsheviks, factories, plants, and railways stopped operating, and the electricity went out. Newspapers ceased publication. Workers began to arm themselves, and militias grew. Police and troops broke up workers' meetings, firing into houses where militias were gathering. Workers on Bronnaya, Tverskaya (now Gorky Street), at the train stations, and at the Goujon factory (now the Hammer and Sickle factory) began to build barricades. Soon, many Moscow streets were covered with barricades made of carts, tram cars, barrels, crates, and street lamps. All this was dumped in the middle of the street, wrapped in telegraph and tram wires. The tsarist cavalry and mounted police could not move through these barriers. At many barricades, workers' combat squads, armed with revolvers, fired at the troops. A continuous firefight raged on the streets of Moscow for several dien. Soybean squads from other places rushed to Moscow's aid. The brave Bolshevik M.V. Frunze arrived from Ivanovo-Voznesensk with his combat workers' squad. Peasants brought bread and potatoes to the workers in Moscow, and sometimes joined the ranks of fighters at the barricades. Presnya (a working-class district of Moscow) became the center of the struggle. The Bolsheviks led the squads. Under their leadership, Presnya held out against the tsarist troops for 10 days. It was a proletarian fortress, where power belonged to the rebellious workers. The Presnya workers heroically defended their district. The workers were assisted by their wives. They bandaged and fed the wounded. The youth demonstrated tremendous courage. They scouted, helped build barricades and ambushes, and fought against the troops.
Workers fighting at the barricades in Moscow in December 1905.
Workers on the Kazan Railway also fought stubbornly against the tsarist troops. There weren't enough troops to counter the rebellious people in Moscow. The tsar sent two regiments of soldiers to Moscow. Only with the help of cannons and machine guns were the rebels routed. General Dubasov sacked Moscow. On December 18, the fighting squads were forced to abandon the barricades and hide their weapons in secret caches. More than a thousand people were killed in Moscow. Fires caused by artillery shells raged for several days throughout the city. The bodies of murdered workers, women, and children littered the streets. Many revolutionary fighters were shot and hanged by the tsarist troops. This is how the tsar's executioners dealt with the rebellious Moscow. During the armed uprising, Lenin was in St. Petersburg. The Bolshevik Central Committee took every measure to rouse the workers to revolt in St. Petersburg. However, the Mensheviks, led by Trotsky, who had established themselves in the St. Petersburg Soviet, opposed supporting the armed uprising in Moscow. The Mensheviks and Socialist Revolutionaries thwarted the workers' revolution. They supported the bourgeoisie, which had conspired with the tsarist government to suppress the revolution. The strike that began in St. Petersburg in December ended without sparking an armed uprising. The struggle of peasants against landlords. During the revolution, peasants rose up against their landlord oppressors throughout almost all of Russia, under the influence of the workers' movement and the appeals of the Bolshevik Party. Almost all of Russia's provinces were engulfed in a peasant movement. Over 7,000 peasant revolutionary uprisings occurred during the three years of revolutionary struggle. Peasants seized land from landowners and monasteries, cut down landowners' and monastery forests, and raided and burned landowners' estates everywhere. In the Saratov province alone, in the fall and winter of 1905, peasants destroyed up to 300 landowners' estates. Peasants expelled the police, volost elders, and village elders and established their own elected government. The most progressive peasants united in peasant unions. The Bolsheviks assisted them in this. The tsar and landowners sent punitive detachments and suppressed peasant uprisings. Armed uprisings of the oppressed peoples of Russia. In Transcaucasia, under the leadership of Comrade Stalin, workers and peasants bravely fought the tsarist troops. All of Georgia was engulfed in rebellion. Masses of tsarist troops were sent into Georgia. Georgian workers and peasants repeatedly engaged in battle with them. In December 1905, many towns and villages in Georgia burned like bonfires lit by tsarist troops. In Ukraine, the first outbreaks of armed rebellion began during the October general strike. The largest uprising in December 1905 occurred in the Donbass: in Horlivka and Luhansk. Factory workers and miners fought for several days against tsarist troops. The workers in Luhansk were then led by the mechanic Klim Voroshilov. In Finland, workers formed their own armed Red Guard. The Red Guard disarmed the tsarist police. Gendarmes, police officers, and tsarist officials abandoned their service in Finland and fled to Russia. The Finnish people elected their own government. The Finnish bourgeoisie, frightened by the growing revolutionary workers' movement, came to an agreement with the tsar and betrayed the workers. The labor movement was soon brutally suppressed. The Red Guard was destroyed, and the government was dispersed. Oppressed peoples everywhere fought against the hated tsarist government. But the bourgeoisie of these peoples, like the Russian bourgeoisie, fought the revolution in alliance with the tsarist regime. This time, the workers and peasants were forced to retreat. The tsar, the landowners, and the bourgeoisie proved stronger. The blood of workers and peasants of all the peoples of Russia spilled in the revolution united the workers and united them in a close, great alliance for a new struggle. The 1905 revolution resonated throughout the world. It was the most powerful struggle of the proletariat since the Paris Commune of 1871. Under the influence of the Russian revolution, a mass strike movement began in Western Europe. In Turkey, workers overthrew their sultan, in Iran, the shah, and in China, the emperor. A republic was established in China.
49. Defeat of the revolution
Suppression of revolutionary uprisings. Despite the bloody reprisals against the rebellious people, the revolution continued. In 1906, workers' strikes, peasants, soldiers, and sailors continued. Particularly significant were the sailors' uprisings in July-August 1906 in Kronstadt and Sveaborg. Thousands of sailors rose up in rebellion, slaughtered their officers, and established their rule in isolated fortifications. But the sailors were poorly organized, and tsarist officers succeeded in suppressing the uprising. The government arrested more than 4,000 sailors. Tsarist Minister Stolypin issued a law for the merciless extermination of revolutionaries. From 1906 to 1909, under this law, more than 2,000 people were hanged, and 25,000 were sent to hard labor, exiled, and imprisoned. Tens of thousands of revolutionaries were shot and tortured without trial. The arrested revolutionaries were subjected to every kind of cruelty: they were tortured in dungeons, had needles driven under their fingernails, burned with hot irons, and starved. Stolypin was particularly harsh against the Bolsheviks. Thousands of revolutionaries devoted to the workers' cause perished on the gallows and in hard labor. Many Bolshevik party organizations were destroyed, the Soviets of Workers' Deputies were destroyed, trade unions and all peasant organizations were closed.
Exiled parties were driven one after another to Siberia.
State Duma. In the same spirit of suppressing the revolutionary movement, Nicholas II convened the State Duma in 1906. According to the law on Duma elections, landowners and capitalists had the right to send more deputies than tens of millions of workers and peasants. Women were deprived of the right to vote. Such was the tsarist constitution. But the tsar soon violated this constitution, too. The first and second State Dumas convened by the tsar were dissolved by him, as they were not always obedient to the tsar and his ministers. The tsar was especially displeased with the Second Duma. Many representatives of peasants and workers were elected to it. Social Democrats had 65 deputies. In their speeches in the Duma, workers and peasants denounced the tsarist government, all its tricks and deceptions of the people. The Tsar ordered the Duma to be dispersed. Tsarist officials drafted a new law on Duma elections. The rights of workers and peasants were further curtailed. All peoples of Siberia and Central Asia were disenfranchised, while the rights of the peoples of the Caucasus and Poland were curtailed. And when the Third Duma convened in the autumn of 1907, the seats in the Tauride Palace in St. Petersburg, where the Duma sessions were held, were almost entirely filled with landowners, merchants, factory owners, generals, and tsarist dignitaries in gilded uniforms. Only a few seats were occupied by deputies representing workers, peasants, and the oppressed peoples of Russia. The State Duma did not change the old order. The nobility, led by the Tsar, continued to rule and plunder Russia. The Third Duma approved the land law of the Tsarist minister Stolypin. All the lands of the landowners remained theirs. The peasants were to be content with the land they had previously owned, but only under new conditions. Previously, most peasants owned the land communally and periodically divided these communal lands among themselves based on the number of workers in their families. Stolypin's law abolished communal land ownership. Each peasant was offered the opportunity to take his plot of land into personal ownership, separate from the commune, and become the owner of his own plot. These peasants who separated from the commune were called khutoryans (farmers), or otrubniks (unclear peasants). Poor peasants, lacking draft animals, tools, or money to pay taxes, sold their plots to wealthy kulaks (kulaks). This was precisely what the tsarist government sought. It wanted to turn the kulaks into small landowners who would defend the tsar's power. More than a million poor peasants were completely deprived of their land and ruined. The government resettled dissatisfied peasants to the lands of peoples living on the outskirts of Russia. The local population was forcibly driven from their native lands into the deserts and mountains. The country's economy after the revolution. Foreign capitalists also helped the tsarist government suppress the revolution. Even before the revolution, they had been purchasing land in Russia with ore, oil, and coal deposits and building their own factories and plants. French and English bankers lent the tsarist government large sums of money, which was used to build railways, finance the army, and support tsarist officials. The revolution in Russia threatened foreign capitalists with the loss of their capital and the enormous profits they earned in Russia.
A metallurgical plant.
Even before the revolution in Russia, capitalists began to form unions to raise prices and deal more quickly with workers. Such associations of capitalists were called trusts and syndicates. After the revolution, bourgeois trusts and syndicates grew in number. After several years of stagnation, industry in Russia revived in 1910: coal, metal, and oil production increased, while sugar and textile production also expanded. Grain exports also increased significantly. While Russia made significant economic progress at this time, it remained a backward country compared to Western Europe and dependent on foreign capitalists. Machines and machine tools were not produced in Russia—they were imported from abroad—and there was no chemical industry. Russia did not produce mineral fertilizers. Russia also lagged behind other capitalist countries in arms production. It turns out that there were more than a few reasons for the defeat of the first bourgeois revolution in Russia. Chief among them was the lack of an alliance between workers and peasants. While the peasants felt that a successful struggle against the landlords was impossible without an alliance with the workers, they failed to understand that the landlords could not be defeated without the overthrow of tsarism. The peasants still believed in the goodwill of their "father the tsar." This is why many peasants were reluctant to form an alliance with the workers to overthrow tsarism, while the sons of peasants, disguised in soldiers' greatcoats, helped the tsar suppress strikes and workers' uprisings. The peasants trusted the compromising Socialist Revolutionaries more than the Bolshevik revolutionaries. The workers also had their shortcomings. The working class was, of course, the vanguard of the revolution, but it was not yet united and cohesive, as its party, the Social Democracy, was divided into two groups: the Mensheviks and the Bolsheviks. The former were compromising and did not want to see the revolution through to completion. The latter, the Bolsheviks, were consistent Leninist revolutionaries and called on the workers to overthrow tsarism. This is why the workers did not always act in unison in the revolution, and the working class was unable to become the true leader (hegemon) of the revolution. The hastily concluded peace with Japan also helped the tsar suppress the revolution. While the war raged and the tsarist troops suffered defeat, the tsar remained weak and was forced to yield to the workers' onslaught. After the conclusion of peace, the situation changed, and the tsar was able to gather forces to fight the revolution.
50. A New Revolutionary Upsurge:
Lenin's departure abroad. Stalin engaged in underground work in Russia. Despite numerous arrests and executions, the Bolsheviks continued the revolutionary struggle. They printed leaflets, newspapers, and brochures. The Bolsheviks used the State Duma election meetings and the Duma itself to openly declare their revolutionary demands and the masses' hatred of the existing system. The entire tsarist police force was deployed to capture the elusive Lenin. At the insistence of the Party, Vladimir Ilyich left first for Finland and then abroad, to Switzerland. From there, he continued to lead the workers' struggle. Lenin's comrade and assistant, Comrade Stalin, remained in Russia. His seething energy inspired the Bolsheviks to a difficult and persistent struggle. In 1908, Stalin was arrested again and exiled to a Siberian province. But prison and exile could not break Stalin's iron will, and the following year, Stalin escaped Siberia and returned to Baku. A year passed. Stalin was arrested again and exiled again. He escaped again. Soon, tsarist spies tracked him down again, and the government exiled Stalin to the deserted Narym region. But the steadfast revolutionary did not give up. In the summer of 1912, he secretly returned to St. Petersburg. Lenin abroad, and Stalin underground in Russia, continued the great struggle for socialism, ready to give their blood drop by drop for the workers' cause. The heroic Bolsheviks helped the working class survive the difficult times of the revolution's defeat and rise again to the revolutionary struggle. The Lena massacre of workers. In the remote Siberian taiga, on the Lena River, lay the gold mines of British capitalists. The lives of the workers there were little different from those of convicts. The British capitalists, however, reaped a profit of 7 million rubles in gold a year from these mines. In the spring of 1912, the workers at the Lena gold mines went on strike. At the British request, the tsarist government sent a detachment of troops under the command of a gendarme officer to the mines. He immediately arrested all the workers' leaders, including exiled Bolsheviks. The workers demanded the release of those arrested. They went to the office. The workers walked along a narrow path, several abreast. Suddenly, a bugle sounded. At the gendarme officer's command, the soldiers lined up along the road. The command to shoot was given.
The execution of workers at the Lena gold mines on April 4, 1912.
Shots rang out. And again and again, the soldiers fired at the workers. Two hundred and fifty dead and 270 wounded workers lay in pools of blood in the snow. News of the massacre on the Lena River spread throughout Russia. Hundreds of thousands of workers abandoned their jobs and took to the streets to protest the new massacre. On May 1, 1912, half a million workers went on strike in Russia. In the villages, peasants once again took up axes, scythes, and pitchforks and destroyed the landowners' estates. Over 13,000 revolutionary peasant uprisings occurred between 1910 and 1914. The Russian people were rising up for a new struggle and marching toward a new revolution. The Bolsheviks were an independent Russian Social Democratic Labor Party. In 1912, representatives of the Russian Bolshevik committees met abroad, in Prague, for a conference. The conference resolved to expel all Mensheviks and all unstable and wavering elements from the party. A united, militant Leninist Bolshevik Party was created. It led the working class and peasantry to a new resolution calling for the overthrow of the tsarist regime and the establishment of workers' and peasants' power, the establishment of an eight-hour workday, and the free transfer of all land to the peasants. The Bolsheviks strengthened their secret party organizations in Russia, including trade unions, workers' clubs, and other open workers' organizations under Bolshevik leadership. Bolshevik newspapers, Zvezda, and then Pravda, began to be published in St. Petersburg. The Bolshevik Pravda was written in simple language understandable to all workers. It helped workers understand the teachings of the Bolshevik Party. The police relentlessly harassed this newspaper, forbidding its sale, and imprisoning editors. V. I. Lenin wrote articles for Pravda and managed it from abroad. I. V. Stalin, V. M. Molotov, and others worked for Pravda.
Barricades in St. Petersburg in July 1914.
During this time, the party nurtured many strong and courageous Bolshevik revolutionaries. Among them was Yakov Sverdlov. He began his revolutionary struggle at the age of seventeen. After spending many years in prison and exile, from which he escaped several times, he finally reached St. Petersburg and fearlessly led the fight against tsarism. S. M. Kirov began his revolutionary activities as early as 1905 and never stopped. Only prisons and exile temporarily distracted this fiery revolutionary from his work. M. V. Frunze, G. K. Ordzhonikidze, V. V. Kuibyshev, and F. E. Dzerzhinsky were all courageous fighters for the workers' cause. M. I. Kalinin, K. E. Voroshilov, L. M. Kaganovich, N. K. Krupskaya, and many others worked tirelessly within the party. They were the party's iron guard, the tireless and steadfast disciples and comrades of Lenin and Stalin. Lenin moved from Paris, where he lived, to Austria, closer to the Russian border, to better direct the work of the Bolsheviks in Russia. At this time, strikes were breaking out one after another in Russia. In Baku, where Stalin had created a strong Bolshevik organization, workers declared a general strike in the oil fields. The workers fought for about a month, but the factory owners prevailed. In the summer of 1914, the workers of St. Petersburg again stopped factories and plants. They took to the streets with red banners. The workers responded to the attack by troops and police with resistance on the barricades. But the rise of the revolution was delayed by the outbreak of the world war. In this war, the tsarist government again sought salvation or revolution.
XI. The Second Bourgeois Revolution in Russia
51. The World Imperialist War
Tsarist Russia at war. In the summer of 1914, the world war began. This war had been in the works for some time. The major capitalist states competed with one another. By the beginning of the 20th century, there wasn't a single inch of land on the globe that hadn't been seized by some state. Capitalists from various countries sought to seize rich lands with numerous populations from each other. German capitalists and landowners were especially greedy in their desire to seize lands. Germany sought to seize some of England's African colonies, and Russia's Ukraine, Poland, and the Baltic states; Russia sought to seize Constantinople from Turkey; England, Mesopotamia and Palestine; France sought to reclaim Alsace-Lorraine, occupied by Germany. In preparation for this predatory war, the capitalists were divided into two camps. In one camp were England, France, and Russia, dependent on them. Their alliance was called the Entente. In the other camp were Germany, Austria-Hungary, Turkey, and Bulgaria. Almost all European countries supported the Entente. Japan and the United States of America were allied with them. The bourgeoisie of the warring countries prepared this predatory war in secret from the people. First, Austria-Hungary attacked Serbia, then Germany, long preparing for war, declared war on Russia. After that, other countries entered the war. When the war began, the bourgeoisie of all the belligerent countries deceived the people, declaring it a war to save their homeland from the enemy. The petty-bourgeois conciliatory parties—the Mensheviks and Socialist Revolutionaries—assisted the Russian bourgeoisie in deceiving the people. The world war lasted four years and cost humanity approximately 30 million lives. The greatest losses were in the army of Tsarist Russia. While the Germans showered the Russian army with shells, the Tsar's ministers and generals left it without sufficient weapons and ammunition. Tens of thousands of Russian soldiers died daily from German cannon fire, machine guns, and disease. But the tsarist generals, obedient to the orders of Tsar Nicholas II and the Entente, urged their soldiers onward with renewed vigor. The generals paid no heed to casualties; for them, soldiers were mere cannon fodder. In the very first months, on the battlefields of Germany, the incompetent tsarist generals destroyed an entire army of 200,000 men. Russia continually recruited new soldiers. At first, only young men were recruited, but later, older men were also included. In total, up to 19 million men were recruited for the war in Russia. During the war, the Russian army inflicted several crushing defeats on the Austro-German armies. The Russian offensive on the Southwestern Front in the summer of 1916 was particularly successful. The Russian army captured enormous trophies and over 100,000 prisoners. This victory forced the Germans to transfer a large number of troops from the Western Front to the Eastern Russian Front and thus helped Italy, France and England stop the German offensive on the Western Front. However, the remarkable breakthrough of the Southwestern Front was not supported by other Russian armies. The incompetent high command and the tsarist government failed to arm or supply the army with everything it needed. At the tsarist court, in the ministries, and throughout the army, there were German spies who passed military secrets to the Germans. Bleeding, dying from gas attacks, freezing in the trenches, the tsarist army, led by incompetent generals, was forced to retreat. By 1916, the Germans had captured Poland, Lithuania, and part of Latvia. But there was no end in sight to the war. The war had severely devastated the Russian economy. There were shortages of metal, coal, and oil. Factories were shut down. The railways couldn't even transport troops. The army and the people were naked and barefoot. The population and soldiers at the front were starving. The grain crops dwindled—there was no one to till the land. A large number of horses and cattle were taken from the peasants for the army. The protracted war imposed incredible pressure on the workers and peasants. The Bolsheviks during the war. The Bolshevik Party opposed global slaughter. Lenin and the Party called on the workers and peasants to take up arms against their oppressors and exposed the vileness of the Mensheviks and Socialist Revolutionaries and their capitalist overlords. In the very first days of the war, workers' organizations were destroyed and closed. The Bolshevik newspaper Pravda was banned even before the declaration of war. Bolshevik deputies of the Fourth State Duma were exiled to Siberia for calling for an anti-war campaign and for calling workers to revolution. The work of the Bolsheviks during the war was difficult. Lenin was separated from Russia by borders and fronts. Other leaders of the Bolshevik Party were in exile. Many Bolsheviks were imprisoned. But the work of the Bolsheviks did not cease. The revolutionary movement during the war. In Russia, under the leadership of the Bolsheviks, mass strikes began. In 1915, there were already 928 strikes in Russia, and in January and February 1917, 1,330. Workers continued their struggle under the slogan: "Down with the war! Down with the tsarist autocracy!" The workers of Petrograd (as St. Petersburg was called from 1914 to 1924) fought at the forefront. In October 1916, they organized a huge political strike against the war and the tsarist autocracy. They even attracted a regiment of soldiers to their side. The workers were also supported by peasants, who rose up in the villages to fight against the war, the landowners, and Stolypin's land laws.
A Russian soldier, standing among barbed wire, curses the tsarist government.
But all the most progressive peasants were in the army. Discontent grew there, and soon, under the influence of the Bolsheviks sent by the Party to work in the army, soldiers also began to protest against the war. Tsarist soldiers at the front began fraternizing with German and Austrian soldiers. Similar fraternization occurred on other fronts of the warring states. The soldiers demanded an end to the bloody slaughter. During the war, oppressed peoples also began to rise up in revolutionary struggle against the tsarist government. Heavy extortion, cattle raiding, and violence against workers caused enormous discontent. This discontent intensified when people began to be drafted for work in the rear. In 1916, Kazakhs, Kyrgyz, Uzbeks, Tajiks, and Turkmens rebelled. They attacked cities, engaged in battle with tsarist troops and police, and killed their own volost elders—servants of the tsarist authorities. The Kazakhs formed their own armed combat units. The leader of the uprising was a brave hero of the Kazakh people, Amangeldy Imanov. The Uzbek rebels destroyed railway lines to prevent troop supplies, burned stations, and cut telegraph wires. In Kyrgyzstan, the rebels obtained weapons by seizing military transport. In the mountains, they built forges and workshops for producing gunpowder. The tsarist authorities sent troops with cannons, machine guns, and armored cars against the rebels. Amid the blood and smoke of burned villages and auls, they suppressed these uprisings. But the united struggle of workers, peasants, soldiers, and oppressed peoples against the war and the tsarist government steadily grew.
52. The Overthrow of Tsarism in February 1917.
Uprising in Petrograd . Tsar Nicholas II and his ministers were at a loss as to how to cope with the defeat at the front and the impending revolution. They were at a loss for what to do. Even the bourgeois "Cadet" party and its leader, Miliukov, ceased supporting the Tsar due to defeats at the front; but the Cadets also feared revolution. The bourgeoisie decided to remove Nicholas II from power and install his brother Mikhail on the throne, suppress the nascent revolutionary movement, and continue the war. Those close to the Tsar advised Nicholas II to end the war, conclude a separate peace with the Germans, and then deal with the revolution. The plans of the Tsar and the bourgeoisie did not come to fruition. They were forestalled by an uprising of workers and soldiers, which began in February 1917. In early 1917, the starving and war-weary workers of Petrograd went on strike. The Bolsheviks led the workers' struggle. They also infiltrated soldiers' barracks, calling on the army to support the workers in their fight against the Tsar. Working men and women took to the streets and demanded: "Down with the war!" Down with the tsarist government! Bread! Peace! Soon the workers began to understand that the tsarist government could not be defeated by a single strike; an armed uprising was necessary—and they rebelled. The tsarist ministers gave the order to shoot the workers without mercy. In the city center, police set up machine guns on rooftops and in attics and fired at the demonstrators. The heroic struggle of the Petrograd workers also drew soldiers into the revolution. On February 27, the troops in Petrograd refused to fire on the workers and began to go over to the side of the people. The rebellious workers and soldiers arrested the tsarist ministers and imprisoned them. Imprisoned revolutionaries were released from prison. Crowds burned police and courthouses. Young workers and working women participated in the uprising alongside their brothers and husbands. Tsar Nicholas II, who was outside Petrograd at the time, sent troops from the front against the rebellious people. But revolutionary workers and soldiers rode out to meet them, explained what they were fighting for, and convinced the troops to disobey the orders of the tsar and the generals. The soldiers obeyed the workers. The revolution triumphed over the tsarist regime. When news of the revolution's victory in Petrograd reached other cities and the front, workers and soldiers overthrew the tsarist regime locally as well. Following the example of the first revolution of 1905, Soviets were created everywhere, but these were no longer just Soviets of workers' deputies, but Soviets of workers' and soldiers' deputies. This marked the difference between the February Revolution of 1917 and the revolution of 1905. The soldiers' deputies in the Soviets were, in essence, peasant deputies, disguised in soldiers' uniforms for the occasion. This meant that the Soviets of workers' and soldiers' deputies were, in fact, Soviets of workers' and peasants' deputies. This meant that an alliance of workers and peasants against the tsarist regime had already formed, and the Soviets of workers' and soldiers' deputies became the organs of this alliance. Without this alliance, the people could not have overthrown the tsar, and the revolution could not have triumphed. Two powers. The bourgeoisie managed to exploit the petty-bourgeois politicians, the Mensheviks and Socialist Revolutionaries, who constituted the majority in the Soviets, and with their help seized power in the country. Traitors to the revolution—the Mensheviks and Socialist Revolutionaries—enabled the bourgeoisie to establish their own bourgeois Provisional Government. But the Soviets continued to exist alongside the Provisional Government. Two powers emerged in the country.
Upon arriving in Petrograd on April 3, 1917, the leader of the proletariat, V. I. Lenin, was greeted by revolutionary sailors and soldiers.
The bourgeoisie and the Mensheviks and Socialist Revolutionaries entrenched in the Soviets sought to continue the war with Germany to a victorious end. The land remained in the hands of the landowners. Capitalists continued to rob the workers. The oppression of the peoples of Russia remained. Lenin, in letters from abroad, and the Bolsheviks, led by Comrade Stalin, who had returned from exile, denounced the Provisional Government to the people and exposed the deceptions of the Mensheviks and Socialist Revolutionaries. On April 3, 1917, Lenin returned to Russia with great difficulty from abroad. All of revolutionary Petrograd —workers, sailors, and soldiers—gathered to greet him. The cheers for Lenin were endless. Lenin climbed onto an armored car, spoke to the people, and into the hushed crowd he issued a fiery appeal: "Long live the world socialist revolution!" It was a call to fight against the bourgeois Provisional Government, to establish working-class power, and to fight for socialism.
XII. The Great October Socialist Revolution in Russia
53. The Bolsheviks Prepare the Socialist Revolution
. The masses follow the Bolsheviks. Upon Lenin's arrival, the party convened a conference of Bolsheviks. Delegates representing 80,000 party members from all over Russia converged on Petrograd . Molotov, Voroshilov, Sverdlov, Kuibyshev, Dzerzhinsky, and many others attended the conference. Lenin and Stalin presided over the conference. They pointed out that the working class had accomplished only its first task—the abolition of the tsarist autocracy in Russia. They said a second task still needed to be accomplished—the socialist revolution. They said the party still faced a serious and arduous struggle, because the bourgeoisie, which had come to dominate the country, would not relinquish power without fierce resistance. They called on the party to win a majority in the Soviets of Workers' and Soldiers' Deputies, as well as in the Soviets of Peasants' Deputies, and to expel the Mensheviks and Socialist Revolutionaries from them. Lenin and Stalin called on the Bolsheviks to organize the masses to fight for the socialist revolution. For the socialist revolution to succeed, they argued, the working class, in close alliance with the poor peasantry, must overthrow the rule of the bourgeoisie. It was necessary to curb the bourgeoisie, wrest the land from the landowners and give it to the peasants for use, grant freedom to the oppressed peoples of Russia, and immediately end the war.
The peasants demanded land. A fellow sailor called for the immediate, organized seizure of the landowners' lands.
Lenin and Stalin's proposals were accepted by the conference. The Bolsheviks launched a massive campaign among the workers, soldiers, and sailors. They also launched a campaign among the peasants. They explained the conference's decisions and called on the people to fight against the Provisional Government for the establishment of Soviet power, an end to the war, and the immediate transfer of all land to the peasants. Workers' and soldiers' demonstrations began in Petrograd . In April, a demonstration of workers and soldiers was organized. The demonstrators carried placards and banners with Bolshevik slogans: "Down with the war! " "Down with the capitalist ministers! " "All power to the Soviets!" The Provisional Government, together with the Mensheviks and Socialist Revolutionaries, was forced to remove the most hated capitalist ministers, Guchkov and Milyukov, from their posts and included several Mensheviks and Socialist Revolutionaries in its ranks. But the government's policies remained unchanged. The war continued, landowners controlled the land, oppressed peoples remained disenfranchised, and workers were threatened with lockouts (the closure of enterprises). The revolutionary mood of the masses grew. They increasingly listened to the voice of the Bolsheviks. The Bolshevik Party grew stronger. In early June 1917, the First All-Russian Congress of Soviets of Workers' and Soldiers' Deputies was held in Petrograd . At this congress, the Mensheviks and Socialist Revolutionaries still held a majority. They secured the congress's approval for support of the bourgeois government and an offensive at the front. The offensive at the front began then. It ended in defeat for the Russian army. The soldiers were reluctant to go into battle, refusing to fight for the interests of the bourgeoisie and demanding the transfer of all power to the Soviets. In vain did the Provisional Government's Minister of War, the Socialist Revolutionary Kerensky, try to persuade the soldiers to shed their blood for a cause alien to them. "The bourgeoisie needs the war," the soldiers replied, "let them fight themselves." The Provisional Government ordered the execution of soldiers who refused to go into battle. The soldiers became increasingly convinced of the betrayal of their interests by the Mensheviks and Socialist Revolutionaries and defected to the Bolsheviks. Demonstrations of workers and soldiers began again in Russia's major cities. The July demonstration and the mutiny of General Kornilov. The summer of 1917 arrived. The Provisional Government still had not satisfied a single demand of the workers, soldiers, peasants, and oppressed peoples of Russia. The devastation in industry and on the railways intensified. Factories and plants were shut down, there were no raw materials or fuel. There was a shortage of bread and meat. Famine was looming. The workers' struggle against the capitalists and their government intensified. Strikes were continuous. Workers organized their own armed units—the Red Guard. Peasant uprisings broke out in the villages. Soldiers left the front in the thousands. Oppressed peoples, denied liberation by the Provisional Government, came forward with their just demands. On July 3, 1917, masses of Petrograd workers, soldiers, and sailors demonstrated under Bolshevik slogans. The bourgeoisie, in collusion with the Mensheviks and Socialist Revolutionaries, called in elite cadet and kulak military units from the front and executed the demonstration, smashing workers' organizations.
Shooting of the demonstration on July 3, 1917, in Petrograd .
Cadets and officers attacked the editorial office of the newspaper Pravda. Bolsheviks were arrested and imprisoned. The Bolsheviks were forced to go underground again. The Provisional Government ordered Lenin's arrest. At the insistence of the Party, Lenin went into hiding. Lenin disguised himself as a worker and, with a passport in the name of a worker named Ivanov, lived in a hut on the outskirts of Petrograd , near Sestroretsk, and some time later moved to Finland. Bourgeois bloodhounds hunted Lenin in vain. The workers protected their beloved leader by all means. The bourgeoisie raged in the rear and at the front. Even the most backward workers began to understand the consequences of the Mensheviks and Socialist Revolutionaries, who defended the interests of the bourgeoisie. More and more workers joined the ranks of the Bolsheviks. The membership of the Bolshevik Party increased to 200,000. At the end of July, the Sixth Congress of the Bolshevik Party convened in Petrograd . Lenin was not present at the congress. He was in hiding. Stalin led the congress. He called on the party to prepare for an armed uprising. The congress outlined the path to victory for the socialist revolution and developed measures to combat the economic devastation in the country. Delegates scattered across Russia began preparing workers and poor peasants for an uprising against the Provisional Government, to overthrow its authority, and to establish the power of the Soviets, the power of workers and peasants. Then the bourgeoisie and landowners organized a conspiracy against the revolution. On their instructions, General Kornilov assembled large detachments of officers, Cossacks, and backward troops and marched them on Petrograd to smash the Soviets of Workers' and Soldiers' Deputies, strangle the workers and peasants, and declare himself the absolute ruler of Russia. At the call of the Bolsheviks, the workers of Petrograd and the Petrograd troops rose up. Revolutionary agitators—workers and soldiers—sent to meet Kornilov's troops told Kornilov's soldiers of their general's true intentions. The soldiers of Kornilov's regiments refused to oppose the revolution. The bourgeoisie's conspiracy failed. Under pressure from the workers and peasants, Kerensky was forced to arrest Kornilov and imprison him. The workers' and soldiers' victory over Kornilov further strengthened the Bolshevik Party's influence. After the Kornilov rebellion, workers and soldiers began expelling the Mensheviks and Socialist Revolutionaries from the Soviets and electing Bolsheviks in their place. In the fall of 1917, the majority of the Petrograd and Moscow Soviets went over to the Bolsheviks. The Soviets became the true centers of the proletarian revolution. They armed the workers, created the Red Guard, and prepared for an armed uprising. In early October, Lenin, hiding from the bourgeois government, appeared in Petrograd to lead the uprising. Lenin declared that the workers' victory was now assured, that an armed uprising must be launched immediately, the government of the bourgeoisie, the Mensheviks, and the Socialist Revolutionaries must be overthrown, and the power of the Soviets must be established.
54. The socialist revolution triumphed.
The victorious uprising of October 25 (November 7), 1917. The Bolshevik Party was preparing for the final, decisive battle—the overthrow of bourgeois power by force of arms. The moment for the uprising was well chosen. The world war continued. In Russia, the majority of workers followed the Bolsheviks. The compromising Menshevik and Socialist-Revolutionary parties had lost the trust of the working people. Many Soviets of Workers' and Soldiers' Deputies were in Bolshevik hands. The workers had their own strong trade unions and the Red Guard. The peasants did not want to wait for the convocation of the Constituent Assembly, as the compromising Socialist-Revolutionary and Menshevik parties advised them to do, and followed the Bolsheviks, who demanded the immediate seizure of the landowners' lands. They expelled the landowners from their namedays and seized the land. The soldiers did not want to continue the war. They rejected Kerensky's order to fight to the bitter end and demanded peace. Not only Russian workers and peasants, but also the peoples of Transcaucasia, Ukraine, Belarus, Central Asia, and Finland rose up against Kerensky's Provisional Government. The Bolsheviks vigorously prepared for the uprising. Its plan was carefully developed.
V. I. Lenin (1870–1924)
Lenin and Stalin among the Red Guards.
But in the most decisive days of preparation for the uprising, Kamenev, Zinoviev, and Trotsky betrayed the plans and dates of the uprising to the bourgeoisie. The Provisional Government, having learned of the uprising from traitors, urgently mobilized troops loyal to it to fight it. But the days of bourgeois rule were numbered. The Central Committee of the Bolshevik Party created a combat center to lead the uprising, headed by Comrade Stalin. Following Lenin's instructions, on October 24, 1917, the combat center launched the uprising. Lenin stood at its head.
V. I. Lenin leads the uprising in the October days of 1917.
As one, the Red Guards, revolutionary soldiers, and sailors of Kronstadt rose up in response to the call of the Bolshevik Party. The courage, revolutionary drive, and discipline of the revolutionary soldiers quickly did their job. All government institutions and military posts in Petrograd were occupied by the Red Guards. The ministers of the Provisional Government, along with detachments of officers and cadets, fortified themselves in the Winter Palace. On October 25, revolutionary troops surrounded the palace. The revolutionary cruiser Aurora and three destroyers entered the Neva River. The siege of the palace lasted until evening. Darkness fell. Only the enormous Winter Palace remained illuminated. Toward nightfall, the fighting intensified. Machine guns rattled. Rifle volleys rang out. A firefight broke out between the troops entrenched in the palace and the advancing revolutionaries. The Red Guards began their assault on the palace.
Revolutionary sailors storm the Winter Palace in October 1917.
The Bolsheviks, who had led the capture of the Winter Palace, offered the besieged forces the opportunity to surrender. They refused. The signal was given. The cannons of the Peter and Paul Fortress opened fire on the Winter Palace. The guns of the cruiser Aurora roared. The artillery fire had its effect. The machine guns in the palace fell silent. The revolutionary troops stormed the palace. The officers and cadets continued to fire back, but soon they surrendered. The Red Guards entered the palace's circular room through a narrow corridor. Several frightened people sat at tables. This was the last bourgeois government in Russia. Kerensky was not there, having managed to escape and hide. In the name of the revolution, all the ministers were declared under arrest. Those arrested were taken to the fortress. The proletarian revolution had triumphed throughout the country. The working class celebrated its victory. On October 25, the people of Petrograd read Lenin's proclamation with profound emotion. It declared that the Provisional Government had fallen, and power had passed into the hands of the Soviets of Workers' and Soldiers' Deputies. The cause for which the people had fought—ending the war, abolishing landlord ownership of land, and establishing a Soviet government—was assured. It was now possible to establish workers' control over factories and plants to combat economic devastation. The Second All-Russian Congress of Soviets of Workers' and Soldiers' Deputies opened at the same time. Lenin submitted, and the congress approved, the first three decrees of the Great Proletarian Revolution: on peace, on land, and on power. The Decree on Peace proposed that all belligerent states immediately begin negotiations to end the war and conclude a peace on the basis of equality. The Decree on Land abolished the landlord class, abolished private landownership, and transferred it to the use of all working people. Peasants received over 150 million hectares of land from the Soviet government. The Decree on Power transferred all power in the country to the Soviets. Our country became a Soviet Republic. The Congress elected the All-Russian Central Executive Committee and the Council of People's Commissars. V. I. Lenin became the head of the Council of People's Commissars. Comrade Stalin was elected People's Commissar for Nationalities. Soon after the Congress, Comrade Sverdlov was elected Chairman of the All-Russian Central Executive Committee. News of the proletariat's victory in Petrograd quickly spread throughout the country. In a number of cities, workers had to wage fierce battles to seize power.
Yakov Mikhailovich Sverdlov (1885–1919).
In Moscow, officers and cadets seized the Kremlin and a number of large buildings. Red Guard workers were forced to dig trenches and wage a real war against counterrevolutionaries. Fighting raged in Moscow for a whole week. Only with cannon fire did the workers and soldiers force the officers and cadets to surrender.
