Telegrams about the transfer of power to the Soviets flew from all Russian cities to Petrograd . The peoples of Siberia, Central Asia, Belarus, the Volga region, and the left bank of Ukraine, with the help of the Soviet government, were liberating themselves from centuries-old oppression by the bourgeoisie and landowners.
The capture of the Kremlin by insurgent workers in Moscow in the October days of 1917.
The victory of the socialist Soviet revolution is thus explained by the following reasons: 1) The bourgeois government of the Socialist Revolutionary Kerensky had completely failed in the eyes of the workers and peasants. Kerensky sought to continue the war to a victorious conclusion, while the workers, peasants, and soldiers demanded an end to the war and the conclusion of peace. Kerensky sought to preserve the lands for the landowners, while the workers and peasants demanded the immediate seizure of the landowners' lands for the peasants. Kerensky sought to curb the workers, while the workers and peasants demanded the curbing of factory owners and the establishment of workers' organizations over them. 2) The second reason is that, on the basis of these demands, a strong alliance of workers and peasants was formed and consolidated in the form of the Sonnets of Workers' and Soldiers' Deputies against the bourgeois Provisional Government and its lackeys—the Socialist Revolutionaries and Mensheviks—in support of the Bolshevik Party. 3) The third reason is that the workers and peasants en masse abandoned the compromising Socialist Revolutionaries and Mensheviks and rallied around the Bolshevik Party, recognizing it as their leader and guide. Without these reasons, the October Revolution could not have succeeded. The Bolshevik Party organized the Soviet state. From the very first days of the victory of the Great Proletarian Revolution, Lenin and Stalin began organizing the Soviet state as a fraternal socialist union of all peoples. The peoples of Russia received from Soviet power complete liberation, such as no other people in the world had ever experienced.
Felix Edmundovich Dzerzhinsky (1877–1926).
Following the decrees on peace and land, a decree on workers' control was issued. Workers' control was established over capitalists in factories and plants, over the production, storage, purchase, and sale of all food products and raw materials. The Council of People's Commissars declared a refusal to pay all debts to foreign states. However, defeated in the capital and the country's centers, the enemies of Soviet power—landowners, capitalists, generals, and priests, along with the Mensheviks and Socialist Revolutionaries—fled to the outskirts of Russia. In the Don region, in right-bank Ukraine, in the Caucasus, in the Orenburg steppes, and in Siberia, they attempted to consolidate their position and organize a campaign against Soviet power. XIV. Transition to Peaceful Work to Rebuild the Country's Economy
60. Rebuilding the National Economy. The Creation of the USSR:
Lenin's Plan for Escape from Devastation. The world war and the civil war imposed by the Entente and counterrevolutionaries had brought the country to utter ruin. Many factories and plants were idle: there was no fuel or raw materials, broken locomotives and mangled carriages littered the railroad tracks. Bridges and railroad tracks had been blown up in many places by the Whites and had to be rebuilt. Industry produced five times less goods than before the war. Peasant fields were poorly cultivated. Much livestock had been taken away during the Tsarist war. Many were killed during the Civil War. Agriculture yielded half as much food as in 1914. There was famine in the country. Private trade was prohibited during the Civil War. Peasants, accustomed to trade, expressed discontent at this time. The bourgeoisie and kulaks, taking advantage of this discontent, roused peasants in several places to revolt against Soviet rule. The Party and the Soviet government decided to implement a number of measures to improve the country's economy. Vladimir Ilyich proposed the following plan in 1921. During the Civil War, peasants donated all their surplus grain to industry, workers, and the Red Army. Workers and peasants had formed a military alliance against landowners and factory owners. Now they needed an alliance to restore the economy and build socialism. Let the peasants not give all their surplus to the state, but pay a precisely defined tax in kind. They could dispose of their remaining products as they wish. To this end, private trade must be permitted. Private industrialists and merchants should be allowed to open small businesses and conduct trade. For the time being, let private industrialists and merchants produce and trade goods. "We will quickly grow stronger and displace private capital. And the time will come when we will completely eliminate the remnants of capitalists and kulaks in our country," Lenin said. Lenin's plan was adopted. It was called the New Economic Policy (NEP). To speed up economic recovery, the Communist Party, as it had during the Civil War, held subbotniks (workdays) for the first time. All workers participated. They worked for free for the benefit of their homeland. Lenin's plan proved successful. Within three to four years, the country's economy was firmly on its feet: factories and plants began operating, and the railways improved. Agriculture also boomed. Peasants brought grain, meat, and eggs to the markets. They began sowing beets and flax, and increased cotton cultivation. Sugar refineries and textile factories began operating across the country. Workers and peasants now had access to grain, sugar, fabrics, and many other goods. Many state-owned and cooperative stores opened. These enterprises began to displace private traders. Vladimir Ilyich Lenin—that mountain eagle, as Stalin called him—had a far-reaching vision. He said that workers and peasants could easily overcome devastation and lead happy lives. They would have to have factories within their own economy where machines were made, and these machines would have to run on electricity. The entire country, Lenin said more than once, needed to be covered with a network of power plants. A plan for the country's electrification was developed. At Lenin's suggestion, construction began on the first large water-powered electric power station on the Volkhov River, near Leningrad. In 1926, after Lenin's death, the station was completed and provided electricity to Leningrad's factories and plants. This helped restore Leningrad's vital industry. Red soldiers won glorious victories in battles against the White and Japanese forces near Spassk and Volochayevka. It was necessary to revive the economy and build socialism. It was necessary to assist all the peoples of the Land of Soviets in raising their national culture. To this end, in 1922, at the suggestion of Lenin and Stalin, delegates from the union republics gathered in Moscow for the First All-Union Congress of Soviets and formed a voluntary state association of peoples, a union state called the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (USSR). Initially, the USSR united several Soviet republics: the Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic (RSFSR), with its capital Moscow; the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic (USSR), with its capital initially in Kharkov and later in Kiev; and the Byelorussian Soviet Socialist Republic (BSSR), with its capital Minsk. The Transcaucasian Soviet Socialist Republics—Azerbaijan, Georgia, and Armenia—formed a single union—the Transcaucasian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic (TSFSR), with its capital Tbilisi. A little later, three independent Soviet republics were established in Central Asia: Uzbekistan, with its capital in Tashkent; Turkmenistan, with its capital in Ashgabat; and Tajikistan, with its capital in Stalinabad. These republics also became part of the USSR.

The liberated peoples began to rebuild their war-torn economies. In 1922, under the leadership of the Bolshevik Party, they created the great Union of Soviet Socialist Republics. The USSR initially included four union republics, later joined by three more. Nowhere in the world has there been, or continues to be, such friendship and mutual trust among peoples as in the USSR. In 1924, the free peoples of the USSR adopted the first Constitution of the USSR (the Basic Law of the State). In it, they enshrined the country's victories. Much time has passed since then—industry has been built and expanded enormously, collective and state farms have been established, culture has flourished, the remnants of landowners, capitalists, and kulaks have been uprooted and destroyed, the exploitation of workers and oppression of people have been abolished. But in our country, enemies of the Soviet people, enemies of the USSR, still remained. It was they—the friends of Trotsky, Zinoviev, and Kamenev, and with them Rykov and Bukharin—who organized a gang of murderers, saboteurs, and spies in the USSR. In 1936, a commission led by I. V. Stalin drafted a new Constitution of the USSR. It was submitted for broad public debate and then approved by the highest governing body of the Union—the All-Union Congress of Soviets. The day the Constitution was approved, December 5, was declared a national holiday. The Constitution enshrines the most important achievements of the Soviet Union during its 19 years of existence. The previous Constitution stated that our republic was called socialist because the working class held power and strove to build socialism. The new Constitution calls our state a socialist state of workers and peasants because socialism had already been largely built in the USSR. In the USSR, all power belongs to the workers of the city and village—the Soviets of Workers' Deputies. The land, its mineral wealth, factories, mines, plants, railways, large buildings, and state farms (state farms) are the property of the state and the common property of the people. Alongside state ownership, there is cooperative and collective farm ownership, the property of individual collective farms, and cooperative associations. The Constitution stipulates that small-scale farming by artisans and individual peasants is also permitted in the USSR, but only on the condition that such artisans or individual peasants work independently and do not exploit the labor of others. Our state achieved all this because it abolished the landowners and capitalists, destroyed the kulaks, and abolished the exploitation of man by man. In the USSR, all people capable of labor must work. "He who does not work, neither shall he eat." The USSR is a voluntary and friendly association of equal peoples. "And this friendship is a great thing: as long as it exists," said Stalin, "the peoples of our country will be free and invincible." Currently, the USSR is a voluntary association of 16 equal union republics. The USSR includes: the Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic, the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic, the Byelorussian Soviet Socialist Republic, the Uzbek Soviet Socialist Republic, the Kazakh Soviet Socialist Republic, the Georgian Soviet Socialist Republic, the Azerbaijan Soviet Socialist Republic, the Lithuanian Soviet Socialist Republic, the Moldavian Soviet Socialist Republic, the Latvian Soviet Socialist Republic, the Kirghiz Soviet Socialist Republic, the Tajik Soviet Socialist Republic, the Armenian Soviet Socialist Republic, the Turkmen Soviet Socialist Republic, the Estonian Soviet Socialist Republic, and the Karelo-Finnish Soviet Socialist Republic.
The highest body of state power in the USSR is the Supreme Soviet of the USSR. Only the Supreme Soviet has the right to issue laws. It forms the government of the USSR — the Council of Ministers of the USSR. At the local level, the organs of power everywhere are the councils of workers' deputies. All local councils, as well as the supreme councils of the union and autonomous republics, as well as the Supreme Soviet of the USSR, are elected by citizens of the USSR on the basis of universal, equal, and direct suffrage by secret ballot. All citizens of the USSR, both men and women, who have reached the age of 18, regardless of race, nationality, religion, educational qualifications, social origin, property status, or past activities, have the right to participate in the elections of deputies, with the exception of the insane and individuals convicted by a court with deprivation of voting rights. Citizens who have reached the age of 23 may be elected to the Supreme Soviet of the USSR. Such elections are called universal. All citizens have equal rights in elections. Citizens of our country elect deputies to all bodies of government by personal vote. Such elections are called direct elections. Voting in elections is secret; every citizen votes for the person they wish to elect to the council. Citizens of the USSR have the right to work, rest, education, and financial security in old age. These rights are guaranteed by our state. In a socialist country, there is no unemployment, which affects millions of workers in capitalist countries. Thousands of rest homes and sanatoriums are open to workers. Every year, all workers and employees of the USSR are granted vacation. In the USSR, all workers can study and receive an education. The state provides scholarships to many students. In the USSR, every person is cared for from birth to old age. Nurseries and kindergartens are organized for children. The elderly and sick are provided with state assistance. All citizens of the USSR are guaranteed freedom of speech, press, assembly, and street demonstrations. But in addition to rights, every citizen of the USSR also has responsibilities to the state. All citizens are obliged to strictly comply with the laws of the Soviet Union, maintain discipline, work honestly, and protect and strengthen socialist property. Anyone who encroaches on socialist property is an enemy of the peoples of the USSR. Defending the Fatherland from any and all enemies of the USSR is the highest duty of a citizen of the USSR. If anyone goes over to the enemy's side or reveals the USSR's military secrets to the enemy, he will betray his homeland, his people, and will be punished as an enemy of the USSR.

At Comrade Stalin's call, all Soviet peoples rose as one to fight for their homeland. Everyone understood that this was the Great Patriotic War, a war for the liberation and independence of our beloved homeland. Everyone knew: if we win, we will be free, but if we are defeated, we will become slaves to the German princes and barons. The workers of Moscow and Leningrad prepared for defense. Many old men and women took up arms and joined the militia. Thousands of Muscovites and Leningraders dug trenches and anti-tank ditches, built fortifications, and extinguished fires ignited by enemy bombs. The Soviet Army displayed miracles of heroism near Moscow and Leningrad. For example, on the approaches to Moscow, 28 guardsmen from General Panfilov's division withstood an onslaught of 50 German tanks. They cried, "There is nowhere further to retreat. Moscow is behind us." They knew they would perish in an unequal battle, but they didn't waver, fighting to their last breath and holding off the tanks for four hours, destroying 14 of them. The entire nation fought with such courage. By the beginning of winter 1941, the enemy had not only been held back but also driven back from Moscow. The Germans still had plenty of strength. Having suffered defeats near Moscow and Leningrad, they launched an offensive in the south in the summer of 1942. The Nazis were pushing east. Devastating Soviet lands, they invaded the fertile steppes of the Northern Caucasus, approached the Volga near Stalingrad, and stopped on the Don near Voronezh. The Germans wanted to outflank Moscow and cut it off from the Urals and Siberia. The danger was great. Our homeland strained every nerve to fight. In areas captured by the enemy. Capturing Soviet lands, the Nazis devastated them. They stole grain, livestock, and various foodstuffs from the population. They destroyed libraries, schools, and museums. They took everything of value for themselves and took it to Germany. Soviet people were forced to work for the Germans. Thousands of men, women, and girls were deported to Germany and sold into slavery to German landowners and kulaks. The Nazis tortured and executed people for the slightest resistance. Gallows were erected in town and village squares. But no amount of persecution could intimidate the Soviet people. To fight the invaders, partisan detachments were formed everywhere. The partisans carried out Comrade Stalin's orders: they attacked Nazi garrisons, blew up bridges, and derailed trains. When captured by the enemy, the partisans steadfastly endured excruciating torture, never revealing anything the enemy wanted to know. Thus, Soviet girls died heroically—Zoya Kosmodemyanskaya, Liza Chaikina, pioneer Sasha Chekalin, and many others. But hundreds of thousands of Nazis were killed by the partisans in the Soviet rear. At the same time, our homeland had become a single military camp. Men went to the front. Women and the elderly replaced those who had left in the rear. Collective farmers provided the country with bread, food, and raw materials for industry. Workers worked day and night. Many new factories were built. The country produced more and more tanks, planes, guns, mortars, and shells. Trains ran continuously along the railways to the west, delivering everything necessary to the front. Our tanks, planes, and guns proved superior to the Germans. And soon, we outstripped the Nazis in terms of weaponry. Heroes of the front. Soviet people selflessly and heroically fought against the enemy. Captain Gastello's plane caught fire in battle. The pilot could have parachuted, but he didn't. Gastello flew the flaming plane into a column of enemy gasoline vehicles and blew them up. Brave Russian pilots Zdorovtsev and Kharitonov expended all their ammunition in aerial combat. But they didn't want to lose the enemy and aimed their planes at their bombers. The German planes were rammed, and our heroic pilots remained unharmed. Soldier Matrosov was advancing with his unit. A machine gun was firing from a Nazi fortification. Matrosov rushed to it and shielded it with his body. The machine gun failed to fire, and our forces broke through the enemy defenses. Azerbaijani Gusein Aliyev single-handedly engaged several Nazi aircraft. Seventeen wounds covered his body, but he shot down the enemy and emerged victorious. A brave fighter from Kazakhstan, Torupsabayev, was advancing on the attack. A German gunshot struck his platoon commander. Confusion ensued. Then Torupsabayev ran forward and shouted, "For the Motherland!" He led his platoon against the Germans. The enemy wavered, and when the battle ended, Torupsabayev simply said, "My job is small—to defeat the Germans. But together, we are a great force." Thus, the workers and peasants, all the peoples of the Soviet Union, rose up in unison, both at the rear and at the front, to fight the hated enemy. The Nazi invaders were routed. In the autumn of 1942, the Germans were held back near Stalingrad. Every day, they rained thousands of bombs on the city, pounding it with heavy artillery. The city was reduced to rubble, but it did not surrender. Here, Comrade Stalin prepared a crushing blow for the enemy. In November, the Soviet Army launched an offensive at Stalingrad. At the appointed hour, Soviet artillery thundered, tanks advanced, and infantry charged. The great Battle of Stalingrad had begun. The German front was broken. 300,000 fascist soldiers were encircled and routed. The invaders were driven from the Volga, Don, and the North Caucasus. Thus began the liberation of our lands. It was not easy to drive back the brutal enemy. He fought back furiously, but was routed in a series of major battles: at Kursk, Leningrad, on the Dnieper, in Crimea, in Belarus, in Bessarabia, and in the Baltics. In all these battles, many German divisions were destroyed or disabled. Withdrawing from Soviet soil, the vicious enemy sought to destroy everything. As they retreated, the Nazis burned villages and towns. They killed thousands of Soviet people—even children were spared. They took everything of value with them. In the summer of 1944, all Soviet soil was cleared of the invaders. Victory salutes thundered joyfully in Moscow. The unity of freedom-loving peoples. The Soviet Army extended military operations beyond our homeland's borders and soon decisively defeated Germany's allies—Romania, Bulgaria, Finland, and Hungary. Our troops entered their lands. All these states admitted defeat. Their peoples expelled their rulers and, together with the Soviet Army, began the war against Nazi Germany. Dealing blow after blow to the Germans, our army liberated Poland, Yugoslavia, and Czechoslovakia. The peoples enslaved by the Nazis greeted their liberator with gratitude. They saw and understood that the Soviet Union was their best friend. The friendship between all freedom-loving peoples grew stronger with each passing day. The Soviet Union bore the brunt of the war. For three years of war, England and the United States of America delayed opening a second front in Europe against German troops by every means possible. But when, after the Soviet Army's enormous victories, it became clear that the Soviet Union alone could completely defeat the enemy, occupy German territory, and liberate all of Western Europe, including France, England and the United States opened a second front in Europe. In June 1944, British and American troops crossed the sea from England and landed on the coast of northern France. Victory over Nazi Germany. In January 1945, the Soviet Army entered Germany. Generalissimo of the Soviet Union Comrade Stalin called for "pursuing the wounded German beast on the heels and finishing it off in its own lair." German fortifications were breached, fortresses destroyed. Soviet troops surrounded large groups of German troops and, if they did not surrender, they were destroyed. The valiant Soviet troops advanced rapidly, crushing the enemy on its own territory. Our victorious banners fluttered over enemy territory. By April 21, 1945, our soldiers had already reached Berlin and engaged in battle on its outskirts. A few days later, Berlin was surrounded on all sides, and on May 2, it was captured by troops of the 1st Ukrainian and 1st Belorussian Fronts. The capture of the German capital was the most powerful blow to Germany, followed by its defeat. On May 8, Nazi Germany capitulated (surrendered to the mercy of the victor). The entire Soviet Union, as well as other countries that had fought against Germany, celebrated the victory over the fascist beast. The Soviet government declared May 9 Victory Day, a day of national celebration for the Soviet people. Thus, Hitler's wild ideas to enslave the Slavic peoples were not destined to come true. The centuries-long struggle of the Slavic peoples for their existence and independence ended in victory over the German invaders.
Nikita Sergeyevich Khrushchev, First Secretary of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union.
The defeat of Japan. Japan was Germany's ally in the Far East. The Japanese invaders sought to enslave China and other countries. They also repeatedly attacked our homeland. To ensure our country's security not only in the West but also in the East, to shorten the end of the war, and to facilitate the speedy restoration of world peace, the Soviet Union entered the war against the Japanese invaders. On September 2, 1945, under the crushing blows of the Soviet Army, Japan admitted defeat and laid down its arms.
Kliment Yefremovich Voroshilov, Chairman of the Presidium of the Supreme Soviet of the USSR.
The exploits of the Soviet people, and above all the Russian people, the most outstanding of all the nations comprising the Soviet Union, won victory for our country. Thanks to the heroic efforts of the front and rear, the Soviet people, led by their great commander, Comrade Stalin, managed to defeat the enemy and save the homeland from enslavement.
67. USSR after the war.
As a result of the Great Patriotic War, our homeland grew even stronger, its influence and authority increased among all countries of the world. In October 1952, the 19th Congress of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union convened in Moscow. The congress adopted a new five-year plan for 1951–1955. This plan outlined a new, powerful upsurge in the country's entire national economy. On March 5, 1953, the Soviet people and workers around the world suffered a grave, irreparable loss. Stalin, Lenin's disciple and successor, died at the age of 73. The death of I. V. Stalin, who dedicated his entire life to serving the people, was a profound loss. The bright memory of I. V. Stalin will live forever in the hearts of working people throughout the world. After the death of I. V. Stalin, our people rallied even more closely around the Communist Party and the Soviet government. All the efforts of the Soviet people are focused primarily on the development of heavy industry. In our country, the production of metal, machinery, and electricity increases every year, while coal and oil production grows. The growth of heavy industry helps develop agriculture, light industry, and the food industry, strengthening our country's defense. The Communist Party and the Soviet government are constantly committed to improving the lives of our people.
Chairman of the Council of Ministers of the USSR Nikolai Alexandrovich Bulganin.
The party and government are led by loyal and proven disciples and comrades of Lenin and Stalin. Nikita Sergeyevich Khrushchev was elected First Secretary of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union, Kliment Yefremovich Voroshilov was elected Chairman of the Presidium of the Supreme Soviet of the USSR, and Nikolai Alexandrovich Bulganin was appointed Chairman of the Council of Ministers of the USSR. Under the leadership of the Communist Party and the Soviet government, the workers of our country are confidently moving towards the bright goal of communism.
